4. 集中精力于成本驱动因素，特别关注那些占成本很大或不断增长百分比的活动。您的相对成本状况 (RCP) 是根据执行价值链中所有活动的累计成本建立起来的。您的成本结构与竞争对手的成本结构之间是否存在实际或潜在的差异？这里的挑战是尽可能准确地了解与每项活动相关的全部成本，不仅包括直接运营和资产成本，还包括因您执行此活动而产生的间接成本。*

4. Zero in on cost drivers, paying special attention to activities that represent a large or growing percentage of costs. Your relative cost position (RCP) is built up from the cumulative cost of performing all the activities in the value chain. Are there actual or potential differences between your cost structure and those of your rivals? The challenge here is to get as accurate a picture as you can of the full costs associated with each activity, including not only direct operating and asset costs but also the overhead costs that are generated because you perform this activity.*

为了解决这个问题，你可以问自己，如果停止执行这项活动，可以削减哪些具体的间接费用。

To get a handle on this, you can ask yourself what specific overhead costs could be cut if you stopped performing this activity.

对于每项活动而言，成本优势或劣势取决于成本动因或一系列影响相对成本的影响因素。相对成本分析的真正“那又怎样”在于，当你深入研究数字，发现可以采取哪些行动来改进它们时。一个完整的例子可以写成一章。这里提供的简短示例可以让您了解我的意思。西南航空长期以来一直享有成本优势，以其每可用座位英里较低的相对成本来衡量。要理解原因，你需要列出西南航空的所有活动，为它们分配成本，然后将结果与其他航​​空公司的结果进行比较。让我们只追踪一项活动：登机口周转。西南航空做得更快，因此它从资产中获得更多收益 — — 其每架飞机和每位员工的成本低于竞争对手。

For each activity, a cost advantage or disadvantage depends on cost drivers, or a series of influences on relative cost. The real “so what” of relative cost analysis comes when you dig deep enough into the numbers to uncover the actions you can take to improve them. A full-blown example would fill its own chapter. The brief one provided here will give you a sense of what I mean. Southwest Airlines has long enjoyed a cost advantage, as measured in its low relative cost per available seat mile. To understand why, you would list all of Southwest’s activities, assign costs to them, and then compare the results with those of other carriers. Let’s follow the trail on just one activity: gate turnarounds. Southwest does it faster, and as a result it gets more out of its assets—its costs per plane and per employee are lower than those of rivals.

看到登机口周转是一项重要的成本驱动因素，您就会更深入地研究登机口周转所涉及的许多具体子活动。在这里，您会寻找在不牺牲客户价值的情况下降低成本的方法。这就是您与竞争对手的业绩差距更大的原因。例如，当飞机降落时，必须排空洗手间。为此，需要将一台设备连接到服务面板上。西南航空发现，问题在于这会干扰地勤人员的其他服务活动。解决方案：西南航空让其供应商波音公司重新定位新 737-300 中的服务面板。

Seeing that gate turnarounds are a significant cost driver, you would then dive a level deeper, to the many specific subactivities involved in gate turnarounds. Here you’d be looking for ways to lower your costs without sacrificing customer value. This is how you drive an even greater wedge between your performance and that of your rivals. When a plane lands, for example, the lavatories have to be drained. To do this, a piece of equipment is hooked up to a service panel. The problem, Southwest discovered, was that this interfered with the ground crew’s other servicing activities. The solution: Southwest got its supplier, Boeing, to reposition the service panel in the new 737-300.

西南航空的例子表明，找出成本驱动因素就像侦探工作一样困难。它既需要创造力，也需要严谨的分析。更简单的方法就是接受行业的传统观念。例如，20 世纪 90 年代的大多数汽车公司都坚信规模是决定性的成本驱动因素，如果你一年卖不出至少 400 万辆汽车，你的成本就会压垮你。随后出现了一股整合狂潮，但其中大部分后来都失败了。

As the Southwest example shows, ferreting out cost drivers can be like detective work. It demands both creativity and rigorous analysis. The easier path is simply to accept the industry’s conventional wisdom. Most auto companies in the 1990s, for example, accepted on faith that scale was the decisive cost driver, that if you didn’t sell at least four million cars a year, your costs would kill you. A frenzy of consolidation, much of it subsequently undone, followed.

当然，规模在汽车行业很重要。但更深入地了解成本驱动因素至关重要。例如，本田是一家相对较小的汽车公司。这可能会让您得出结论，本田在成本方面处于劣势。但本田是世界上最大的摩托车生产商，总体而言，它是一家庞大的发动机生产商。由于发动机占汽车成本的 10%，而本田可以在其产品线之间分摊发动机开发成本，因此这一范围优势抵消了其整体规模不足。此外，本田对发动机开发的关注是支持其定价的差异化因素。

Of course, scale matters in the auto industry. But a deeper understanding of the cost drivers is critical. Honda, for example, is a relatively small car company. This might lead you to conclude that Honda would have a cost disadvantage. But Honda is the world’s largest producer of motorcycles, and overall it is a huge producer of engines. Since engines account for 10 percent of the cost of a car and Honda can share the cost of engine development across its product lines, this scope advantage offsets its overall lack of scale. Moreover, Honda’s focus on engine development is an element of differentiation that supports its pricing.

你真的有竞争优势吗？首先量化，然后分解

Do You Really Have a Competitive Advantage? First You Quantify, and Then You Disaggregate

 
 
  1. 您的每项业务的长期盈利能力与经济中的其他公司相比如何？在美国，从 1992 年到 2006 年，平均公司净资产收益率约为 14.9%（息税前利润除以平均投资资本减去超额现金），尽管这一数字在商业周期中略有不同。您的企业回报是好还是坏？如果好，说明有些事情对您有利。如果坏，说明有些事情出了问题。无论哪种情况，都要深入挖掘根本原因。
  2. How does the long-term profitability in each of your businesses stack up against other companies in the economy? In the United States, from 1992 to 2006, the average company earned about 14.9 percent return on equity (earnings before interest and taxes divided by average invested capital less excess cash), although this varied somewhat over the business cycle. Are the returns for your business better or worse? If better, something is working in your favor. If worse, then something is wrong. In either case, dig deeper into the underlying causes.
    3.  
  3. 现在，将您的业绩与您所在行业的平均回报进行比较，并比较过去五到十年的表现。由于天气等一系列瞬息万变的因素，盈利能力可能会在短期内波动。选择一个较长的时间范围，最好是与您所在行业的投资周期相匹配的时间范围。这将告诉您是否具有竞争优势。

    假设 A 公司获得了 15% 的回报，而全国基准为 13%，行业基准为 10%。行业结构分析将解释为什么整个行业比全国平均水平低 3 个百分点。但 A 的出色表现（比行业高出 5 个百分点）表明它具有竞争优势。因此，在这种情况下，A 不存在战略问题。另一方面，它确实必须应对具有挑战性的行业结构。区分这两个盈利来源至关重要，因为影响行业结构的因素和决定相对地位的因素非常不同。除非一家公司了解其利润表现来自何处，否则它将无法战略性地应对它。

  4. Now compare your performance to the average return in your industry, and do so over the last five to ten years. Profitability can fluctuate in the short run as a result of a number of factors as transient as the weather. Choose a longer time horizon, ideally one that matches the investment cycle of your industry. This will tell you whether or not you have a competitive advantage.

    Suppose company A earns a 15 percent return against a national benchmark of 13 percent and an industry benchmark of 10 percent. The analysis of industry structure will explain why the industry overall is 3 points below the national average. But A’s superior performance—it exceeds its industry by 5 points—indicates that it has a competitive advantage. So in this case, A does not have a strategy problem. On the other hand, it does have to deal with a challenging industry structure. The distinction between these two sources of profitability is crucial because the factors that affect industry structure and those that determine relative position are very different. Until a company understands where its profit performance comes from, it will be ill equipped to deal with it strategically.

    5.  
  5. 接下来，继续深入挖掘，了解为什么企业表现优于或差于行业平均水平。将相对绩效分解为两个部分：相对价格和相对成本。相对价格和成本对于理解战略和绩效至关重要。

    在讨论的例子中，A 公司获得的回报比平均竞争对手高出 5%。其实际价格（调整优惠和折扣后）比行业平均水平高出 8%。为了获得这一溢价，A 公司必须花费更多：在这种情况下，其相对成本高出 3 个百分点。这解释了 A 公司高出 5% 的回报。

  6. Next, keep digging to understand why the business is performing better or worse than the industry average. Disaggregate your relative performance into its two components: relative price and relative cost. Relative price and cost are essential for understanding strategy and performance.

    In the example under discussion, company A achieved a 5 percent higher return than the average competitor. Its realized price (adjusting for concessions and discounts) was 8 percent higher than the industry average. To command that premium, company A had to spend more: in this case, its relative cost was 3 percentage points higher. That explains A’s 5 percent higher return.

    7.  
  7. 进一步挖掘。在价格方面，可以将整体价格溢价（或折扣）追溯到特定产品线、客户或地理区域的差异，或标价与标价外折扣之间的差异。在成本方面，将成本优势（或劣势）分解为运营成本（损益表）和资本利用（资产负债表）的部分通常会有所启发。
  8. Dig further. On the price side, it may be possible to trace the overall price premium (or discount) to differences in particular product lines, in customers or geographic areas, or in list price versus discounts off list. On the cost side, it is often revealing to disaggregate the cost advantage (or disadvantage) into that part due to operating cost (income statement) and that part due to the utilization of capital (balance sheet).
    9.  
 

这些基本的经济关系是公司业绩和战略的基础。战略就是要努力塑造这些盈利能力的根本决定因素。

These basic economic relationships underlie company performance and strategy. Strategy is about trying to shape these underlying determinants of profitability.

 

战略意义：波特的美丽新世界

Strategic Implications: Porter’s Brave New World

 

毫不夸张地说，价值链——波特在《竞争优势》（1985 年）中首次深入阐述——已经改变了管理者看待世界的方式。想想价值链思维带来的巨大影响。

It is no exaggeration to say that the value chain, first laid out in depth by Porter in Competitive Advantage (1985), has changed the way managers see the world. Consider the enormous consequences of value chain thinking.

首先，你开始将每项活动视为不仅仅是成本，而是必须为成品或服务增加一定价值的步骤。随着时间的推移，这种观点彻底改变了组织定义其业务的方式。例如，35 年前，经纪业务是股票交易的方式，佣金很高。一刀切，至少适合那些有钱负担得起的人。每个人都理所当然地认为业务就是业务。

The first is that you begin to see each activity not just as a cost, but as a step that has to add some increment of value to the finished product or service. Over time, this perspective has revolutionized the way organizations define their business. Thirty-five years ago, for example, the brokerage business, with its hefty commissions, was how stocks were traded. One size fit all, or at least it fit those wealthy enough to afford it. Everyone took for granted that the business was what the business was.

 

您开始将每项活动不仅仅视为一项成本，而且视为必须为成品或服务增加一定价值的一个步骤。

You begin to see each activity not just as a cost, but as a step that has to add some increment of value to the finished product or service.

 

但是，如果你开始把经纪业务看作一系列创造价值的活动，会发生什么情况呢？你会发现，经纪业务背后是一套完全整合的活动，从研究和分析证券到执行交易，再到发送月度报表。所有这些活动的成本都隐藏在佣金价格中。查尔斯·施瓦布 (Charles Schwab) 围绕不同的价值链创建了以他的名字命名的公司，并创建了一个名为折扣经纪的新类别。并非所有客户都需要建议，那么他们为什么要为此付费呢？取消提供建议所需的所有活动，而是专注于执行交易，你就可以创造一种不同的价值：低成本交易，让更广泛的客户群能够拥有股票。仅仅25 年前，将价值链（公司内部开展的活动）与客户的价值定义相匹配是一种新的思维方式。今天，它已成为传统智慧。

But what happens when you start thinking about that business as a collection of value-creating activities? You see that behind that broker was a fully integrated set of activities that ranged all the way from doing research and analysis of securities to executing trades to sending out monthly statements. The costs of all those activities were buried in the price of the commission. Charles Schwab created the company that bears his name—and a new category known as discount brokerage—around a different value chain. Not all customers want advice, so why should they have to pay for it? Take away all the activities needed to give advice, focus instead on executing trades, and you can create a different kind of value: low-cost trades that make stock ownership accessible to a wider customer base. Matching the value chain—the activities performed inside the company—to the customer’s definition of value was a new way of thinking just twenty-five years ago. Today it has become conventional wisdom.

价值链思维的第二个主要结果是，它迫使你超越自己组织及其活动的界限，认识到你是涉及其他参与者的更大价值体系的一部分。例如，如果你想像麦当劳那样，围绕始终如一、完美的炸薯条建立快餐业务，你就不能向顾客找借口，因为你购买的土豆种植户缺乏适当的储存设施。顾客不在乎谁的错。他们只关心薯条的质量。因此，麦当劳必须采取具体行动，以确保它购买的所有土豆种植户都能以某种方式符合其标准。

A second major consequence of value chain thinking is that it forces you to look beyond the boundaries of your own organization and its activities and to see that you are part of a larger value system involving other players. For example, if you want to build a fast food business around consistent, perfect French fries, as McDonald’s did, you can’t make excuses to customers because the potato farmer you buy from lacks proper storage facilities. Customer don’t care who’s at fault. They care only about the quality of their fries. So, McDonald’s has to perform specific activities to make sure that, one way or another, all the potato growers from whom it buys can meet its standards.

价值体系中的每个人都应该了解自己在价值创造的更大过程中所扮演的角色，即使他们与最终用户之间只有一两步之遥。大多数葡萄酒爱好者都知道，打开一瓶好酒，倒给客人喝，却发现酒有木塞味——也就是酒的味道被一种称为“木塞污染”的问题破坏了，这是多么令人不快。到 20 世纪 90 年代，这个问题对葡萄酒制造商和销售商来说已经达到了临界点。他们希望木塞制造商能解决这个问题。你不会希望一个廉价的、像商品一样的部件破坏昂贵产品的价值。

And everyone in the value system had better understand the role they play in the larger process of value creation, even when they are removed by one or two steps from the ultimate end user. Most wine drinkers know how unpleasant it can be to uncork a nice bottle of wine, pour it for a guest, and then discover that it’s corky—that is, the taste has been ruined by a problem known as cork taint. By the 1990s, the problem reached a tipping point for wine makers and sellers. They wanted cork makers to fix it. You don’t want a cheap, commodity-like component to ruin the value of an expensive product.

软木大部分产自葡萄牙和其他地中海国家的树木，几十年来，软木几乎垄断了葡萄酒瓶塞的生产。因此，软木制造商反应迟缓也就不足为奇了。他们的技能在于从栓皮栎的外皮中采摘软木，而不会损坏树木。他们是手工工人——基本上是农民，而不是化学家。

Cork, most of which comes from trees in Portugal and other Mediterranean countries, has enjoyed a near monopoly on wine closures not just for decades, but for centuries. No surprise, then, that the cork makers were slow to respond. Their skill lay in harvesting cork from the outer bark of cork oaks without damaging the trees. They were hand workers—basically farmers, not chemists.

这为 Nomacorc 等塑料制造商创造了机会。Nomacorc 的价值链使其能够相对轻松地研究葡萄酒污染的化学成分并解决问题。虽然传统的软木塞制造商仍停留在较旧的思维模式（“我们从事软木塞业务”），但塑料制造商可以了解如何成为更大的价值创造过程的一部分。到 2009 年，Nomacorc 位于北卡罗来纳州的自动化工厂每月生产近 1.6 亿个塑料瓶塞，合成软木塞占据了 20% 的市场份额。

This created an opportunity for plastics makers such as Nomacorc to step into the breech. Nomacorc’s value chain made it relatively easy for it to undertake research into the chemistry of wine taint, and to solve the problem. While the traditional cork makers were stuck in an older mind-set (“we’re in the cork business”), the plastics makers could see how to become part of a larger value-creating process. By 2009, Nomacorc’s automated North Carolina factory was churning out close to 160 million plastic stoppers a month, and synthetic corks had captured 20 percent of the market.

价值链的相互依赖性具有重大意义。跨界管理，无论是公司与客户之间，还是公司与供应商或业务合作伙伴之间，对于战略而言，都与公司内部管理一样重要。使用波特的价值链结构就像第一次通过显微镜观察。突然间，管理者可以看到以前看不见的整个关系世界。

This interdependence of value chains has enormous implications. Managing across boundaries, whether these are between the company and its customers or the company and its suppliers or business partners, can be as important for strategy as managing within one’s own company. Using Porter’s value chain construct was like looking through a microscope for the first time. Suddenly managers could see a whole world of relationships that had previously been invisible to them.

价值链是分析公司相对成本和价值的重大突破。价值链使管理者关注产生成本并为买家创造价值的具体活动。尽管管理者经常谈论其组织的技能或能力如何创造价值，但活动才是关键。Nomacorc 显然拥有大多数管理者所称的化学“核心竞争力”。但它在葡萄酒市场的竞争成功源于决定将这些能力部署到增强葡萄酒瓶塞设计和制造的活动中。

The value chain was a major breakthrough for analyzing both a company’s relative cost and value. The value chain focuses managers on the specific activities that generate cost and create value for buyers. Although managers often talk about how their organization’s skills or capabilities create value, activities are where the rubber meets the road. Nomacorc clearly had what most managers would call a “core competence” in chemistry. But its competitive success in the wine market resulted from decisions to deploy those capabilities in activities that enhanced the design and manufacture of wine stoppers.

您能通过执行获得竞争优势吗？

Can You Execute Your Way to Competitive Advantage?

 

现在，我们对竞争优势有了完整的定义：由于所开展的活动不同而产生的相对价格或相对成本差异（见图3-6）。只要一家公司取得了竞争优势，就一定存在活动差异。但这些差异可以表现为两种不同的形式。一家公司可以更擅长执行相同的活动配置，也可以选择不同的活动配置。当然，现在您已经认识到第一种方法是竞争，力争做到最好。现在，我们可以更好地理解为什么这种方法不太可能产生竞争优势。

We now have a complete definition of competitive advantage: a difference in relative price or relative costs that arises because of differences in the activities being performed (see figure 3-6). Wherever a company has achieved competitive advantage, there must be differences in activities. But those differences can take two distinct forms. A company can be better at performing the same configuration of activities, or it can choose a different configuration of activities. By now, of course, you recognize that the first approach is competition to be the best. And by now, we are in a better position to understand why this approach is unlikely to produce a competitive advantage.

图 3.6

FIGURE 3.6

竞争优势源自公司价值链中的活动

Competitive advantage arises from the activities in a company’s value chain

 

波特使用“运营效率” (OE)这一短语来指公司比竞争对手更好地执行类似活动的能力。大多数经理使用“最佳实践”或“执行”这一术语。无论您喜欢哪个术语，我们谈论的是允许公司从其使用的资源中获得更多收益的多种实践。重要的是不要将 OE 与战略混淆。

Porter uses the phrase operational effectiveness (OE) to refer to a company’s ability to perform similar activities better than rivals. Most managers use the term “best practice” or “execution.” Whichever term you prefer, we are talking about a multitude of practices that allow a company to get more out of the resources it uses. The important thing is not to confuse OE with strategy.

首先，我们要认识到 OE 的差异是普遍存在的。有些公司在减少服务失误、保持货架库存、留住员工或消除浪费方面比其他公司做得更好。这些差异可能是竞争对手之间盈利能力差异的重要来源。

First, let’s recognize that differences in OE are pervasive. Some companies are better than others at reducing service errors, or keeping their shelves stocked, or retaining employees, or eliminating waste. Differences like these can be an important source of profitability differences among competitors.

但仅仅提高运营效率并不能带来强大的竞争优势，因为“最佳实践”优势很少是可持续的。一旦一家公司建立了新的最佳实践，其竞争对手往往会迅速效仿。这种不断模仿的过程有时被称为超级竞争。最佳实践在商业媒体和顾问的帮助下迅速传播，这些顾问围绕基准测试和质量/持续改进计划创造了一个行业。最通用的解决方案，即那些适用于多个公司和行业环境的解决方案，传播速度最快。（说出一个尚未被某种版本的全面质量管理所覆盖的行业。）

But simply improving operational effectiveness does not provide a robust competitive advantage because rarely are “best practice” advantages sustainable. Once a company establishes a new best practice, its rivals tend to copy it quickly. This treadmill of imitation is sometimes called hypercompetition. Best practices spread rapidly, aided by the business media and by consultants who have created an industry around benchmarking and quality/continuous improvement programs. The most generic solutions, those that apply in multiple company and industry settings, diffuse the fastest. (Name an industry that has yet to be visited by some version of Total Quality Management.)

此类项目非常引人注目。当管理人员在公司内部实施最新的最佳实践时，他们会因取得的切实改进而获得奖励。这很容易使他们忽视公司外部正在发生的事情的大局。在最佳实践方面展开竞争实际上提高了每个人的标准。虽然 OE 有绝对的改进，但没有人有相对的改进。最佳实践的必然传播意味着每个人都必须跑得更快才能保持原位。

Programs like these are compelling. Managers are rewarded for the tangible improvements they achieve when they implement the latest best practice inside their companies. That makes it all too easy to lose sight of the bigger picture of what’s happening outside their companies. Competing on best practices effectively raises the bar for everyone. While there is absolute improvement in OE, there is relative improvement for no one. The inevitable diffusion of best practices means that everyone has to run faster just to stay in place.

没有哪家公司能承受执行不力的后果。低效率甚至会压倒最独特、最有潜力的战略。但是，如果你赌自己可以通过执行与竞争对手相同的活动来获得竞争优势（价格或成本的可持续差异） ，那么你很可能会输掉这场赌注。在 OE 竞争中，没有人比日本人表现得更好，但正如波特的著作中详细记录的那样，OE 竞争甚至导致其中最好的公司长期盈利能力不佳。

No company can afford sloppy execution. Inefficiency can overwhelm even the most distinctive and potentially valuable strategies. But betting that you can achieve competitive advantage—a sustainable difference in price or cost—by performing the same activities as your rivals is a bet you will probably lose. No one has been better at OE competition than the Japanese, but, as Porter’s work documents in great detail, OE competition has led even the best of them to chronically poor profitability.

竞争对手竞争的核心在于削弱公司维持相对价格和相对成本差异的能力。竞争是实现最佳表现的最好方式。竞争会加速这一过程。在接下来的四章中，我们将看到围绕独特活动配置而构建的战略如何实现并保持竞争优势。战略是竞争对手竞争的解药。

Competitive rivalry, at its core, is a process working against the ability of a company to maintain differences in relative price and relative cost. Competition to be the best is the great leveler. It accelerates that process. In the next four chapters, we will see how strategy, built around a unique configuration of activities, works to achieve and sustain competitive advantage. Strategy is the antidote to competitive rivalry.

竞争优势的经济基础

The Economic Fundamentals of Competitive Advantage

 
 
  • 股东价值、销售回报率、增长和市场份额等流行指标对战略具有误导性。战略的目标是从您部署的资源中获得丰厚的回报，而这最好通过投资资本回报率来衡量。
  • Popular metrics such as shareholder value, return on sales, growth, and market share are misleading for strategy. The goal of strategy is to earn superior returns on the resources you deploy, and that is best measured by return on invested capital.
    •  
  • 竞争优势不在于击败竞争对手，而在于创造卓越的价值，以及在买方价值和成本之间比竞争对手拉开更大差距。
  • Competitive advantage is not about beating rivals; it’s about creating superior value and about driving a wider wedge than rivals between buyer value and cost.
    •  
  • 竞争优势意味着您将能够维持比行业竞争对手更高的相对价格或更低的相对成本，或两者兼而有之。如果您拥有竞争优势，它将体现在您的损益表中。
  • Competitive advantage means you will be able to sustain higher relative prices or lower relative costs, or both, than your rivals in an industry. If you have a competitive advantage, it will show up on your P&L.
    •  
  • 对于非营利组织来说，竞争优势意味着你花费的每一美元都能为社会创造更多的价值（相当于更高的价格），或者你使用更少的资源能创造同样的价值（相当于更低的成本）。
  • For nonprofits, competitive advantage means you will produce more value for society for every dollar spent (the analogue of higher price), or you will produce the same value using fewer resources (the equivalent of lower cost).
    •  
  • 相对价格和相对成本的差异最终可以归因于公司所从事的活动。
  • Differences in relative prices and relative costs can ultimately be traced to the activities that companies perform.
    •  
  • 企业的价值链是企业所有创造价值和产生成本的活动的集合。这些活动以及这些活动所包含的整个价值链是企业竞争优势的基本单位。
  • A company’s value chain is the collection of all its value-creating and cost-generating activities. The activities, and the overall value chain in which activities are embedded, are the basic units of competitive advantage.
    •  
 
 

第二部分

PART TWO

 

什么是策略？

What Is Strategy?

你可以把任何计划或方案称为战略，大多数人就是这么用这个词的。但好的战略，即能带来卓越经济绩效的战略，则是另一回事。简单概括一下，竞争优势意味着你为客户创造了价值，并且你能够为自己获取价值，因为你在行业中选择的定位有效地保护了你免受五种力量侵蚀利润的影响。我知道最后一句话有点拗口。更简单地说，你找到了一种通过与众不同来表现更好的方法。

YOU CAN CALL any plan or program a strategy, and that’s how most people use the word. But a good strategy, one that will result in superior economic performance, is something else. To recap quickly, competitive advantage means you have created value for customers and you are able to capture value for yourself because the positioning you have chosen in your industry effectively shelters you from the profit-eroding impact of the five forces. I realize that last sentence is a mouthful. More simply put, you have found a way to perform better by being different.

波特对战略的定义是规范性的，而非描述性的。也就是说，它区分了好的战略和坏的战略。他的重点是内容，而非过程。他的重点是你想要达到的目标，而非你实现目标的决策过程——而不是你如何或是否进行正式的战略规划，也不是你的战略是否可以用 50 个字或更少的字数概括。该领域的其他人一直在研究诸如此类的合理且重要的流程和人员问题，而波特则用一句老生常谈的战略短语来说，“坚守自己的本职工作”：创造和维持竞争优势的一般原则。

Porter’s definition of strategy is normative, not descriptive. That is, it distinguishes a good strategy from a bad one. His focus is on content, not process. His focus is on where you want to be, not on the decision-making process by which you got there—not how, or even whether, you do formal strategic planning, nor whether your strategy can be captured in fifty words or less. Others in the field have pursued legitimate and important process and people questions such as those, while Porter has, to use a well-worn strategy phrase, “stuck to his knitting”: the general principles of creating and sustaining competitive advantage.

在本章中，我们将介绍每个好的策略必须通过的五项测试：

In this section of chapters, we’ll cover five tests every good strategy must pass:

 
  • 独特的价值主张
  • A distinctive value proposition
    •  
  • 量身定制的价值链
  • A tailored value chain
    •  
  • 与竞争对手不同的权衡
  • Trade-offs different from rivals
    •  
  • 适合整个价值链
  • Fit across value chain
    •  
  • 持续性
  • Continuity over time
    •  
 

我们将看到每个因素如何促进战略及其长期可持续性。

We’ll see how each of these contributes to a strategy and its sustainability over time.

第四章

CHAPTER 4

 

创造价值：

Creating Value:

 

核心

The Core

 

战略的第一项测试是拥有独特的价值主张，这是非常直观的，许多管理者认为，如果他们能做到这一点，他们就拥有了战略。选择向客户提供的特定价值是竞争的核心。但回想一下竞争优势的定义：由于所执行活动的差异而产生的相对价格或相对成本差异。您的价值链必须专门定制才能实现您的价值主张。没有量身定制的价值链就能有效实现的价值主张不会产生可持续的竞争优势。量身定制的价值链是波特的第二项测试，它既不明显也不直观。

STRATEGY’S FIRST TEST, HAVING a distinctive value proposition, is so intuitive that many managers think they have a strategy if they can get this far. Choosing the particular kind of value you will offer your customers is the core of competing to be unique. But recall the definition of competitive advantage: a difference in relative price or relative costs that arises because of differences in the activities being performed. Your value chain must be specifically tailored to deliver your value proposition. A value proposition that can be effectively delivered without a tailored value chain will not produce a sustainable competitive advantage. The tailored value chain is Porter’s second test, and it is neither obvious nor intuitive.

本章将探讨战略的这两个核心要素如何相互关联，以及它们如何与行业结构和竞争优势相关联。战略意味着有意选择一组不同的活动来提供独特的价值组合。如果所有竞争对手都以相同的方式生产、分销、提供服务等等，那么按照波特的说法，他们是在争夺最佳地位，而不是在战略上竞争。

How these two core elements of strategy are linked to each other—and how they are linked to industry structure and competitive advantage—is the subject of this chapter. Strategy means deliberately choosing a different set of activities to deliver a unique mix of value. If all rivals produce the same way, distribute the same way, service the same way, and so on, they are, in Porter’s terms, competing to be the best, and not competing on strategy.

第一个测试：独特的价值主张

The First Test: A Distinctive Value Proposition

 

价值主张是面向客户、面向业务需求方的战略要素。价值主张反映了公司对将提供的特定价值的选择，无论这些选择是有意还是无意做出的。波特将价值主张定义为三个基本问题的答案（见图4-1）：

The value proposition is the element of strategy that looks outward at customers, at the demand side of the business. A value proposition reflects choices about the particular kind of value the company will offer, whether those choices have been made consciously or not. Porter defines the value proposition as the answer to three fundamental questions (see figure 4-1):

 
  • 您要为哪些客户提供服务？
  • Which customers are you going to serve?
    •  
  • 您要满足哪些需求？
  • Which needs are you going to meet?
    •  
  • 什么样的相对价格能够给客户提供可接受的价值，并为公司提供可接受的盈利能力？
  • What relative price will provide acceptable value for customers and acceptable profitability for the company?
    •  
 

图 4-1

FIGURE 4-1

价值主张回答了三个问题

The value proposition answers three questions

 
 

价值主张是战略的一个要素，它面向外部，着眼于客户，即业务的需求方。价值链则侧重于内部运营。战略从根本上讲是综合性的，将需求方和供应方结合在一起。

The value proposition is the element of strategy that looks outward at customers, at the demand side of the business. The value chain focuses internally on operations. Strategy is fundamentally integrative, bringing the demand and supply sides together.

 

这一定义反映了波特思想的演变，超越了他 1996 年发表在《哈佛商业评论》上的文章《什么是战略？》。他在文章中描述了定位的三个来源：多样性、需求和渠道。后续工作使他得出了本文讨论的更完整的表述，在过去十年中，他曾在无数次演讲和讲座中详细阐述这一表述。

This definition reflects the evolution of Porter’s thinking beyond his 1996 HBR article “What Is Strategy?” There he described three sources of positioning: variety, needs, and access. Subsequent work led him to the more complete formulation discussed here, one he has elaborated over the past decade in numerous speeches and lectures.

哪些客户？

Which Customers?

 

在一个行业中，通常存在不同的客户群体或客户细分。价值主张可以专门针对这些细分市场中的一个或多个。对于某些价值主张，选择客户是第一位的。这种选择直接导致三角形的另外两条腿：需求和相对价格。

Within an industry, there are usually distinct groups of customers, or customer segments. A value proposition can be aimed specifically at serving one or more of these segments. For some value propositions, choosing the customer comes first. That choice then leads directly to the other two legs of the triangle: needs and relative price.

客户细分通常是任何良好行业分析的一部分，选择您要服务的客户可能是您在五种力量中定位的重要基础。在以下示例中，请注意每个示例如何反映不同的细分基础：沃尔玛的细分基于地理位置，Progressive 的细分基于人口统计，而 Edward Jones 的细分基于心理统计。

Customer segmentation is typically part of any good industry analysis, and choosing the customer(s) you will serve can be an important anchor in your positioning vis-à-vis the five forces. In the examples that follow, note how each reflects a different basis for segmentation: Walmart’s segmentation was based on geography, Progressive’s on demographics, and Edward Jones’s on psychographics.

鉴于沃尔玛是全球最大的零售商，销售额超过 4000 亿美元，问沃尔玛服务于哪个细分市场似乎无关紧要。但与所有大公司一样，沃尔玛也是从小处做起，它必须选择一个起点。选择服务特定的客户群是沃尔玛起步的契机。20 世纪 60 年代，当沃尔玛开始运营时，折扣零售是一种新的颠覆性商业模式。早期的参与者专注于大城市和纽约等大都市区，而山姆·沃尔顿则做了一件独特的事情：他选择了人口在 5,000 到 25,000 之间的偏远乡村小镇。用沃尔顿自己的话来说，沃尔玛的“关键战略是将规模较大的商店开进其他人都忽视的小镇。”

Given that Walmart is the world’s largest retailer, with over $400 billion in sales, it may seem irrelevant to ask which segment Walmart serves. But like all large companies, Walmart started small, and it had to pick a place to begin. Choosing to serve a specific customer group gave Walmart its start. In the 1960s, when Walmart began operations, discount retailing was a new, disruptive business model. While the early players focused on big cities and metropolitan areas like New York, Sam Walton did something unique: he chose isolated rural towns with populations between 5,000 and 25,000. Walmart’s “key strategy,” in Walton’s own words, “was to put good-sized stores into little one-horse towns which everybody else was ignoring.”

就五种力量而言，这种顾客选择使沃尔玛避免了与其他折扣店的直接竞争。尽管人们倾向于认为沃尔玛是一个激烈的竞争对手，但沃尔玛一开始就完全避免了正面竞争。这样做让它有多年的喘息空间来发展和扩大其作为日常低价供应商的定位。

In terms of the five forces, this choice of customers insulated Walmart from direct rivalry with other discounters. Although people tend to think of Walmart as a fierce competitor, Walmart started out by completely avoiding head-to-head competition. Doing so gave it many years of breathing room to develop and extend its positioning as a provider of everyday low prices.

总部位于俄亥俄州的汽车保险公司 Progressive 也针对行业内普遍回避的客户制定了一项战略。大约 30 年来，Progressive 一直选择为行业内所谓的“非标准”司机提供服务，这些人更有可能发生事故并提出保险索赔（例如摩托车车主或有酒后驾驶记录的驾驶员），从而蓬勃发展。由于没有其他选择，非标准买家通常几乎没有议价能力。

Progressive, the Ohio-based auto insurer, also built a strategy around a customer its industry was largely avoiding. For about three decades, Progressive thrived by choosing to serve what the industry called “nonstandard” drivers, those more likely to be involved in accidents and to file insurance claims (motorcycle owners, for example, or motorists with drunk-driving records). With few alternatives, nonstandard buyers typically had little bargaining power.

最后，如果你看看财富管理业务，你会发现几乎每个人都在追逐同一个人口群体：高净值个人。但爱德华琼斯 (Edward Jones) 除外，它是美国最成功的经纪公司之一。三十年来，它一直专注于客户，而这些客户的定义不是他们有多少钱，而是他们对投资的态度。琼斯服务于保守的投资者，他们将财务决策委托给值得信赖的顾问。从五种力量来看，这个客户群体对价格的敏感度较低，忠诚度更高。

Finally, if you look at the wealth management business, you’ll find just about everyone chasing the same demographic segment: the high-net-worth individual. Not Edward Jones, one of the consistently most successful U.S. brokerage firms. For thirty years, it has focused on customers defined not by how much money they have, but on their attitude toward investing. Jones serves conservative investors who delegate financial decisions to a trusted advisor. In terms of the five forces, this customer segment has been less price sensitive and more loyal.

通常情况下，这些价值主张都针对行业忽视或回避的客户群体。但这并不是必需的。例如，在保险业，USAA 一直表现优异，其价值主张针对低风险客户。以下是必需的：找到一种独特的方式，为您选择的细分市场提供盈利服务。

As often happens, each of these value propositions targeted a customer group overlooked or avoided by the industry. That’s not essential, however. In insurance, for example, USAA has been a stellar performer with a value proposition aimed at low-risk customers. Here’s what is essential: finding a unique way to serve your chosen segment profitably.

哪些需求？

Which Needs?

 

在许多情况下，选择公司要满足的需求是导致三角形另外两条边的主要决定。在这里，战略建立在满足特定需求或需求子集的独特能力之上。这种能力通常来自产品或服务的特定功能。通常，基于需求的价值主张会吸引可能不符合传统细分标准的客户组合。公司的客户不是属于明确的人口统计类别，而是根据他们在特定时间共有的共同需求或需求集来定义。

In many cases, choosing the need the company will serve is the primary decision that leads to the other two legs of the triangle. Here, strategy is built on a unique ability to meet a particular need or a subset of needs. Often that ability arises from the specific features of a product or service. Typically, value propositions based on needs appeal to a mix of customers who might defy traditional segmentation. Instead of belonging to a clear demographic category, the company’s customers will be defined by the common need or set of needs they share at a given time.

 

通常情况下，基于需求的价值主张会吸引那些可能不符合传统人口统计细分的各类客户。

Typically, value propositions based on needs appeal to a mix of customers who might defy traditional demographic segmentation.

 

Enterprise Rent-A-Car 是北美汽车租赁市场的领导者，其规模超过了曾经占据主导地位的 Hertz 和 Avis。Enterprise 的盈利能力也大幅提升。它是业内唯一一家持续盈利能力超群的大型公司，因为数十年来它一直奉行独特的战略。

Enterprise Rent-A-Car is the market leader in car rental services in North America, where it is bigger than the once-dominant players, Hertz and Avis. Enterprise has also been dramatically more profitable. It is the only major company in the industry that has enjoyed sustained superior profitability, because for decades it pursued a distinctive strategy.

Enterprise 的价值主张基于一个简单的观点：租车在不同时间满足不同的需求。赫兹及其业内追随者围绕旅行者、出差或度假的人建立了业务。Enterprise 认识到，大约 40% 到 45% 的租车发生在租车人的家乡。例如，如果您的汽车被盗或在事故中受损，您将需要租车。在这种情况下，您的保险公司可能会承担费用，通常会在合同中限制其支付的价格。Enterprise 约三分之一的收入来自保险公司。其他场合也会促使租车人选择家乡租车 — 例如，当汽车出现机械故障或孩子放学回家度假时。在所有这些用途中，家乡租车人往往比商务或度假旅行者对价格更敏感。

The Enterprise value proposition is based on a simple insight: renting a car meets different needs at different times. Hertz and its followers in the industry built their business around travelers, people away from home on business or on vacation. Enterprise recognized that a sizeable minority of rentals, roughly 40 to 45 percent, occur in the renter’s home city. If your car is stolen, for example, or damaged in an accident, you’ll need a rental. In such cases, your insurance company might cover the cost, usually with contractual limits on the price it will pay. About a third of Enterprise’s revenues come from insurers. Other occasions prompt home-city rentals as well—for example, when a car has a mechanical failure or when a child is home from school on vacation. In all of these uses, home-city car renters tend to be more price sensitive than business or vacation travelers.

Enterprise 制定了独特的价值主张来满足这些需求：价格合理、方便、本地租车。与 Hertz 和 Avis 相比，Enterprise 选择以不同的相对价格满足不同的需求。这并不是说 Enterprise 是最好的汽车租赁公司。它所服务的市场也并非天生就更好。但从它所服务的特定需求开始，Enterprise 对价值主张三角做出了不同的选择。Enterprise 的客户群将打破传统的按人口统计特征进行市场细分的做法。

Enterprise crafted a unique value proposition to meet these needs: reasonably priced, convenient, home-city rentals. Compared with Hertz and Avis, Enterprise has chosen to serve a different need at a different relative price. It is not that Enterprise is the best car rental company. Nor is the market it serves inherently better. But starting with the specific need it serves, Enterprise has made a different choice about the value proposition triangle. Enterprise’s customer base would confound traditional market segmentation by demographic characteristics.

Zipcar 成立于 2000 年，总部位于马萨诸塞州剑桥，在城市租车领域走的是一条与众不同的路。它的价值主张针对的是另一类具有不同需求的客户（见图4-2）。Zipsters 是该公司会员的称呼，他们往往选择不拥有汽车，但偶尔需要用车。Zipcar 允许他们短至一小时的租车时间。

Zipcar, started in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in 2000, is pursuing a different path to uniqueness in home-city car rentals. Its value proposition targets yet another kind of customer with a different kind of need (see figure 4-2). Zipsters, as the company’s members are called, are often people who choose not to own a car, but who occasionally need to use one. Zipcar allows them to rent a car for time periods as short as an hour.

图 4-2

FIGURE 4-2

定位地图

Positioning maps

 

Zipcar 提供有趣而复杂的价值组合：取车和还车极其方便；租赁期限极其灵活；包括保险和汽油在内的明确全包价格；以及与这个快速增长的品牌相关的无形“酷”因素。我应该补充一点，因为这家公司处于早期发展阶段，它无疑将继续测试其价值主张的界限，并在学习过程中对其进行调整。

Zipcar offers an interesting and complex mix of value: extreme convenience in vehicle pickup and drop-off; extreme flexibility in the rental period; clear, all-inclusive pricing that includes insurance and gas; and the intangible “cool” factor associated with this fast-growing brand. I should add that because this company is an early work-in-progress, it will undoubtedly continue to test the boundaries of its value proposition and to make adjustments to it as it learns.

相对价格是多少？

What Relative Price?

 

对于某些价值主张，相对价格是三角形的主要支柱。有些价值主张针对的是行业中其他产品服务过度（因此价格过高）的客户。公司可以通过消除不必要的成本并满足“刚好足够”的需求来赢得这些客户。在产品层面，想想一部基本款手机和一部更昂贵、功能更丰富的智能手机之间的区别。当客户服务过度时，较低的相对价格往往是三角形的主要支柱。

For some value propositions, relative price is a primary leg of the triangle. Some value propositions target customers who are overserved (and hence overpriced) by other offerings in the industry. A company can win these customers by eliminating unnecessary costs and meeting “just enough” of their needs. At the product level, think about the difference between a bare-bones cell phone and a more expensive, feature-laden smartphone. Where customers are overserved, the lower relative price is often the dominant leg of the triangle.

相反，一些价值主张针对的是行业中其他产品服务不足（因此价格偏低）的客户。例如，选择 NetJets 而不是乘坐商业航班头等舱的客户希望获得更好的服务，并愿意为此支付高额费用。同样，丹麦的 Bang & Olufsen (B&O) 为其客户提供的不仅仅是其他高端音响设备制造商提供的出色音质。B&O 的客户希望产品外观和音质一样好，他们愿意为精美的设计支付更多费用。在像 B&O 这样的价值主张中，未满足的需求通常是三角形的主导，而较高的相对价格支持了公司为满足需求而必须承担的额外成本。

Conversely, some value propositions target customers who are underserved (and hence underpriced) by other offerings in the industry. Customers who choose NetJets instead of flying first class on a commercial airline, for example, want an enhanced service and are willing to pay a steep premium for it. Similarly, Denmark’s Bang & Olufsen (B&O) gives its customers something more than the spectacular sound quality offered by other high-end audio equipment makers. B&O’s customers want products that look as good as they sound, and they are willing to pay more for beautiful design. In value propositions like B&O’s, the unmet need is typically the dominant leg of the triangle, while the higher relative price supports the extra costs the company has to incur to meet it.

当需求被过度满足时：西南航空。根据公司传说，西南航空是这样诞生的。早在 20 世纪 60 年代末，“有几个人说，‘有个主意。我们为什么不创办一家只收取几块钱、每天有很多航班的航空公司，而不是像其他人那样——收取很多钱，每天只有几个航班？’”简而言之，这就是西南航空的价值主张：非常低的价格加上非常便捷的服务。

When Needs Are Overserved: Southwest. According to company legend, here’s how Southwest Airlines was born. Back in the late 1960s, “a couple of guys said, ‘Here’s an idea. Why don’t we start an airline that charges just a few bucks and has lots of flights every day instead of what the other guys are doing—charging a lot of bucks and having just a few flights each day?’” That, in a nutshell, is Southwest Airlines’ value proposition: very low prices coupled with very convenient service.

西南航空是世界上最成功、也是被效仿最多的航空公司，它以极低的价格满足了“刚好够用”的客户需求，从而蓬勃发展。西南航空从 1971 年成立之初只飞往德克萨斯州三个城市的简陋航班，发展成为规模和盈利能力均居世界领先地位的航空公司之一。它之所以能做到这一点，是因为它的价值主张在三十年间与其他航空公司截然不同。

Southwest Airlines, the most successful—and the most emulated—airline in the world, has thrived by meeting “just enough” of its customers’ needs at dramatically lower prices. From its humble beginnings flying only to three cities in Texas in 1971, Southwest has grown to be one of the world’s leading airlines, both in size and in profitability. It has done so with a value proposition that for three decades was radically different from other airlines.

西南航空不像其他航空公司那样承诺带你去任何你想去的地方。它也没有提供曾经是行业标准的基本服务：餐食、指定座位、行李转运。全方位服务航空公司（这个术语可能不再准确描述传统航空公司，因为它们的成本和价格更高）过度满足了乘坐西南航空短途点对点航线的大量旅客的需求。

Southwest didn’t promise to get you anywhere you wanted to go, as other airlines did. Nor did it offer the basic amenities that were once standard industry fare: meals, assigned seats, baggage transfers. Full-service airlines (perhaps a term that no longer accurately describes the legacy carriers, with their higher costs and prices) overserved the needs of a large number of travelers flying Southwest’s shorter point-to-point routes.

西南航空的价值主张使其在五种力量中占据了独特的地位。众所周知，航空业极其不友好。

Southwest’s value proposition put it in a unique position vis-à-vis the five forces. As most know, the airline industry is brutally inhospitable.

 
  • 供应商，特别是工会以及飞机制造商，都很强大。
  • Suppliers, especially the labor unions but also plane makers, are powerful.
    •  
  • 顾客之所以强大，是因为他们对价格敏感，而且转换成本低。
  • Customers are powerful because they are price sensitive and have low switching costs.
    •  
  • 由于固定成本高昂，竞争对手通过价格竞争来填补席位。
  • Rivals, dealing with high fixed costs, compete on price to fill seats.
    •  
  • 新进入者是一个持续的威胁，因为进入门槛比你想象的要低。你可以用几架租赁的飞机创办一家航空公司。
  • New entrants are a constant threat, because entry barriers are lower than you might think. You can start an airline with a couple of leased planes.
    •  
  • 替代品使价格降低。顾客可以选择其他交通方式，尤其是短途旅行。
  • Substitutes keep prices down. Customers can choose other forms of transportation, especially on shorter trips.
    •  
 

西南航空的相对成本较低，这让它避开了行业自毁式的价格竞争。此外，它的价值主张让它在面对最后一种力量——替代时拥有了真正独特的定位。它的低票价让飞行成为对价格敏感的旅行者（习惯开车或坐公交车）的有吸引力的选择。早年，一位股东问首席执行官赫伯·凯莱赫，西南航空是否能将票价提高几美元，因为其达拉斯-圣安东尼奥航线的票价为 15 美元，比布兰尼夫的 62 美元低得多。凯莱赫说不，我们真正的竞争对手是地面交通，而不是其他航空公司。

Southwest’s low relative costs provided shelter from the industry’s self-destructive price competition. Moreover, its value proposition gave it a truly unique positioning vis-à-vis that last force, substitution. Its low fares made flying an attractive alternative for price-sensitive travelers accustomed to driving or taking a bus. In the early years, a shareholder asked CEO Herb Kelleher if Southwest couldn’t raise its prices by just a few dollars since its $15 price on the Dallas–San Antonio route was so much lower than Braniff’s $62 fare. Kelleher said no, our real competition is ground transportation, not other airlines.

西南航空首次在达拉斯、休斯顿和圣安东尼奥这三个原有城市之外扩张。它选择了德克萨斯州的哈林根，这个位于里奥格兰德河谷的小镇可能很少有人听说过。西南航空推出服务的前一年，有 123,000 名乘客从西南航空的基地城市飞往山谷。西南航空开始飞往哈林根的一年内，乘客数量跃升至 325,000 人次。

Consider Southwest’s first expansion beyond its original three cities, Dallas, Houston, and San Antonio. It chose Harlingen, Texas, a town in the Rio Grande Valley probably few people have ever heard of. The year before Southwest launched its service, 123,000 passengers flew from Southwest’s base cities to the Valley. Within a year after Southwest began flying to Harlingen, passenger volume jumped to 325,000.

价格并不是全部原因。西南航空也更加方便。首先，它的航班频繁，让乘客可以随时出行。其次，它的航班准时到达，乘客不必在售票柜台排长队等待。第三，西南航空战略的核心二级机场更靠近市中心，缩短了旅客的总旅行时间。这些便利因素对商务旅客来说很有吸引力。

And price isn’t the whole story. Southwest was also more convenient. First, its frequent departures allowed customers to travel when they wanted. Second, its flights arrived on time and customers didn’t have to wait in slow lines at the ticket counter. Third, the secondary airports that became central to Southwest’s strategy were closer to downtown, cutting a traveler’s total trip time. These convenience factors were a draw for business travelers.

西南航空并没有在第一天就弄清楚其价值主张的每一个要素。很少有公司能做到这一点。西南航空是在实践中学习的。下面是一个典型的例子，说明西南航空是如何在实践中学习的。1971 年，休斯顿的一架飞机需要在周末飞往达拉斯进行例行维护。当时的首席执行官拉马尔·缪斯不想让飞机空着，他认为有收入总比没有收入好。他以 10 美元的价格出售周五晚上航班的座位，比该航线标准票价 20 美元低了一半。这趟航班的座位已售罄，为这家陷入困境的初创公司带来了一些额外的现金。

Southwest didn’t figure out every element of its value proposition on Day One. Companies rarely do. It learned by doing. Here’s a classic example of how that happens in practice. In 1971, one of the planes in Houston needed to go to Dallas for routine maintenance over the weekend. Then-CEO Lamar Muse didn’t want to fly the plane empty, figuring that some revenue was better than none. He offered seats on the Friday-night flight for $10, half off the standard $20 fare on that route. The flight sold out, providing some extra cash for the struggling start-up.

比现金更棒的是西南航空对客户做出的颠覆性洞察。有些人显然对价格更敏感，而对时间不那么敏感。缪斯立即采取行动。他将高峰票价提高到 26 美元，将非高峰票价降至 13 美元。多级定价现在是行业标准做法，但在当时，这是一项重大创新。它使西南航空能够进一步细分客户并提高飞机客座率。较低的非高峰票价对休闲旅客更有吸引力，因为他们对价格更敏感，而且出行时间比商务旅客更灵活。

Even better than the cash was the game-changing insight about Southwest’s customers. Some were clearly more price sensitive, and less time sensitive, than others. Muse acted immediately. He raised the peak fare to $26 and dropped the off-peak fare to $13. Multiple-tier pricing is now standard industry practice, but at the time, it was a major innovation. It allowed Southwest to further segment its customers and to fill its planes. Lower off-peak fares appeal to leisure travelers who are more price sensitive and have greater flexibility about when they travel than do business passengers.

因此，西南航空的价值主张跨越了传统的客户细分市场，在特定场合吸引各种客户：商务旅客、家庭和学生。西南航空不会一直满足目标客户的所有需求，而是满足许多客户至少在某些时候会有的一种需求。西南航空创造了一种独特的价值，几十年来，这种价值使其有别于其他航空公司。

Thus Southwest’s value proposition cut across traditional customer segments, appealing, on given occasions, to a variety of customers: business travelers, families, and students. Instead of meeting all of the needs of a target customer all of the time, Southwest meets one type of need that many customers have at least some of the time. Southwest created a distinct kind of value that, for many decades, distinguished it from other airlines.

尽管西南航空被广泛模仿，但说西南航空找到了行业“最佳”价值主张是错误的。它只是在以特定的相对价格满足特定需求方面才是“最佳”的。

Although Southwest has been widely imitated, it would be a mistake to say that Southwest has found the “best” value proposition for the industry. It is only “best” at meeting a particular kind of need at a particular relative price.

当需求得不到满足时：阿拉文眼科医院。印度阿拉文眼科医院成立于 1976 年，创始人是理想主义的退役军医 Govindappa Venkataswamy，人称 V 医生。V 医生不需要详细的市场细分图就能确定大量需求严重得不到满足的人群。数百万印度人因负担不起白内障手术费用而患上可预防的失明。阿拉文眼科医院最初只有 11 张床位和 3 名医生，如今已成为世界上最大的眼科护理提供商，每年进行约 30 万次手术，其中至少三分之二是免费的。

When Needs Are Underserved: Aravind Eye Hospital. India’s Aravind Eye Hospital was founded in 1976 by an idealistic retired army surgeon, Govindappa Venkataswamy, known as Dr. V. Dr. V. didn’t need a detailed market segmentation map to identify a large population with a dramatically underserved need. Millions of Indians suffer from preventable blindness because they can’t afford cataract surgery. Starting with just eleven beds and three doctors, Aravind has become the world’s largest provider of eye care in the world, performing about 300,000 surgeries a year, at least two-thirds of them for free.

Aravind 的价值主张非同寻常。更正一下：它有两个价值主张。一个是针对那些想要用钱买到最好的眼科护理的富裕客户。这些客户希望在最先进的设施中接受最先进的医生的诊治，他们愿意为这种先进的医疗服务支付市场价格。这是一个价值主张。

Aravind has an extraordinary value proposition. Correction: it has two value propositions. One is aimed at affluent customers who want the best eye care money can buy. These customers want to be seen by state-of-the-art doctors in state-of-the-art facilities, and they are willing to pay the going market rate for such advanced medical care. That’s one value proposition.

第二种是针对那些付不起钱，否则会失明的人。阿拉文德医院为他们提供了视力，以及随之而来的独立。医疗服务与付费患者提供的服务相同——同样的医生，同样的手术室。酒店功能（食宿）大大简化。但价格进一步降低，降至零。

The second is for those who can’t afford to pay and who would otherwise become blind. Aravind offers them sight, and the independence that goes with it. The medical care is identical to that provided to the paying patients—same doctors, same operating rooms. The hotel function (room and board) is vastly stripped down. But the price is stripped down even further, all the way to zero.

Aravind 以不同的价格满足了两个不同客户群体的至关重要的需求，从而蓬勃发展。最引人注目的是，Aravind 在财务上实现了自给自足——它既不依赖政府资金，也不依赖慈善捐款，尽管它的成功越来越吸引后者。相反，它采取了一项已被证明可持续 30 多年的战略。

Aravind has thrived by meeting vitally important needs for two distinct customer segments, at different price points. What’s most remarkable is that Aravind is financially self-sustaining—it depends neither on government money nor on charitable donations, although its success has increasingly attracted the latter. Instead it has a strategy that has proven to be sustainable for over three decades.

 

战略的第一个测试就是你的价值主张是否与竞争对手不同。如果你试图服务相同的客户、满足相同的需求并以相同的相对价格出售产品，那么根据波特的定义，你没有战略。

The first test of a strategy is whether your value proposition is different from your rivals. If you are trying to serve the same customers and meet the same needs and sell at the same relative price, then by Porter’s definition, you don’t have a strategy.

 

在大多数企业中，价值主张三角形可能有许多不同的配置。一些公司服务于市场上的几乎所有客户，但只满足特定需求或需求群。其他公司服务于更集中的客户群，但旨在满足更多客户的需求。一些公司以高价提供更高的价值。其他公司由于效率高，提供相对较低的价格。

In most businesses, there are many different possible configurations of the value proposition triangle. Some companies serve virtually all customers in the market but only meet a specific need or cluster of needs. Other companies serve a more focused customer base but aim to meet more of those customers’ needs. Some companies deliver higher value at a premium price. Others, enabled by their efficiency, offer a low relative price.

战略的第一个测试就是看你的价值主张是否与竞争对手不同。如果你试图服务相同的客户、满足相同的需求并以相同的相对价格出售产品，那么根据波特的定义，你没有战略。你只是在竞争，力争做到最好。

The first test of a strategy is whether your value proposition is different from your rivals. If you are trying to serve the same customers and meet the same needs and sell at the same relative price, then by Porter’s definition, you don’t have a strategy. You’re competing to be the best.

第二项测试：量身定制的价值链

The Second Test: A Tailored Value Chain

 

如果你想描述一种战略，价值主张自然是开始的地方。从满足客户需求的利益组合角度考虑战略是直觉的。但战略的第二个测试经常被忽视，因为它根本不直观。波特解释说，独特的价值主张不会转化为有意义的战略，除非实现它的最佳活动与竞争对手所进行的活动不同。他的逻辑简单而令人信服：“如果不是这样，每个竞争对手都可以满足相同的需求，定位就没有任何独特或有价值的东西。”

If you’re trying to describe a strategy, the value proposition is a natural place to begin. It’s intuitive to think of strategy in terms of the mix of benefits aimed at meeting customers’ needs. But the second test of strategy is often overlooked because it is not intuitive at all. A distinctive value proposition, Porter explains, will not translate into a meaningful strategy unless the best set of activities to deliver it is different from the activities performed by rivals. His logic is simple and compelling: “If that were not the case, every competitor could meet those same needs, and there would be nothing unique or valuable about the positioning.”

洞察客户需求很重要，但还不够。战略和竞争优势的本质在于活动，在于选择以不同的方式开展活动或开展与竞争对手不同的活动。我们刚刚描述的每家公司都做到了这一点，根据其价值主张定制其价值链。

Insight into customers’ needs is important, but it’s not enough. The essence of strategy and competitive advantage lies in the activities, in choosing to perform activities differently or to perform different activities from those of rivals. Each of the companies we’ve just described has done just that, tailoring their value chains to their value propositions.

沃尔玛、Progressive 和 Edward Jones

Walmart, Progressive, and Edward Jones

 

让我们回到这三家公司，它们的价值主张都是围绕服务于不同的客户而建立的。我们将通过简单地强调反映每家公司所选细分市场的主要活动选择，以及这些选择与服务于不同客户的竞争对手的选择有何不同，来开始我们对定制价值链的观察。

Let’s return to the trio of companies whose value propositions were built around serving a distinct customer. We’ll begin our look at tailored value chains by simply highlighting the major activity choices that reflect each company’s chosen segment, and how those choices are different from those made by rivals who are serving different customers.

首先是沃尔玛。其他折扣店选择在大都市地区开设门店，而沃尔玛则投资于小城镇，那里距离最近的城市可能要开车四小时。沃尔顿对这一领域了如指掌。他正确地打赌，如果他的商店能够达到或超过这些城市的价格，“人们就会在家购物。”此外，沃尔玛的许多市场规模太小，无法支持一家以上的大型零售商。这是一个强大的进入壁垒。作为第一个进入者，沃尔顿能够抢占竞争对手的先机，阻止他们进入沃尔玛的地盘，从而使公司有时间磨练其持久的竞争优势：在全国乃至更广阔的市场提供每日低价的能力。

First, Walmart. While other discounters chose to put stores in large metropolitan areas, Walmart invested in small-town locations, where the nearest city was probably a four-hour drive away. Walton knew this terrain well. He rightly bet that if his stores could match or beat those city prices, “people would shop at home.” Moreover, many of Walmart’s markets were too small to support more than one large retailer. This was a powerful barrier to entry. By being first, Walton was able to preempt competitors and discourage them from entering Walmart’s territory, allowing the company time to hone the enduring sources of its competitive advantage: its ability to provide everyday low prices in markets all across the country and beyond.

Progressive 的目标客户提出了一个特殊的挑战。你如何将一个糟糕的司机变成一个盈利客户？Progressive 需要一条不同于行业标准的价值链。首先，Progressive 以不同的方式处理风险评估，建立一个庞大的数据库，其中包含更精细的指标，可以更好地预测事故发生的可能性。它利用这些数据来发现其他保险公司认为是糟糕司机的群体中的良好风险。例如，在被指控饮酒的司机中，有孩子的司机再次犯罪的可能性最小；在摩托车手中，40 岁以上的哈雷车主骑车的频率较低。Progressive 使用此类信息来制定价格，以便即使是最差的客户也能获利。因此，Progressive 的竞争优势始于相对价格（针对可比风险）。

Progressive’s target customer posed a special challenge. How do you turn a bad driver into a profitable customer? Progressive needed a different value chain from the industry’s standard one. First, Progressive tackled risk assessment in a different way, building a massive database with more granular indicators that better predicted the probability of accidents. It used this data to spot the good risks in pools that looked like bad drivers to other insurers. For example, among drivers cited for drinking, those with children were least likely to reoffend; among motorcyclists, Harley owners aged forty-plus were likely to ride their bikes less often. Progressive used information like this to set prices so that even the worst customers could be profitable. Progressive’s competitive advantage, then, started with relative price (for comparable risks).

其次，由于事故随时可能发生，Progressive 专注于在事故发生后将成本降至最低。例如，理赔解决得越快，Progressive 就能节省越多的钱。（时间越短，诉讼就越少。）Progressive 的价值链通过多种方式实现了这一点。最引人注目的是，配备公司货车和笔记本电脑的理赔员可以直接前往事故现场并当场开具支票。这在业内并不常见。因此，Progressive 的竞争优势还在于相对成本较低。

Second, since accidents were likely, Progressive focused on minimizing their cost once they occurred. The faster claims were settled, for example, the more money Progressive could save. (Less time meant fewer lawsuits.) Progressive’s value chain accomplished this in a number of ways. Most dramatically, an adjuster equipped with a company van and a laptop could go directly to the accident scene and issue a check on the spot. This was not common practice in the industry. Progressive’s competitive advantage, then, also had a component of lower relative cost.

与 Progressive 一样，Edward Jones 也根据其选定的客户群体量身定制了其价值链，这些客户群体是保守的个人投资者，他们希望有一位值得信赖的顾问为他们做出财务决策。信任是通过个人的面对面关系建立起来的。为此，Jones 投资了许多位置便利的办事处——小城镇、郊区和商业街。每个办事处只有一名财务顾问，这是业内独一无二的模式。Jones 更喜欢从行业外招聘，寻找既有社区精神又有创业精神的顾问。它投入巨资培训新员工，让他们了解其保守的产品线（主要是蓝筹投资）和买入并持有的理念。

Like Progressive, Edward Jones also tailored its value chain to its chosen customer segment, conservative individual investors who wanted a trusted advisor to make financial decisions for them. Trust is built through personal, face-to-face relationships. To that end, Jones invests in conveniently located offices, and lots of them—in small towns, suburbs, and strip malls. Each office has just one financial advisor, a model unique in the industry. Jones prefers to hire from outside the industry, looking for advisors with both community and entrepreneurial spirit. It spends heavily on training new hires in its conservative product line (mostly blue-chip investments) and its buy-and-hold philosophy.

Jones 为这些为其选定客户量身定制的活动付出了代价。它放弃了更频繁交易或利润更高的奇异投资带来的收入。与其他经纪公司相比，它的培训和占用成本较高。但这些活动为 Jones 的选定客户创造了价值，他们愿意为 Jones 值得信赖的个人服务支付高额溢价（每笔交易 100 美元，而低价经纪商只需 8 美元）。

Jones pays a price for these activities tailored to its chosen customer. It foregoes revenue from more frequent trading or more exotic investments with higher margins. Its training and its occupancy costs are high relative to other brokerage firms. But these activities create value for Jones’s chosen customers, who are willing to pay a large premium ($100 per trade versus $8 for low-priced brokers) for Jones’s trusted personal touch.

Aravind 的价值链

Aravind’s Value Chain

 

Aravind 最初的灵感来自于麦当劳。V 博士希望白内障手术的效率和连续性能够像麦当劳生产汉堡一样高。他设计了一个系统来实现这一点。

The original inspiration for Aravind came from, of all places, McDonald’s. Dr. V. wanted to produce cataract surgeries as efficiently and as consistently as McDonald’s produced hamburgers. He designed a system that does just that.

本质上，当外科医生为一名患者做手术时，下一名患者已经在他身后的手术台上准备就绪。当一个手术结束时，外科医生只需转身开始下一个手术。熟练的外科医生不会浪费一分钟宝贵的时间。手术室里的每个人，包括外科医生，都接受过遵循标准化程序的培训。流程中的每一步都经过精心整合，以产生一个高效的整体。

Essentially, while a surgeon is operating on one patient, the next patient is already prepped on a table behind him. When one operation ends, the surgeon simply turns around and starts the next one. Not a minute of the skilled surgeon’s valuable time is lost. Everyone in the operating room, including the surgeon, is trained to follow a standardized procedure. Every step in the process is carefully integrated to produce an efficient whole.

结果不言而喻：2009-2010 年，阿拉文德医院仅雇用了印度 1% 的眼科人力，却完成了印度约 5% 的眼科手术。这一成就堪比亨利·福特的 T 型车装配线，该装配线使福特工人的生产力比汽车行业平均水平高出五倍。阿拉文德医院通过应用福特用于让大众买得起汽车的核心设计元素，让白内障手术变得经济实惠：活动标准化、劳动力和设备专业化以及永不停歇的高产量生产线。

The results speak for themselves: Aravind, in 2009–2010, performed about 5 percent of all eye surgeries in India, employing only 1 percent of the nation’s ophthalmic manpower. The achievement mirrors that of Henry Ford’s assembly line for the Model T, which made Ford workers five times more productive than the auto industry average. Aravind has made cataract surgery affordable by applying the core design elements that Ford used to make cars affordable for the masses: standardization of activities, specialization of labor and equipment, and a high-volume production line that never stops.

运营模式推动了 Aravind 创造价值的能力，但这并不是全部。毕竟，在一个低成本都太贵的市场中，低成本生产商有什么好处呢？V 博士的解决方案是：向付费客户收取市场价格。由于 Aravind 的成本比其他供应商低得多，因此每位付费客户都可以补贴两人的免费护理。粗略地说，这就是 Aravind 竞争优势的计算方法。

The operating model drives Aravind’s ability to create value, but it’s not the whole story. After all, what good is being a low-cost producer in a market where even low cost is too expensive? Dr. V.’s solution: charge paying customers market rates. Because Aravind’s costs are so much lower than other providers, each paying customer subsidizes free care for two. That, very roughly speaking, is the arithmetic of Aravind’s competitive advantage.

Aravind 的价值链选择支持其吸引付费客户的能力，这些客户被安置在单独的翼楼或建筑中，提供各种现代化的舒适设施。然而，真正的吸引力在于医疗服务的质量。Aravind 的专业水平处于领先地位。它建立了一流的教学和研究机构，与世界各地领先的眼科中心建立了合作关系。它的医生都是世界一流的。

Aravind’s value chain choices support its ability to attract paying customers, who are housed in a separate wing or building that offers every modern comfort. The real draw, however, is the quality of the medical care. Aravind is professionally state of the art. It has developed a premier teaching and research institute, with affiliations with leading eye centers around the world. Its doctors are world class.

那些了解医院管理者所面临挑战的人现在可能摇头叹息。你如何让外科医生同意像流水线工人一样被对待？对该行业的五力分析会告诉你，外科医生拥有要求缩短工作时间、提高工资和更多自主权的所有筹码。然而，Aravind 能够做一些美国医疗保健服务仍然无法做到的事情。Aravind 跟踪成本、时间和结果——甚至术后结果——所有这些都可以追溯到特定的医生和用于帮助他们提高绩效的数据。

Those of you who understand the challenges faced by hospital administrators are now probably shaking your heads. How do you get surgeons to agree to be treated like assembly line workers? A five forces analysis of this industry would tell you that surgeons have all the leverage to demand shorter hours, higher pay, and more autonomy. Yet Aravind is able to do something that continues to elude health-care delivery in the United States. Aravind tracks costs, time, and results—even postsurgical outcomes—all of which can be traced back to specific doctors and the data used to help them improve their performance.

对于 V 医生如何能找到愿意接受这些条件的医生，有一个轻率的答案。他最初雇用的是家庭成员。他们根本无法拒绝。还有一个更严肃的答案。V 医生建立了一个提供两项强有力的非金钱奖励的组织。一是致力于专业发展和卓越。例如，考虑一下它提供的广泛培训和专业联盟。二是呼吁无私服务和同情。这是一个肩负使命的组织。这项使命听起来无形，但却以有形的方式为 Aravind 的竞争优势做出了贡献。Aravind 的价值观使其能够招募和留住所需人才，并以非凡的方式配置其活动——一种完全符合其价值主张的方式。

There is a glib answer for how Dr. V. was able to find doctors willing to accept these conditions. His original hires were family members. They simply couldn’t say no. There is a more serious answer as well. Dr. V. has built an organization that offers two powerful nonmonetary rewards. One is its commitment to professional development and excellence. Consider, for example, the extensive training it provides and its professional affiliations. The second is an appeal to selfless service and compassion. This is an organization on a mission. And that mission, as intangible as it sounds, contributes to Aravind’s competitive advantage in tangible ways. Aravind’s values allow it to recruit and retain the talent it needs and to configure its activities in an extraordinary way—a way that is perfectly tailored to its value proposition.

Aravind 以人人都能负担得起的价格提供优质的眼科护理。这是它的价值主张。其量身定制的价值链将这一承诺转化为战略。

Aravind provides quality eye care at a price everyone can afford. That’s its value proposition. Its tailored value chain turns that promise into a strategy.

西南航空的定制活动

Southwest’s Tailored Activities

 

把高尚的阿拉文航空与爱好娱乐的西南航空相提并论似乎有些牵强，但从战略上讲，它们有很多共同之处，也有很多战略方面的值得借鉴的地方。两家公司在艰难的行业条件下都取得了持续的卓越业绩。

Comparing high-minded Aravind to fun-loving Southwest Airlines may feel like a stretch, but strategically speaking they have a lot in common, and a lot to teach about strategy. Both have produced sustained superior performance in the face of difficult industry conditions.

和阿拉文一样，西南航空也培育出了一种服务文化，这种文化让西南航空的战略得以奏效。在早期，西南航空大部分时间都在与威胁其生存的法律纠纷作斗争。德克萨斯州现有的航空公司不希望低价竞争对手进入市场。他们用尽一切法律和政治武器来阻止西南航空的飞行。这增强了西南航空的使命感，创造了一种独特的“战士”文化，致力于将旅客从不友好的行业中解放出来。西南航空的员工和阿拉文一样，都付出了额外的努力。尽管他们加入了工会，但他们从未像其他航空公司那样对公司采取对抗性的零和态度。这有助于提高竞争优势，提高客户满意度并降低相对成本。例如，西南航空和阿拉文都受益于低流动率。

Like Aravind, Southwest has cultivated a service culture that makes its strategy work. The company spent most of its early years fighting legal battles that threatened its very survival. The existing carriers in Texas did not want a low-priced competitor to enter the market. They used every legal and political weapon money could buy to prevent Southwest from flying. This intensified the sense of mission at Southwest, creating a distinctive “warrior” culture dedicated to freeing travelers from the grips of a customer-unfriendly industry. Southwest’s employees, like Aravind’s, go the extra mile. Though unionized, they have never adopted the adversarial, zero-sum attitude toward the company that has plagued other airlines. This contributes to competitive advantage, raising customer satisfaction and lowering relative costs. Both Southwest and Aravind, for example, benefit from low turnover.

在西南航空的成功撼动航空业之前，大多数航空公司都奉行一种常见的竞争方式，即模仿彼此的枢纽辐射系统、定价结构、常旅客计划和工会协议。西南航空选择不遵循这些行业“最佳实践”——其中一些是有效的竞争方式，可以满足其他类型航线的其他需求。相反，西南航空创建了量身定制的活动配置，以实现其独特的结果。

Before Southwest’s success shook up the airline industry, most carriers pursued a common way of competing, imitating each other’s hub-and-spoke systems, pricing structures, frequent flyer programs, and union agreements. Southwest chose not to pursue these industry “best practices”—some of them valid ways of competing that meet other needs on other types of routes. Instead, Southwest has created a tailored configuration of activities to deliver its unique outcome.

传统的全方位服务航空公司旨在将乘客从几乎任何 A 点运送到任何 B 点。为了到达大量目的地并为乘客提供转机服务，全方位服务航空公司采用以主要机场为中心的枢纽辐射系统。为了吸引需要更多舒适度和服务的乘客，他们提供头等舱或商务舱。为了满足必须换乘飞机的乘客的需求，他们会协调航班时刻表并办理行李托运和转运。由于有些乘客的旅行时间长达数小时，因此全方位服务航空公司传统上会提供餐食。

The traditional full-service airline is designed to get passengers from almost any point A to any point B. To reach a large number of destinations and serve passengers with connecting flights, full-service airlines employ a hub-and-spoke system centered on major airports. To attract passengers who desire more comfort or services, they offer first class or business class. To accommodate passengers who must change planes, they coordinate schedules and check and transfer baggage. Because some passengers will be traveling for many hours, full-service airlines traditionally served meals.

相比之下，西南航空则将自己的所有活动都量身定制，以最低成本提供特定航线的频繁服务。从一开始，西南航空就不提供餐食、指定座位、联运行李托运或高级舱位服务，而这些都有助于缩短登机口周转时间，我们在第 3 章中已经提到过。这使得西南航空能够延长飞机的飞行时间，以更少的飞机提供频繁的起飞。登机口和地勤人员比其竞争对手更精简、更灵活、更高效。标准化的机队提高了维护效率。随着基于网络的旅游网站成为一种流行的分销渠道，大多数航空公司都争相签约（这对行业结构来说是一个糟糕的决定，因为它迫使客户只看价格就购买）。西南航空却不是这样。它的乘客直接在西南航空的网站上购买机票，绕过了其他渠道，西南航空也因此避免了销售佣金。

Southwest, in contrast, tailored all its activities to deliver frequent service on its particular type of route at the lowest cost. From the start, it didn’t offer meals, assigned seats, interline baggage checking, or premium classes of service, all of which contributed to the faster gate turnaround times we saw in chapter 3. This enables Southwest to keep planes flying longer hours and to provide frequent departures with fewer aircraft. Gate and ground crews are leaner, more flexible, and more productive than its rivals. A standardized fleet of aircraft boosts the efficiency of maintenance. As Web-based travel sites became a popular distribution channel, most airlines rushed to sign up (a bad decision for industry structure, since it pushes customers to buy on price alone). Not Southwest. Its passengers buy tickets directly on the Southwest Web site, bypassing other channels and allowing Southwest to avoid sales commissions.

这些只是西南航空竞争优势的部分成本驱动因素，这些因素使其能够为每位员工提供更多乘客，每个登机口每天提供更多航班，每架飞机的利用时间更长。西南航空根据一系列量身定制的活动，确立了独特而宝贵的战略地位。在西南航空服务的航线上，一家全方位服务的航空公司永远无法像西南航空这样方便或低成本。

These are just some of the cost drivers underpinning Southwest’s competitive advantage, allowing it to serve more passengers per employee, to get more daily departures per gate, and to get more hours of use per plane. Southwest staked out a unique and valuable strategic position based on a tailored set of activities. On the routes served by Southwest, a full-service airline could never be as convenient or as low cost.

战略定位，尤其是当其高度集中时，有时被视为开辟一个“利基市场”。这个词的含义是市场机会很小。尽管有时确实如此，但即使是集中的竞争对手也可能非常强大。以西南航空为例，最初看似狭窄的利基市场已经彻底改变了航空业。西南航空和我们的下一个例子 Enterprise Rent-A-Car 都已成为行业领导者。

A strategic positioning, especially when it has a high degree of focus, is sometimes seen as carving out a “niche.” The implication of that word is that the market opportunity is small. Although this may sometimes be the case, even focused competitors can be very large. In the case of Southwest, what initially looked like a narrow niche has revolutionized the airline industry. Both Southwest and our next example, Enterprise Rent-A-Car, have become industry leaders.

您能同时实现差异化和低成本吗？

Can You Be Differentiated and Low Cost at the Same Time?

 

在其职业生涯早期，波特就确定了一套通用战略——专注、差异化和成本领先——这些战略很快成为思考关键战略选择的最广泛使用的工具之一。这三者都反映了每一项有效战略必须具备的最基本的一致性。专注是指公司服务的客户和需求的广度或狭窄程度。差异化使公司能够获得溢价。成本领先使其能够通过提供较低的相对价格来竞争。这些对战略类型的广泛描述抓住了任何行业中战略选择的基本维度。

Early in his career, Porter identified a set of generic strategies—focus, differentiation, and cost leadership—that quickly became one of the most widely used tools for thinking about key strategic choices. Each of the three reflects the most basic level of consistency that every effective strategy must have. Focus refers to the breadth or narrowness of the customers and needs a company serves. Differentiation allows a company to command a premium price. Cost leadership allows it to compete by offering a low relative price. These broad characterizations of strategy types capture the fundamental dimensions of strategic choice relevant in any industry.

与此同时，波特还描述了一种常见的战略错误，即“进退维谷”。当一家公司试图满足所有客户的所有需求时，就会发生这种情况，一方面，成本领先者能够满足“刚好足够”的客户需求，另一方面，差异化者能够更好地满足“想要更多”（他们看重的某些特定属性）的客户。

At the same time, Porter described a common strategic mistake, which came to be known as getting stuck in the middle. This happens when a company tries to be all things to all customers and is outflanked by cost leaders on one side, who meet “just enough” of their customers’ needs, and by differentiators on the other side, who do a better job of satisfying customers who “want more” (of some particular attribute they value).

这是否意味着一家公司不能同时实现差异化和低成本？完全不是，尽管这是另一个长期存在的误解。波特最早的著作（大约 1980 年）有时被引用为相反的证据。但波特在 20 世纪 90 年代继续完善其关于价值主张和价值链之间联系的研究，这项工作本应消除这种误解。“当你深入了解特定产品所满足的特定需求时，”他解释说，“你会发现可能的选择/组合要复杂得多。通用战略确定了战略的一个主要主题，例如相对成本。但有效的战略以独特的方式整合了多个主题。客户的需求很少是单一的，因此满足这些需求的战略也不会是单一的。当一家公司选择要服务哪些客户和需求，并根据这些选择调整其价值链时，它就有可能同时实现差异化、低成本和专注，就像 Enterprise 一样。或者像西南航空那样，你可以享受到更便捷、更低成本的体验，而不会陷入困境。”

Does this mean that a company can’t be both differentiated and low cost at the same time? Not at all, although this is another persistent misconception. Porter’s earliest work (circa 1980) is sometimes cited as evidence to the contrary. But Porter went on in the 1990s to refine his work on the link between the value proposition and the value chain, work that should have put that misunderstanding to rest. “When you get down to the specific needs that are served by specific products,” he explains, “you see that the possible choices/combinations are far more complex. Generic strategies identified one dominant theme of a strategy, such as relative cost. But effective strategies integrate multiple themes in a unique way. Customers’ needs are rarely uni-dimensional and therefore a strategy to meet those needs won’t be uni-dimensional either. When a company makes choices about which customers and needs it will serve, and when it tailors its value chain to those choices, it is possible to be differentiated and low cost and focused at the same time, as Enterprise is. Or, like Southwest, you can be more convenient and lower cost—without getting stuck in the middle.”

 

汽车租赁价值链

Car Rental Value Chains

 

Enterprise 独特的价值主张——为车主提供本地租车服务——只是其成功故事的一部分。其在配置价值链时做出的选择解释了其竞争优势。Enterprise 能够为那些想要降低成本的客户提供服务，因为这些需求可以通过不同的、低成本的活动配置来满足。Enterprise 的战略洞察力是，其特定的价值主张需要与Hertz 或 Avis 完全不同的价值链。

Enterprise’s unique value proposition—rentals for car owners in their home city—is only part of the story of its success. The choices it has made in configuring its value chain explain its competitive advantage. Enterprise was able to serve customers who wanted lower costs because those needs could be met with a different, lower-cost configuration of activities. Enterprise’s strategic insight was that its particular value proposition would require a completely different value chain from a Hertz or an Avis.

其他汽车租赁公司选择租金高、方便旅行者的地点，例如机场、火车站或酒店。但 Enterprise 却不是这样。它选择了遍布大都市的小型办公室，通常是简单的店面，这种做法始于 1957 年创始人杰克·泰勒在圣路易斯创办他的小型汽车租赁公司时。但随着公司的发展和战略的出现，战略逻辑也随之出现。对于本地租车人来说，没有什么比必须去机场取车更不方便的了。

Other car rental companies chose high-rent locations convenient to travelers, for example, airports, train stations, or hotels. Not Enterprise. It chose small offices, often simple storefronts, spread all over a metropolitan area, a practice that began when founder Jack Taylor started his tiny auto leasing business in St. Louis in 1957. But as the company grew and its strategy emerged, so did the strategic logic. Nothing could be more inconvenient for a home-city renter than to have to go to the airport to pick up a car.

最初只是公司早期历史的偶然，后来却演变成战略选择。对于其选定的客户而言，Enterprise 的邻近地点（目前距离 90% 的美国人口不到 15 英里）更为方便。租金也较低，这使得 Enterprise 能够收取比竞争对手更低的价格。直到 1995 年，即公司成立 35 年后，Enterprise 才开设了第一家机场地点。在汽车租赁业务中，很容易看出，对于旅行者和本地租车者来说，办公室的最佳配置非常不同。

What began as an accident of early company history became a matter of strategic choice. For its chosen customer, Enterprise’s neighborhood locations, now within fifteen miles of 90 percent of the U.S. population, are more convenient. The rent was also lower, allowing Enterprise to charge lower prices than rivals. Only in 1995, more than thirty-five years after the company was founded, did Enterprise open its first airport location. In the car rental business, it is easy to see that the optimal configuration of offices is very different for travelers than for home-city renters.

事实上，正和竞争之所以可能，正是因为大多数活动都有各种配置方式。Zipcar 可以完全取消办公室。Zipster 是付费会员，其信息已存档，省去了租车交易的所有常规文书工作。技术让客服人员变得多余，因为 Zipster 可以在线预订。Zipcar 停放在遍布大都市地区的指定地点。嵌入无线芯片的特殊访问 Zipcard 允许会员仅在指定的租车时间打开他们预订的特定汽车。挡风玻璃上的应答器记录使用时间和里程，并通过无线链路直接传送到中央计算机。Zipcar 让租车变得像从 ATM 机取现金一样简单。

In fact, positive-sum competition is possible precisely because there are a variety of ways to configure most activities. Zipcar is able to do away with offices entirely. Zipsters are paid members whose information is on file, eliminating all the usual paperwork of a rental transaction. Technology makes customer service staff unnecessary because Zipsters make reservations online. Zipcars are parked in designated spots spread throughout a metro area. Special access Zipcards with embedded wireless chips allow members to open the specific car they’ve reserved only at the specified rental time. Transponders on the windshield record hours of usage and mileage, which are directly communicated to a central computer via a wireless link. Zipcar makes renting a car as easy as withdrawing cash from an ATM.

价值链的其他部分也需要量身定制。每家汽车租赁公司都必须配置其车队。由于度假和商务旅客通常想要特殊的车型（例如 SUV 或敞篷车），Hertz 和 Avis 将这些“热门”车型纳入其车队。Enterprise 的本地城市租车者对低成本、更基本的车型感到满意。他们也不太关心汽车的年龄，这使得 Enterprise 能够比以旅行者为导向的公司保留其汽车的时间更长。Zipcar 正在通过一系列“酷”车（如环保的本田 Insight 和宝马 Mini）来打造其品牌。

Other parts of the value chain are tailored as well. Every car rental company has to configure its fleet of vehicles. Because vacation and business travelers often want special car models—SUVs or convertibles, for example—Hertz and Avis include these “hot” vehicles in their fleets. Enterprise’s home-city renters are satisfied with lower-cost, more basic models. They are also less concerned with the age of a car, enabling Enterprise to keep its cars longer than the traveler-oriented companies. Zipcar is building its brand with a fleet of “cool” cars like the environmentally friendly Honda Insight and the BMW Mini.

对于 Zipcar 来说，这些印有公司时尚标志的汽车就像滚动的广告牌，向社区宣传公司的品牌。Zipcar 还通过与学校和公司建立大量合作伙伴关系来吸引新客户。为了符合其价值主张，Enterprise 倾向于向保险公司和汽车经销商推销，这是其保持低成本的另一个重要方式。相比之下，Hertz 使用昂贵的消费者广告来吸引其商务和休闲旅客。

For Zipcar, the cars themselves, displaying the company’s hip logo, are like rolling billboards that announce the company’s brand to the neighborhood. Zipcar also attracts new customers through a raft of partnerships with schools and companies. In keeping with its value proposition, Enterprise tends to market to insurance companies and car dealerships, another important way in which its costs are kept low. In contrast, Hertz uses expensive consumer advertising to attract its business and leisure travelers.

当一家公司专注于向不同的客户群体提供不同类型的价值时——对波特来说，这是战略定位的本质——价值链差异的列表可能会很广泛（见图4-3）。

When a company focuses on delivering a different kind of value to a different set of customers—for Porter, the essence of strategic positioning—the list of value chain differences can be extensive (see figure 4-3).

图 4-3

FIGURE 4-3

每个价值主张都最好通过量身定制的价值链来交付

Each value proposition is best delivered by a tailored value chain

 

限制是必要的

Limits Are Essential

 

价值主张中的选择限制了公司将做什么，这对战略至关重要，因为它们创造了机会，可以以最佳方式定制活动，从而实现这种价值。只有在有限制的情况下，只有在你不试图满足所有人的需求的情况下，定制才有可能。换句话说，限制使得开发一条与选择提供不同价值的竞争对手不同的价值链成为可能。

Choices in the value proposition that limit what a company will do are essential to strategy because they create the opportunity to tailor activities in a way that best delivers that kind of value. Tailoring is possible only if there are limits, only if you are not trying to be all things to all people. In other words, limits make it possible to develop a value chain that is different from that of rivals who have chosen to offer a different kind of value.

 

价值主张中的选择限制了公司的行为，这对于战略而言至关重要，因为它们创造了以最佳方式定制活动的机会，从而实现最佳价值。

Choices in the value proposition that limit what a company will do are essential to strategy because they create the opportunity to tailor activities in a way that best delivers that kind of value.

 

这是一项至关重要的测试，应该应用于任何战略。如果同一条价值链能够同样出色地提供不同的价值主张，那么这些价值主张就没有战略意义。只有需要量身定制的价值链才能实现的价值主张才能成为强大战略的基础。这是对抗竞争对手的第一道防线。

This is a crucially important test that should be applied to any strategy. If the same value chain can deliver different value propositions equally well, then those value propositions have no strategic relevance. Only a value proposition that requires a tailored value chain to deliver it can serve as the basis for a robust strategy. This is the first line of defense against rivals.

因此，战略定义了一种竞争方式，体现在一系列活动中，这些活动为特定用途或特定客户群（或两者兼而有之）提供了独特的价值。在大多数行业中，可能存在许多具有战略意义的价值主张。这仅仅反映了客户和需求的巨大差异，以及通常需要不同的活动配置才能最有效地满足这些需求这一事实。即使一个行业生产的产品看起来是同质的，波特也指出，价值链上下游存在许多差异化机会——交付、处置、认证和测试以及融资，仅举几个方面。

Strategy, then, defines a way of competing, reflected in a set of activities that delivers unique value in a particular set of uses or for a particular set of customers, or both. In most industries, there can be many strategically relevant value propositions. This simply reflects the great diversity in customers and needs, and the fact that different activity configurations are often required to meet those needs most effectively. Even when an industry produces something that looks like a homogenous product, Porter points to many opportunities up and down the value chain for differentiation—in delivery, in disposal, in certification and testing, and in financing, to name just a few dimensions.

虽然并非每项活动都需要独一无二，但稳健的战略总是需要相当程度的量身定制。要建立竞争优势，公司必须通过独特的价值链提供其独特的价值。它必须执行与竞争对手不同的活动或以不同的方式执行类似的活动。

While not every single activity need be unique, robust strategies always involve a significant degree of tailoring. To establish a competitive advantage, a company must deliver its distinctive value through a distinctive value chain. It must perform different activities than rivals or perform similar activities in different ways.

因此，价值主张和价值链——战略选择的两个核心维度——是密不可分的。价值主张从外部关注客户。价值链从内部关注运营。战略从根本上讲是综合性的，将需求方和供应方联系在一起。

Thus the value proposition and the value chain—the two core dimensions of strategic choice—are inextricably linked. The value proposition focuses externally on the customer. The value chain focuses internally on operations. Strategy is fundamentally integrative, bringing the demand and supply sides together.

发现新职位：从哪里开始

Discovering New Positions: Where to Begin

 

波特写道：“战略竞争可以看作是感知新定位的过程，新定位会吸引客户离开既有定位，或吸引新客户进入市场。”事后描述战略时，价值主张是合乎逻辑的起点，我在本章中就是这么做的。但实际上，公司如何真正找到新定位呢？寻找新方法来细分客户或满足尚未满足的需求是一个起点。但价值链（公司开展的一系列独特活动）也是一个同样有效的起点。事实上，这基本上就是公司在确定其“优势”时所做的。

“Strategic competition,” Porter writes, “can be thought of as the process of perceiving new positions that woo customers from established positions or draw new customers into the market.” In describing a strategy after the fact, the value proposition is the logical place to begin, as I have done in this chapter. But how do companies, in practice, actually find new positions? Looking for new ways to segment customers or to serve unmet needs is one starting point. But the value chain—the unique set of activities your company performs—is an equally valid starting point. This, in fact, is essentially what companies do when they identify their “strengths.”

以 Grace Manufacturing 为例，这是一家位于阿肯色州的小型家族企业。Grace 并非家喻户晓的品牌，但其主打产品 Microplane 却在厨师中享有盛誉，是磨碎硬奶酪和剥柑橘皮的首选工具。Microplane 随后推出了数十条产品线，在家庭用品行业开辟了一个新的细分市场。

Consider Grace Manufacturing, a small, family-owned company based in Arkansas. Grace is not a household name, but its leading product, the Microplane, is renowned among cooks as the tool of choice for grating hard cheeses and zesting citrus. The Microplane, followed by tens of line extensions, created a new segment in the housewares industry.

Grace 如何找到自己的定位是一个有趣的故事。该公司是一家钢制打印机带的合同制造商，随着打印机技术的进步，钢制打印机带已逐渐过时。面对核心产品即将消亡的局面，Grace 的主要资产是一种专有的掩蔽和蚀刻工艺，可以生产出边缘锋利的带子。现任公司首席执行官的 Chris Grace 回忆起高中时在家族企业工作的经历：“‘当时，如果你在工厂工作，问题不是你会不会割伤手指，而是什么时候会割伤手指。我们意识到我们擅长制造锋利的东西。所以我们想，我们能制造什么锋利的东西？’”他们决定生产专业木工用的工具。

How Grace discovered its position is an interesting story. The company was a contract manufacturer of steel printer bands, a product approaching obsolescence as printer technology advanced. Facing the imminent demise of its core product, Grace’s principal asset was a proprietary masking and etching process that produced bands with razor-sharp edges. Chris Grace, now the company’s CEO, recalled working in the family business while he was in high school: “‘Back then, if you worked in the plant, it wasn’t a question of whether you were going to cut your finger, but when. We realized we were good at making sharp things. And so we thought, what can we make that’s sharp?’” They settled on tools for serious woodworkers.

Microplane 品牌的锉刀设计为安装在钢锯架上。但不知何故，人们说它是一种非凡的厨房工具。公司创始人理查德·格雷斯最初在听说他的产品被如此使用时感到失望。但如今，该公司生产了一系列厨房用锋利产品，从披萨切刀到巧克力磨碎机。此外，格雷斯利用其在生产锋利物品方面的专有技术，为骨科医生增加了用于磨骨或准备植入物髋臼的产品。专有是这个故事的关键词。格雷斯制造公司不仅擅长制造锋利物品。对于战略而言，最重要的是，它拥有独特的优势。

The Microplane brand rasp was designed to be mounted on a hacksaw frame. But somehow word got out that it made an extraordinary kitchen tool. Richard Grace, the company’s founder, was initially disappointed when he heard how his product was being used. But today, the company makes a whole line of sharp products for the kitchen, from pizza cutters to chocolate graters. Moreover, leveraging its proprietary know-how in producing sharp things, Grace has added products for orthopedists that grind bone or prepare hip sockets for implants. Proprietary is a key word in this story. Grace Manufacturing didn’t just have a strength in making sharp things. Most essential for strategy, it had a unique strength.
