发现新位置是一种创造性行为。触发最初洞察力的因素往往因人而异，因组织而异。没有哪本菜谱或专家系统能够可靠地制定出制胜战略。从定义上讲，战略就是创造独特的东西，做出别人没有做过的一系列选择。

Discovering new positions is a creative act. What triggers the initial insight often varies from one person, and one organization, to the next. No cookbook or expert system can reliably churn out winning strategies. By definition, strategy is about creating something unique, making a set of choices that nobody else has made.

 

第五章

CHAPTER 5

 

权衡：

Trade-offs:

 

关键人物

The Linchpin

 

在上一章中，我介绍了波特对战略的最初两个测试：独特的价值主张和实现该主张所需的定制价值链。如果要说有什么重要的启示，那就是战略需要选择。竞争优势取决于做出与竞争对手不同的选择，取决于权衡。这是波特的第三个测试。权衡起着如此关键的作用，以至于称其为战略的关键一点也不为过。它们将战略凝聚在一起，有助于创造和维持竞争优势。

IN THE LAST CHAPTER, I presented Porter’s first two tests of strategy: a unique value proposition and the tailored value chain required to deliver it. If there is one important takeaway message, it is that strategy requires choice. Competitive advantage depends on making choices that are different from those of rivals, on making trade-offs. This is Porter’s third test. Trade-offs play such a critical role that it’s no exaggeration to call them strategy’s linchpin. They hold a strategy together as they contribute to both creating and sustaining competitive advantage.

需要做出权衡是另一个与流行思维相悖的想法，它体现在两个方面。第一个误解是关于权衡本身。管理者往往认为“越多越好”。更多的客户、更多的产品、更多的服务意味着更多的销售和利润。你可以拥有一切。你可以同时做A 和 B。如果你选择其中之一，你就会在金钱上白白浪费。做出权衡几乎是一种软弱的表现。

The need to make trade-offs is yet another idea that runs counter to popular thinking, and it does so in two ways. The first misconception is about trade-offs themselves. Managers tend to believe that “more is always better.” More customers, more products, more services mean more sales and profits. You can have it all. You can do both A and B. If you choose either one or the other, you’ll be leaving money on the table. Making trade-offs is almost a sign of weakness.

第二个误解是关于在当今竞争异常激烈的世界里，是否有可能保持竞争优势。这个世界里任何东西都可以被复制，你所能期望的最好结果也不过是一系列非常短暂的优势。听起来很熟悉？这又是为了成为最好的而竞争。

The second misconception is about whether it is possible, in today’s supercharged, hypercompetitive world, to sustain a competitive advantage. This is a world in which anything can and will be copied, a world in which the best you can hope for in competing is a series of very temporary advantages. Sound familiar? This is, once again, competing to be the best.

但仔细思考一下，你就会发现这个论点与事实不符。确实，仅仅选择一个独特的价值主张并不能保证可持续发展。如果你找到了一个有价值的立场，模仿者就会注意到。但竞争优势可以持续数十年，西南航空、宜家、沃尔玛、Enterprise Rent-A-Car、宝马、麦当劳、苹果等公司就是明证。这些多元化公司的战略有什么共同之处？答案只有一个词：权衡。

But think about it for a minute, and you’ll see that this argument fails to square with the facts. It’s true that choosing a unique value proposition alone is no guarantee of sustainability. If you find a valuable position, imitators will take notice. But competitive advantages can and do persist for decades, as companies such as Southwest Airlines, IKEA, Walmart, Enterprise Rent-A-Car, BMW, McDonald’s, Apple, and many others attest. What do the strategies of such diverse companies as these have in common? The answer lies in just one word: trade-offs.

什么是权衡？

What Are Trade-offs?

 

权衡在战略上相当于岔路口。如果你选择一条路，就不能同时选择另一条路。无论岔路口是产品本身的特性，还是价值链中活动的配置，权衡都意味着你无法同时实现两种选择，因为这些选择是不相容的。

Trade-offs are the strategic equivalent of a fork in the road. If you take one path, you cannot simultaneously take the other. Whether the fork in the road is about the characteristics of the product itself or about the configuration of activities in the value chain, a trade-off means that you can’t have it both ways because the choices are incompatible.

 

权衡在战略上相当于岔路口。如果你选择了一条路，就不能同时选择另一条路。

Trade-offs are the strategic equivalent of a fork in the road. If you take one path, you cannot simultaneously take the other.

 

例如，每家航空公司都必须选择一种航线系统。它既可以选择枢纽辐射型配置，让乘客能够往返于更多目的地之间，但成本更高；也可以选择点对点航线系统，牺牲“无处不在”，服务较少的目的地，但成本更低。这是一个非此即彼的选择。航空公司可以选择其中一种，但不能同时选择两种，否则会造成效率低下。

Every airline, for example, must choose a route system. It can choose a hub-and-spoke configuration that offers passengers the ability to travel between many more destinations but at higher cost, or it can choose a point-to-point route system that sacrifices “ubiquity,” serving fewer destinations but doing so at lower cost. The choice is a stark either-or. An airline can choose one or the other, but it can’t choose both at once without creating inefficiencies.

当存在权衡时，产品或活动不仅仅是不同，而且是不一致的。一种选择会排除或损害另一种选择。竞争充满了经济权衡。这些是战略的核心。

Where there are trade-offs, products or activities are not just different. They are inconsistent. One choice precludes or compromises the other. Competition is full of economic trade-offs. These lie at the very heart of strategy.

以台湾半导体公司 (TSMC) 为例，这家半导体制造商的销售额约为 90 亿美元（2009 年）。虽然大多数企业家都以推出新产品或服务而闻名，但台湾半导体公司的创始人张忠谋却通过认识到一个关键权衡的价值而建立了一家公司。当他于 1987 年创立台积电时，几乎所有的主要半导体公司都是业内所谓的集成设备制造商 (IDM)。也就是说，他们设计和制造自己的芯片。由于芯片制造设施非常昂贵，如果 IDM 产能过剩，他们会将其出租给无力建造自己设施的小型企业。对于 IDM 来说，这些小公司的需求只是事后才考虑的。

Consider Taiwan Semiconductor (TSMC), a semiconductor manufacturer with sales of about $9 billion (in 2009). While most entrepreneurs are known for coming up with new products or services, Morris Chang, the founder of Taiwan Semiconductor, built a company by recognizing the value of a single, crucial trade-off. When he started TSMC in 1987, nearly all of the major semiconductor companies were what the industry calls integrated device manufacturers (IDMs). That is, they designed and manufactured their own chips. Because the manufacturing facilities for chips are very expensive, if the IDMs had excess capacity, they would rent it out to smaller firms that couldn’t afford to build their own facilities. For the IDMs, the needs of these smaller companies were just an afterthought.

张博士知道，这种情况给小公司带来了真正的困境。一方面，他们负担不起自己的产能。另一方面，通过将生产外包给 IDM，他们最宝贵的资产——知识产权——面临风险。他们担心 IDM 会窃取他们的芯片设计。

Dr. Chang knew that this situation posed a real dilemma for the smaller companies. On the one hand, they couldn’t afford their own capacity. On the other hand, by outsourcing production to the IDMs, they put at risk their most valuable asset, their intellectual property. They lived in fear that an IDM would steal their chip designs.

张忠谋愿意做出重大牺牲。他将成为其他芯片设计公司的制造商。就这样。台积电将不再从事自己的芯片设计业务。通过这一关键选择，张博士消除了利益冲突。他不再与客户竞争，而是为他们制造产品。通过这样做，他将为客户创造更多价值。当然，这一根本性的政策选择意味着台积电的价值链与其竞争对手不同——其活动也不同。

Morris Chang was willing to make a big trade-off. He would become a manufacturer for other chip designers. Period. Taiwan Semiconductor would not be in the business of designing its own chips. With that one crucial choice, Dr. Chang eliminated the conflict of interest. Instead of competing with his customers, he would simply manufacture for them. By so doing, he would create more value for his customers. And, of course, this fundamental policy choice meant that TSMC had a different value chain than its rivals—its activities were different.

这种权衡是台积电竞争优势的来源。请记住，竞争优势不仅仅是你擅长的东西，它还反映在你的损益表中。通过专注于制造，张忠谋实现了较低的相对成本（即他的制造成本低于竞争对手的IDM）。而且由于他除了制造之外还提供知识产权保护，客户愿意为他创造的附加值支付更多费用。

This trade-off was the source of TSMC’s competitive advantage. And remember that competitive advantage is not just something you’re good at, it’s something that’s reflected in your P&L. By focusing only on manufacturing, Morris Chang achieved lower relative costs (that is, his manufacturing costs were lower than those of rival IDMs). And because he offered intellectual property protection in addition to manufacturing, customers were willing to pay more for the added value he created.

稳健的战略通常包含多种权衡。最好的战略几乎在价值链的每一步都有权衡。以瑞典家居巨头宜家为例。宜家的价值主张是以低廉的价格提供良好的设计和功能。其目标客户是宜家所说的“钱包薄”的人。在选择其特定类型的价值以及实现该价值所需的活动时，宜家接受了一系列限制：它无法满足所有客户的所有需求。

Robust strategies typically incorporate multiple trade-offs. The very best have trade-offs at almost every step in the value chain. Consider IKEA, the Swedish home furnishings giant. IKEA’s value proposition is to provide good design and function at a low price. Its target customer is what IKEA calls the person “with a thin wallet.” In choosing its particular kind of value and the activities needed to deliver it, IKEA has accepted a set of limits: it does not meet all the needs of all customers.

在家居用品的制造和销售过程中，宜家在每一个重要的增值步骤中都做出了与我所说的“传统”家居用品零售商不同的选择。请考虑以下几点：

In every major value-adding step in the process of creating and selling home furnishings, IKEA has made different choices from what I’ll call the “traditional” home furnishings retailer. Consider the following:

 
  • 产品设计。宜家的家具是模块化的，可以随时组装。传统零售商出售的是完全组装好的家具。这是一个关键的非此即彼的权衡。一件家具要么完全组装，要么不完全组装。与业内大多数其他公司不同，宜家设计自己的产品；这种选择让宜家能够在其销售的所有产品的款式和成本方面做出各种关键的权衡。宜家的设计师有非常具体的目标和明确的限制：为特定产品系列设计一款售价为 30 美元的咖啡桌。这就是一些尖锐的权衡。你可以用低成本获得好的设计，但你不可能拥有一张用雀眼枫木制成的 30 美元的咖啡桌，或用最好的皮革制成的 40 美元的椅子。宜家的设计师的任务是针对每件产品做出明确的权衡。
  • Product design. IKEA’s furniture is modular and ready to assemble. The traditional retailer sells fully assembled pieces. That’s a critical either-or trade-off. Either a piece of furniture is fully assembled or it isn’t. Unlike most other companies in its industry, IKEA designs its own products; this choice then allows IKEA to make all kinds of critical trade-offs in styling and in the cost of everything it sells. IKEA’s designers are given very specific targets with clear constraints: design a coffee table for a given product line that will sell for $30. Here’s where you see some sharp trade-offs. You can have good design at low cost, but there is no way you can have, for example, a $30 coffee table made of birdseye maple, or a $40 chair made with the finest leather. IKEA’s designers are tasked with making clear trade-offs regarding each product.
    •  
  • 产品种类繁多。传统零售商提供各种家具风格——从美国殖民风格到法国乡村风格再到明朝风格。他们为顾客提供数百种面料选择。但种类繁多和定制化都会增加成本。宜家的权衡是：款式范围狭窄，仅限于斯堪的纳维亚风格及其分支，并且仅提供少数几种饰面和面料选择。反过来，限制产品复杂性的权衡使宜家能够从高效的第三方制造商那里批量采购产品，这些制造商在全球范围内生产。记住五种力量。宜家是一个巨人，能够与供应商谈判获得优惠价格。
  • Product variety. Traditional retailers offer a wide range of furniture styles—from American colonial to French country to Ming dynasty. They offer customers hundreds of fabric choices. But both breadth and customization add costs. IKEA’s trade-off: carry a narrow style range, limited to Scandinavian and its offshoots, and offer only a few choices of finishes and fabrics. In turn, trade-offs that limit product complexity allow IKEA to source product in bulk from efficient third-party manufacturers that produce on a global scale. Remember the five forces. IKEA is a Goliath, able to negotiate favorable prices from its suppliers.
    •  
  • 店内服务。传统零售商会聘用销售人员帮助客户做出数百种家居装饰选择。但是，销售人员会增加成本。这又是一个棘手的权衡，非此即彼的选择。要么在商店中聘用销售人员，要么不聘用，但你无法同时做到这两点。宜家对这种权衡非常明确。它告诉客户，自助服务可以换取更低的价格。甚至商店的自助餐厅也在强调这一信息。标牌上写着，用餐结束后自己收拾桌子可以让你享受用餐开始时支付的低价。
  • In-store service. Traditional retailers use sales associates to help customers with the hundreds of choices involved in furnishing a home. Sales associates, however, add cost. Here is another sharp trade-off, an either-or choice. Either you staff a store with sales associates or you don’t, but you can’t have it both ways. IKEA is explicit about this trade-off. It tells its customers that in exchange for serving themselves, they will be rewarded with lower prices. Even the store cafeteria reinforces this message. Signs explain that clearing your own table at the end of your meal allows the low price you paid at its start.
    •  
  • 配送和店面设计。传统家具卖家将产品直接从制造商或仓库运送到客户家中。宜家明确将配送“外包”给客户，同样是为了降低价格。宜家在店面设计和位置方面做出的诸多权衡让您可以轻松（尽可能轻松）地自助购物。当您在宜家众多的展示间中看到自己喜欢的东西时，您会记下商品编号。当您离开最后一个展示区并在到达收银台之前，您会经过一个巨大的仓库，货架上堆满了以扁平包装形式摆放的即装即用的家具。您找到商品编号，将扁平包装装入宜家专门设计的购物车，然后出门去取车。宜家选择方便驾车前往的地点（在美国，绝不选择市中心），并有充足的免费停车位；它创建大型商店来展示和储存每件商品（绝不选择只展示部分商品的小商店）。
  • Delivery and store design. Traditional furniture sellers have products shipped direct from a manufacturer or a warehouse to the customer’s home. IKEA explicitly “outsources” delivery to its customers, again in exchange for lower prices. Its many trade-offs in store design and location make it easy (well, as easy as it can be) for you to serve yourself. When you see something you like in one of IKEA’s many, many room displays, you write down the item number. As you leave the last display area and before you arrive at the checkout lines, you pass through a cavernous warehouse, its shelves stacked with ready-to-assemble furniture in flat packs. You look for your item number, load the flat pack onto IKEA’s specially designed shopping cart, and out you go to your car. IKEA chooses car-friendly locations (in the United States, never downtown) with ample free parking; it creates huge stores to display and stock every item (never small stores displaying only selected items).
    •  
  • 平板包装和竞争优势。宜家早期的历史是这样的，一位宜家员工拆掉了一张桌子的腿，以便顾客可以把它用车带回家。正如该公司所说，这是一次“尤里卡时刻”。如果家具以拆开的平板包装形式出售，顾客可以“自行送货”。此外，节省空间的平板包装大大降低了物流成本。宜家每辆卡车可以装下六倍数量的家具，运送到其门店。

    这种洞察力最终成为宜家的竞争优势，即它使宜家的价值链活动变得与众不同，从而降低了其成本。平板包装家具的运输成本大大低于组装家具。这使得宜家能够收取较低的价格，同时仍能盈利。

    平板包装还有其他优势。愿意将购买的家具带回家自己组装的顾客不仅可以支付更低的价格，而且可以当天就拿到家具，无需等待数周送货，运输损坏的风险也小得多。这增加了宜家的成本优势，并提高了客户满意度。我永远不会忘记我买的第一张沙发。等了六个星期才送货，结果送到的时候，沙发的布料上有一个大裂口。我花了几个小时安排将沙发运回制造商，又花了六个星期等待更换。这对我来说不是一次愉快的经历，对供应商来说也是一次昂贵的经历。

    一项有趣的最新研究发现了所谓的宜家效应：自行组装实际上提高了而不是降低了消费者愿意支付的价格。当你能同时提高客户价值并降低自己的成本时，这还不错！

  • Flat packs and competitive advantage. Early in IKEA’s history, or so the story goes, an IKEA employee removed the legs of a table so that a customer could carry it home in his car. As the company tells it, this was one of those Eureka moments. If furniture were sold disassembled and in flat packs, customers could “self-deliver.” In addition, the space-saving flat packs massively lower the cost of logistics. IKEA can fit six times the number of pieces into each truckload being delivered to its stores.

    This insight ultimately became a source of competitive advantage; that is, it led to differences in the activities in IKEA’s value chain that resulted in lower costs than those of its rivals. Shipping costs for furniture in flat packs are dramatically lower than those for assembled furniture. This allows IKEA to charge lower prices and still make a profit.

    Flat packs have other advantages. Customers who are willing to carry their purchases home and do their own assembly not only pay a lower price, but also get the furniture today, without waiting weeks for delivery, and with far less risk of shipping damage. This adds to IKEA’s cost advantage, and it enhances customer satisfaction. I’ve never forgotten the first sofa I ever bought. After waiting six weeks for it to be delivered, it arrived with a big tear in the fabric. I spent hours arranging to have the sofa shipped back to the manufacturer, and another six weeks waiting for the replacement. Not a happy experience for me, and a costly one for the vendor.

    An intriguing recent study has found a so-called IKEA effect: that self-assembly actually raises, not lowers, the price consumers would be willing to pay. Not bad when you can raise customer value and lower your own costs at the same time!

    •  
 

现在想想这些成本和价值差异的累积影响，它们都源于一种权衡：要么你出售需要运输的全组装家具，要么你设计成可以运输的平板包装，然后由客户在家组装。波特喜欢说，如果你有一个战略，你应该能够将它直接与你的损益表联系起来。这正是这种联系的一个例子。

Now think about the cumulative impact of these differences in cost and value, all of them stemming from one trade-off: either you sell fully assembled furniture that has to be shipped, or you design it to be transported in flat packs and assembled in-home by the customer. Porter is fond of saying that if you have a strategy, you should be able to link it directly to your P&L. This is an example of precisely that kind of linkage.

 

如果您有策略，您应该能够将其直接链接到您的损益表。

If you have a strategy, you should be able to link it directly to your P&L.

 

量身定制的选择贯穿宜家的价值链。而许多关于如何创造其独特价值形式的选择不仅与其竞争对手的选择不同，而且是不相容的——也就是说，竞争对手无法在不损害或破坏宜家为客户创造的价值的情况下复制宜家的做法。这些是真正的非此即彼的选择，使宜家能够实现其价值主张——低成本的优质设计。

Tailored choices pervade IKEA’s value chain. And many of those choices about how to create its distinctive form of value are not just different from the choices its rivals make. They are incompatible—that is, a rival couldn’t copy what IKEA does without compromising or damaging the value it creates for its customers. These are genuine either-or choices that allow IKEA to deliver on its value proposition—good design at low cost.

为什么会出现权衡？

Why Do Trade-offs Arise?

 

权衡取舍的原因有很多。波特强调了其中三个。首先，产品特性可能不兼容。也就是说，最能满足一组需求的产品在满足其他需求方面表现不佳。宜家的大型商店对那些想要快速“进出”购物的人来说是一场噩梦。宝马的“终极驾驶机器”无法满足寻求廉价基本交通工具的购车者的需求。麦当劳快速、廉价的汉堡包并不能满足那些想要健康、新鲜农场食材的本地美食爱好者的需求。

Trade-offs arise for a number of reasons. Porter highlights three. First, product features may be incompatible. That is, the product that best meets one set of needs performs poorly in addressing others. IKEA’s huge stores are a nightmare for those who want to make a quick “in and out” purchase. BMW’s “ultimate driving machine” does not serve the needs of car buyers looking for cheap, basic transportation. McDonald’s fast, cheap hamburgers are not very satisfying for locavores who want healthy, farm-fresh ingredients.

其次，活动本身可能存在权衡。换句话说，最能提供一种价值的活动配置不一定能同样好地提供另一种价值。可以肯定的是，设计用于处理小批量和定制产品的工厂在大批量生产或标准产品时效率会较低。每小时交付一次的物流系统并不是每周交付一次的最佳物流系统。等等。这样的权衡会产生经济后果。如果一项活动的设计过度或设计不足，其价值就会被破坏。如果你有幸在四季酒店享受过礼宾服务，你就会知道公司设计这项“活动”是为了向客人提供高水平的帮助。创造这种价值、雇用和培训合适的人员需要花钱。如果你把同样的礼宾员安排在一些客人几乎不需要帮助或不需要帮助的环境中，那么创造这种高水平服务所花费的部分成本就会被浪费。

Second, there may be trade-offs in activities themselves. In other words, the configuration of activities that best delivers one kind of value cannot equally well deliver another. You can bet that a plant designed to handle small lot sizes and custom products will be less efficient for large production runs or standard products. A logistical system geared to deliver once per hour is not the best one to deliver once per week. And so on. Trade-offs like these have economic consequences. If an activity is either overdesigned or underdesigned for its use, value will be destroyed. If you’ve had the pleasure of being served by a concierge at a Four Seasons hotel, you know that the company designs this “activity” to provide guests with a high level of assistance. It costs money to create this kind of value, hiring and training the right kind of person. If you put that same concierge in a setting where some guests require little or no assistance, then some of the cost that went into creating that high level of service would be wasted.

另一个需要权衡的因素是形象或声誉的不一致。例如，你能想象意大利跑车制造商法拉利推出一款小型货车吗？公司有时会因为扩张的热情而对形象的这种不一致视而不见。几十年来，零售商西尔斯 (Sears) 建立了购买优质工具和电器的声誉。当它收购经纪公司 Dean Witter 并试图销售投资产品和电锯时，客户无法将西尔斯的新形象与旧形象相协调。结果是企业扩张史上最惨痛的失败之一。在最好的情况下，这种不一致会让客户感到困惑。在最坏的情况下，它们会损害公司的信誉和声誉。

Another source of trade-offs is inconsistencies in image or reputation. Can you imagine, for example, the Italian sports car maker Ferrari introducing a minivan? Companies have occasionally been blinded to such inconsistencies in image by their zeal to expand. For decades, the retailer Sears built a reputation as the place to buy quality tools and appliances. When it acquired broker Dean Witter and tried to sell investment products as well as power saws, customers just couldn’t reconcile the new image of Sears with the old. The result was one of the more spectacular failures in the history of corporate expansion. At best, inconsistencies like these confuse customers. At worst, they undermine the company’s credibility and reputation.

因此，权衡利弊的产生有很多原因。它们在竞争中无处不在。它们通过创造选择的需求使战略成为可能。

Trade-offs, then, arise for many reasons. They are pervasive in competition. They make strategy possible by creating the need for choice.

成本/质量权衡：正确还是错误？

The Cost/Quality Trade-off: True or False?

 

“一分钱一分货”这句话概括了商业思维中最古老、最基本的权衡之一：要提高质量，就需要付出更高的成本；相反，如果削减成本，就会降低质量。这是一个显而易见的永恒真理……直到 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代的质量运动似乎证明这是错误的。这场运动的口号是“质量是免费的”，首先在日本扎根，然后传播到世界其他地方。一家又一家公司发现他们可以同时降低成本和提高质量。在许多人看来，一个基本的权衡可以被打破。

“You get what you pay for” is a phrase that captures one of the oldest and most fundamental trade-offs in business thinking: to create higher quality, you need to incur higher costs; conversely, if you cut costs, you will reduce quality. This was an obvious and eternal truth . . . until, that is, it was seemingly shown to be false by the quality movement in the 1980s and 1990s. That movement, with its rallying cry “Quality Is Free,” first took hold in Japan and then spread to the rest of the world. Company after company found that they could reduce costs and improve quality at the same time. It appeared to many that a fundamental trade-off could be broken.

你能同时拥有高质量和低成本吗？质量是免费的吗？波特称这是“危险的半真半假”。答案是“是的，但是”。是的，当更高的质量意味着消除缺陷和浪费时，质量是免费的。你正在处理一个错误的权衡，一个应该被打破的权衡。一般来说，当组织在运营效率方面落后时，就会出现错误的权衡——也就是说，当他们在执行基本活动方面落后时，这些活动是通用的，而不是针对战略的。因此，在 20 世纪 90 年代，雷克萨斯能够以更低的价格提供比凯迪拉克“更豪华”的汽车，因为通用汽车已经远远落后于当前的最佳实践。今天，在美国医疗保健领域，我相信有很大的机会同时改善医疗结果和降低成本，“质量是免费的”口号可能是一个有用的警钟。

Can you have high quality and low cost at the same time? Is quality free? Porter calls this a “dangerous half-truth.” The answer is “Yes, but.” Yes, quality is free when higher quality means eliminating defects and waste. There you are dealing with a false trade-off, one that should be broken. In general, false trade-offs arise when organizations fall behind in operational effectiveness—that is, when they lag in how well they perform basic activities, the kind of activities that are generic and not strategy specific. Thus, in the 1990s, Lexus was able to offer “more luxury” than Cadillac at a lower price because General Motors had fallen so far behind the current state of best practice. Today, in U.S. health care, where I believe there is great opportunity to improve medical outcomes and reduce costs at the same time, the slogan “Quality Is Free” might serve as a useful wake-up call.

创新也会出现，使旧的权衡取舍变得过时。新技术和新管理实践等创新可以降低成本并提高绩效。但只有当这些创新改变了游戏规则时——或者当一家公司的效率本来就落后时——质量才是真正的免费。

It is also the case that innovations come along and render old trade-offs obsolete. Innovations such as new technologies and new management practices can result in both lower cost and improved performance. But only when such innovations change the game—or when a company is lagging in efficiency to begin with—is it true that quality is free.

然而，一旦公司在执行方面取得一致，它们就会面临真正的权衡。那么，提高“质量”通常意味着增加新功能、使用更好的材料或提供更好的服务。例如，在乘用车中，这可能意味着将布座椅升级为皮革座椅，或增加全球定位系统。从这个意义上讲，质量绝对不是免费的。增加重要的产品功能、改善服务、提供更好的销售帮助或提供其他增强功能几乎总是需要花费更多。这里的权衡是真实的，具有约束力的。

Once companies achieve parity in execution, however, they face real trade-offs. Then, adding “quality” usually means adding new features, using better materials, or offering greater service. In a passenger car, for example, it might mean upgrading from cloth seats to leather, or adding a global positioning system. Quality in that sense of the word is definitely not free. It almost always costs more to add significant product features, improve service, provide better sales assistance, or deliver other enhancements. Here the trade-offs are real and binding.

让我们明确一点。这并不是说围绕低价建立的价值主张不能同时提供其他方面的客户价值。宜家的设计是一种特殊的品质，只要宜家控制原材料、制造和物流成本，它就恰好与低成本相一致。西南航空的便利性是另一种品质，也与低成本相一致。频繁的出发实际上增强了西南航空的成本优势，使其能够更好地利用飞机和地勤人员。而这些方便、频繁的出发本身就是通过许多低成本做法（不指定座位、不转运行李）实现的，这些做法使西南航空能够快速完成登机口周转。西南航空巧妙地强调了这种品质，将其做出的权衡变成了一种美德。然而，航空公司品质的其他方面——指定座位、更大的腿部空间、用瓷器盛放的餐食——都是要付出代价的。

Let’s be clear. This is not to say that a value proposition built around low price cannot simultaneously offer some other dimensions of customer value. IKEA’s design, one particular kind of quality, happens to be consistent with low costs as long as IKEA controls the costs of raw materials, manufacturing, and logistics. Southwest’s convenience, another kind of quality, is also consistent with low costs. Frequent departures actually enhance Southwest’s cost advantage, allowing for better utilization of planes and ground crews. And those convenient, frequent departures are themselves made possible by the many low-cost practices (no assigned seats, no baggage transfers) that allow Southwest to have fast gate turnarounds. Southwest cleverly stresses this type of quality, making a virtue of the trade-offs it has made. However, other dimensions of airline quality—an assigned seat, more legroom, a meal served on china—carry a real price tag.

当管理者专注于执行，专注于确保他们在一般活动方面符合“最佳实践”时，消除权衡可能是一件好事。然而，当谈到战略时，权衡对于让你做的事情与众不同至关重要。找到权衡——例如宜家对平板包装价值的洞察——对于制定战略至关重要。维持和强化权衡，使它们更加尖锐，对于维持战略至关重要。

When managers focus on execution, on making sure that they are “best practice” when it comes to generic activities, then eliminating trade-offs can be a good thing. When it comes to strategy, however, trade-offs are essential in making what you do unique. Finding trade-offs—IKEA’s insight about the value of flat packs, for example—is essential to creating strategy. Maintaining and steepening trade-offs, making them even sharper, is essential to sustaining strategy.

 

真正的权衡让模仿者望而却步

Real Trade-offs Keep Imitators at Bay

 

如果你成功了，而竞争对手也并未在转折点上掉以轻心，他们就会试图模仿你的做法。但权衡会阻碍他们。权衡的本质是让战略可持续的选择，因为它们不容易匹配或抵消。如果没有权衡，任何好的想法都可以被复制。产品功能可以复制。服务可以复制。传递价值的方式也可以复制。但只要有权衡，模仿者就会付出经济代价。

If you are successful and competitors aren’t asleep at the switch, they will try to copy what you do. But trade-offs will get in their way. By their very nature, trade-offs are choices that make strategies sustainable because they are not easy to match or to neutralize. If there are no trade-offs, any good idea can be copied. Product features can be copied. Services can be copied. Ways of delivering value can be copied. But where there are trade-offs, the copycat will pay an economic penalty.

不那么快餐

Not-So-Fast Food

 

麦当劳是快餐市场的领导者，其定位围绕速度和一致性。其价值链中的一切都是为实现这一价值主张而量身定制的。但在 20 世纪 90 年代末，麦当劳遇到了增长问题。在经历了一系列失败的产品发布和面临市场饱和之后，麦当劳决定与竞争对手汉堡王和温迪汉堡竞争，为顾客提供定制菜单选项（例如，不加泡菜的汉堡）。该公司推出了“为你量身定制”活动，其中包括斥巨资翻新所有餐厅的厨房。总费用估计接近 5 亿美元。

McDonald’s, a market leader in fast food, built its positioning around speed and consistency. Everything in its value chain is tailored to deliver that value proposition. But in the late 1990s, McDonald’s had a growth problem. Coming off a series of failed product launches and facing market saturation, McDonald’s decided that it needed to match rivals Burger King and Wendy’s by offering customers the option to customize their menu options (for example, a burger without the pickles). The company introduced its “Made for You” campaign, which involved expensive refurbishing of the kitchens at all its restaurants. The total bill was estimated at close to half a billion dollars.

但是“为您量身定制”也有其他代价。定制食品需要更多时间，定制程度越高，保持一致性就越困难。如果你开始认为这些结果（速度、一致性、定制）都需要权衡，那么你注意到了。定制程度越高，速度越慢，一致性越差。此外，在购买时准备每个订单使餐厅无法为繁忙的午餐时间备货。陷入困境的连锁店发现自己进退维谷：他们要么雇佣额外的员工来充实厨房，从而损失利润，要么冒险让顾客长时间等待。麦当劳从惨痛的经历中吸取了权衡的教训。它不能复制汉堡王的战略，否则就会搞砸自己的战略。

But “Made for You” came with other costs as well. Customized food preparation takes more time, and the greater the customization, the more difficult it is to achieve consistency. If you’re starting to think that each of these outcomes—speed, consistency, customization—involves trade-offs, you’re paying attention. More customization equals less speed and less consistency. Moreover, preparing each order at the time of purchase deprived restaurants of the ability to stock up for the busy lunch hour. Beleaguered franchises found themselves between a rock and a hard place: they could take a profit hit by hiring extra workers to staff the kitchens, or they could risk irritating customers with long waits. McDonald’s learned about trade-offs the hard way. It couldn’t copy Burger King’s strategy without messing up its own.

波特将麦当劳试图采取的做法称为“跨界”，这是最常见的竞争模仿形式。正如其名称所暗示的那样，跨界者试图在保持现有地位的同时，获得成功地位带来的好处。换句话说，跨界者试图拥有一切，通过将新功能、新服务或新技术嫁接到其已经开展的业务上，获得两个世界中最好的。战略是一个非此即彼的境界；跨界者认为它可以进入一个兼具两者的世界。这通常只是一厢情愿的想法。

Porter calls what McDonald’s tried to do straddling, and it is the most common form of competitive imitation. The straddler, as the word implies, tries to match the benefits of the successful position while at the same time maintaining its existing position. In other words, a straddler tries to have it all, to get the best of two worlds by grafting new features, services, or technologies onto the activities it already performs. Strategy is an either-or realm; the straddler thinks it can escape into a world of both-and. This usually turns out to be wishful thinking.

电影：直接上映还是零售上映

Movies: Direct Versus Retail

 

更常见的结果是像 Blockbuster 这样的案例。作为美国最大的录像带租赁店运营商，Blockbuster 受到 Netflix 日益成功的威胁，Netflix 的订户可以在线订购电影，然后通过邮寄送货上门，而且随着技术的发展，还可以直接下载。这是两个不同的价值主张，需要两条不同的价值链，需要进行重大的权衡。Netflix 拥有 50 多个地区仓库，辅以最先进的分销系统，可以提供比 Blockbuster 5,000 多家当地商店更广泛的电影库。Blockbuster 试图——但未能——同时实现两者，在自己的价值主张之上添加了 Netflix 的价值主张。权衡对试图同时以两种方式竞争的公司施加了真正的经济惩罚。

The more common outcomes are cases like Blockbuster. The largest operator of video rental stores in the United States, Blockbuster was threatened by the growing success of Netflix, whose subscribers ordered movies online for home delivery via mail, and, as the technology evolved, via direct download as well. These are two different value propositions requiring two different value chains, with significant trade-offs. Netflix’s 50-plus regional warehouses, backed by a state-of-the art distribution system, could supply a wider library of films than Blockbuster’s 5,000-plus local stores. Blockbuster tried—and failed—to have it both ways, adding Netflix’s value proposition on top of its own. Trade-offs impose real economic penalties for companies that try to compete in two ways at once.

跨越天空

Straddling in the Skies

 

当英国航空公司 (BA) 开始捍卫自己的地盘，抵御廉价航空公司的崛起时，它拥有后见之明的优势。最近，该行业发生了几起著名的跨界惨败，包括大陆航空试图在某些航线上提供全套服务，而在其他航线上提供低成本服务。同时以两种方式竞争被证明成本太高，也太复杂。

When British Airways (BA) set out to defend its turf against the rising tide of budget carriers, it had the advantage of hindsight. Most recently, there had been several notable straddling fiascos in the industry, including Continental Airlines’ attempt to be full service on some routes and low cost on others. Competing in two ways at once turned out to be too expensive and too complicated.

英国航空公司牢记这一教训：如果你要在同一家公司中占据两个不同的位置，那么绕过权衡的唯一方法就是创建一个独立的组织，让其自由选择自己的定制价值链。英国航空公司的经验表明，即使你这样做，也仍然很难实现。

British Airways took this lesson to heart: if you’re going to occupy two distinct positions in the same business, the only way to bypass the trade-offs is to create a separate organization with the freedom to choose its own, tailored value chain. BA’s experience shows that even when you do that, it is still a very hard act to pull off.

其新成立的子公司 Go Fly 被允许建立独立的身份，拥有自己的管理团队、品牌和航线网络。尽管如此，英航还是陷入了与美国同行相同的一些权衡之中，损害了其优质声誉，让客户感到困惑。Go Fly 最初的广告口号是“英国航空旗下的全新低成本航空公司”。Go Fly 选择的机场距离大城市较近，而瑞安航空等竞争对手的机场更拥挤，更容易出现延误。与大多数低票价航空公司不同的是，它为乘客分配座位，并将餐饮服务外包给高端餐饮公司。

Its new subsidiary, Go Fly, was allowed to establish an independent identity, with its own management team, branding, and route network. Nonetheless, BA got caught on some of the same trade-offs as its American counterparts, muddling its premium reputation and confusing customers. Go’s original advertising slogan was “the new low-cost airline from British Airways.” Go selected airports closer to major cities than competitors like Ryanair, airports that were more crowded and more prone to delays. Also unlike most low-fare airlines, it gave passengers seat assignments and contracted food service to a high-end catering outfit.

在亏损额超出预期后，英航认为经营一家廉价航空公司不符合其作为高端航空公司的定位。于是，英航将 Go 出售给了私募股权公司 3i。从英航手中解放出来后，Go 发起了一场针对英航客户的激进广告宣传活动。仅仅一年后，3i 就以收购价的四倍将规模更大的 Go 出售给了廉价竞争对手易捷航空。

After racking up somewhat-higher-than-expected losses, BA decided that running a low-cost airline was inconsistent with its positioning as a premium carrier. It sold Go to private equity firm 3i. Free from BA, Go launched an aggressive advertising campaign explicitly targeting BA customers. Only a year later, 3i was able to sell a larger Go to low-cost rival EasyJet at four times the price it had paid for the company.

权衡利弊让那些想要跨界的企业举步维艰。但跨界并不是一家公司抄袭另一家公司的唯一方式。重新定位是另一种方式。当一家公司现有的地位不再可行时，它可能会试图通过完全复制他人的战略来重新定位自己。这显然很难做到——你必须树立新的声誉和一套新的支持活动和技能，还必须拆除旧的。毫不奇怪，这种重新定位很少见，也应该如此。重新定位者实际上是选择与领先一步的竞争对手进行同一场竞赛。

Trade-offs make it tough for would-be straddlers. But straddling isn’t the only way one company can copy another. Repositioning is another. When a company’s existing position is no longer viable, it may try to reposition itself by copying someone else’s strategy in its entirety. This is obviously hard to do—you have to build a new reputation and a new set of supporting activities and skills, and you also have to dismantle the old. Not surprising, repositioning of this sort is rare, as well it should be. A repositioner effectively chooses to run the same race as a rival who has a giant head start.

家居装修：男性与女性

Home Improvement: Men Versus Women

 

当 Lowe's 意识到自己需要新的定位时，它选择了一条更具战略性的道路。家装零售业因家得宝 (Home Depot) 在 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代的巨大成功而闻名。家得宝最初的价值主张是：它为自己动手者（主要是男性）提供完成家居装修所需的材料和建议，而且价格低于当时雇用承包商或从五金店购买的替代方案。家得宝在平均面积超过 130,000 平方英尺的大型仓库式商店中提供最广泛的商品选择。其训练有素的员工（其中许多人以前是商人）提供建议并帮助购物者在大型商店中穿梭。该公司不仅吸引了自己动手者，也吸引了小型承包商。两者都被家得宝的商品种类和低廉的价格所吸引。

Lowe’s took a more strategic path when it recognized that it needed a new positioning. Home improvement retailing is a category made famous by the spectacular success of Home Depot in the 1980s and 1990s. Home Depot’s original value proposition was this: it offered do-it-yourselfers, mainly men, the materials and the advice they needed to accomplish home improvements at low prices relative to the existing alternatives of hiring a contractor or buying from hardware stores. Home Depot offered the widest selection of items in huge, warehouse-style stores that averaged over 130,000 square feet. Its well-trained associates, many of whom were former trades people, provided advice and helped shoppers navigate the huge stores. The company appealed not only to do-it-yourselfers but also to smaller contractors. Both were attracted to Home Depot’s merchandise assortment and low prices.

家得宝的价值主张如此吸引人，竞争优势如此巨大，以至于许多行业老牌企业（通常是门店面积在 20,000 到 30,000 平方英尺之间的区域性连锁店）被迫倒闭。到 1988 年，当时美国最大的 DIY 家居装修连锁店 Lowe's 已经看到了危机的迹象。如果没有新的战略，它将成为家得宝成功的又一个牺牲品。

Home Depot’s value proposition was so attractive, and its competitive advantage was so great, that many of the industry incumbents, typically regional chains with stores of between 20,000 and 30,000 square feet, were driven out of business. By 1988, Lowe’s, then the largest do-it-yourself home improvement chain in the United States, could see the handwriting on the wall. Without a new strategy, it would become another casualty of Home Depot’s success.

为了应对家得宝的低价策略，劳氏复制了家得宝的大型商店模式。但与此同时，劳氏发现了家得宝无法满足的需求，这成为其独特战略的基础。通过对数千名顾客的调查，劳氏了解到，女性，而不是男性，是大型家居装修项目的推动力，尤其是涉及设计和时尚的项目。这一洞察成为劳氏新价值主张的基础。

To address Home Depot’s lower prices, Lowe’s copied its larger store format. At the same time, however, Lowe’s discovered a need that Home Depot wasn’t meeting, which became the basis for a distinctive strategy. From surveying thousands of customers, Lowe’s learned that women, not men, are the driving force for major home improvement projects, especially those involving design and fashion. That insight became the basis for Lowe’s new value proposition.

专注于女性的需求导致产品组合和商品推销方面出现许多权衡。劳氏更注重家居时尚、厨房、草坪和花园、装饰品和消费电器——这与其对女性的吸引力相符。劳氏的目标是在普通商品上与家得宝保持价格竞争力，但提供更高比例的独特时尚商品，以获得更高的利润。

Concentrating on women’s needs gave rise to a number of trade-offs in product assortment and merchandising. Lowe’s places greater emphasis on home fashion, kitchen, lawn and garden, decorating items, and consumer appliances—in line with its appeal to women. Lowe’s aims to be price competitive with Home Depot on common items but to offer a higher proportion of unique and fashion items with better margins.

 

权衡是让战略可持续的选择，因为它们不容易匹配或中和。

Trade-offs are choices that make strategies sustainable because they are not easy to match or to neutralize.

 

劳氏没有像家得宝那样将商品堆放在托盘和货架上，而是将厨房、窗帘和其他物品摆放在家中。这种权衡虽然降低了空间利用率，但更适合其目标客户。劳氏商店摆脱了仓库氛围，拥有较低的天花板、更明亮的灯光和更吸引人的货架。为了使其商店形式符合其价值主张，劳氏做出了另一项重要的权衡：它通过一个拥有独立和不同设施的独立部门为承包商提供服务。

Instead of displaying piles of merchandise on palettes and racks, as Home Depot does, Lowe’s created displays of kitchens, window treatments, and other items as they would appear in the home. This trade-off was less space efficient, but better suited to its target customers. Moving away from the warehouse ambience, Lowe’s stores have lower ceilings, brighter lighting, and more attractive shelving. To keep its store format geared to its value proposition, Lowe’s has made another important trade-off: it serves contractors through a separate division with separate and different facilities.

由于这些关于商品组合和购物体验的决策，劳氏商店必须比家得宝更频繁地补货，而且补货数量更少——这是另一个会产生成本影响的重要权衡。每家公司都有自己独特的商店补货方式。关键在于，劳氏并没有试图抄袭家得宝的一切。它开辟了不同的定位，拥有不同的价值链。有些客户和需求更适合劳氏，有些则更适合家得宝。这两种战略之所以强大，是因为在实施过程中需要做出许多权衡。劳氏通过与家得宝不相容的选择实现了竞争优势，反之亦然。

As a result of these decisions about assortment and the shopping experience, Lowe’s stores must be restocked more frequently and in smaller quantities than Home Depot’s—another important trade-off that has cost consequences. Each company has its own tailored approach to replenishing merchandise for its stores. The point is that Lowe’s didn’t try to copy everything from Home Depot. It carved out a different positioning, with a different value chain. Some customers and needs are better served by Lowe’s. Some are better served by Home Depot. What makes both strategies robust are the many trade-offs required to carry them out. Lowe’s achieves its competitive advantage through choices that are incompatible with Home Depot’s, and vice versa.

21 世纪初期，Lowe's 从规模较小的基础起步，但销售额和收益增长更快。一些分析师迅速宣布 Lowe's 是“赢家”。在 Porter 看来，这正是破坏性的零和思维，当公司试图以独特性为竞争优势时，这种思维会阻碍公司的发展。当时，家得宝也遇到了一些业绩问题，但这些问题是由糟糕的门店执行力而不是糟糕的战略造成的。

In the early 2000s, Lowe’s, starting from a smaller base, grew faster in sales and earnings. Some analysts were quick to proclaim Lowe’s “the winner.” For Porter, this was precisely the kind of destructive, zero-sum thinking that gets in the way of companies when they try to compete on uniqueness. Home Depot was having some performance problems at the time, but those were caused by poor store execution, not by poor strategy.

劳氏非常聪明，抄袭了家得宝成功的一个要素，而这个要素对于该行业的任何人来说都至关重要，但它也非常聪明，确立了自己独特的定位。两家公司都有发展的空间，各自走自己的路。然而最近，家得宝一直在抄袭劳氏，例如，增加了玛莎·斯图尔特的家居装饰系列，以吸引女性。如果模仿过度，就会破坏关键的权衡，这种举动可能会破坏竞争优势。

Lowe’s was smart enough to copy the one element of Home Depot’s success that had become vital for anyone in that industry, but it was also smart enough to stake out its own unique positioning. There was room for both companies to thrive, each pursuing its own path. Yet more recently, Home Depot has been copying Lowe’s, adding, for example, a home décor line by Martha Stewart to appeal to women. Imitation that undermines key trade-offs—as this kind of move has the potential to do if carried too far—also undermines competitive advantage.

选择不该做的事情

Choosing What Not to Do

 

权衡利弊使得选择不做什么和选择做什么同样重要。决定满足哪些需求和提供哪些产品是制定战略的关键。但决定不满足哪些需求以及不提供哪些产品、功能或服务也同样重要。接下来是困难的部分——坚持这些决定。

Trade-offs make choices about what not to do as important as choices of what to do. Deciding which needs to serve and which products to offer is absolutely key to developing a strategy. But it is just as important to decide which needs you will not serve, and which products, features, or services you won’t offer. And then comes the hard part—sticking to those decisions.

公司往往会随着时间的推移为其产品添加功能和特性，希望这能扩大其客户群并增加销售额。“越多越好”的心理很难抗拒。导致功能蔓延的论点太熟悉了：添加一项功能的增量成本很小；我们需要收入增长；我们必须与竞争对手的产品相媲美；我们的客户告诉我们这就是他们想要的。（对于非营利组织来说，“使命蔓延”——为了取悦大捐赠者或员工而开展的偏离目标的项目——是类似的问题。）

Companies tend over time to add functions and features to their products, hoping this will broaden their customer base and increase sales. The “more is better” psychology is hard to resist. The arguments that lead to feature creep are all too familiar: the incremental cost of adding a feature is minimal; we need the revenue growth; we have to match what our rivals are offering; our customers are telling us this is what they want. (For nonprofits, “mission creep”—off-target projects undertaken to please big donors or staff—is the analogous problem.)

这是导致竞争者争相成为最好的滑坡。当你试图为每个人提供一些东西时，你往往会放松支撑你竞争优势的权衡。无论你在哪里找到一个多年来一直保持竞争优势的组织，你都可以肯定该公司已经抵御了无数次攻击，捍卫了其关键的权衡。

This is the slippery slope that leads to competition to be the best. When you try to offer something for everyone, you tend to relax the trade-offs that underpin your competitive advantage. Wherever you find an organization that has sustained its competitive advantage over a period of many years, you can be sure that company has defended its key trade-offs against numerous onslaughts.

 

当你尝试为每个人提供一些东西时，你往往会放松支撑你的竞争优势的权衡。

When you try to offer something for everyone, you tend to relax the trade-offs that underpin your competitive advantage.

 

这种冲击往往以席卷整个行业的新潮流的形式出现。20 世纪 50 年代，一波新技术浪潮——微波炉、速冻、人工调味料——改变了食品行业。In-N-Out Burger 是一家新鲜食品供应商，现做现卖，决定放弃最新的食品潮流。当麦当劳和其他公司转向冷冻牛肉饼时，哈里·斯奈德（In-N-Out 的创始人）却选择了相反的路线。他实际上雇佣了自己的屠夫来提供可靠的新鲜牛肉来源。

Often that onslaught takes the form of a new trend sweeping the industry. In the 1950s, a wave of new technology—microwaves, flash freezing, artificial flavorings—transformed the food industry. In-N-Out Burger, the purveyor of fresh food, freshly prepared, decided to take a pass on the latest food fads. As McDonald’s and others switched to frozen beef patties, Harry Snyder (In-N-Out’s founder) took the opposite fork in the road. He actually hired his own butcher to provide a reliable source of fresh beef.

20 世纪 90 年代末，几乎每家经纪公司都纷纷进军网上交易。没有人想落后。除了爱德华·琼斯 (Edward Jones)，也就是我们在第 4 章中描述的零售经纪公司。爱德华·琼斯制定了独特的战略，与中等收入的保守投资者建立长期关系，而这类客户往往被行业忽视。我们看到，爱德华·琼斯建立了一个密集的零售办事处网络，因为它选定的客户希望与个人进行面对面的交流，而不是在呼叫中心听到陌生的声音。除了个人关注之外，琼斯还明白，它的特定客户看重简单、保守的金融产品，以及稳定、低风险、买入并持有的投资方式。

In the late 1990s, nearly every brokerage firm rushed into online trading. No one wanted to be left behind. No one, that is, except Edward Jones, the retail brokerage we described in chapter 4. Edward Jones has built a distinct strategy around long-term relationships with conservative investors of modest means, a type of customer often ignored by the industry. We saw that Edward Jones built a dense network of retail offices because its chosen customer wants a face-to-face relationship with an individual, not an unfamiliar voice at a call center. Beyond personal attention, Jones understands that its particular customers value simple, conservative financial products combined with a steady, low-risk, buy-and-hold approach to investing.

在 20 世纪 90 年代的繁荣时期，行业和媒体以及琼斯自己的经纪人都对公司施加了巨大的压力，要求其增加互联网交易。琼斯的公司被批评落后于时代。但管理团队（琼斯是业内仅存的几位合伙人之一）坚持自己的立场，他们从波特那里学到了权衡的力量。尽管互联网交易被媒体誉为“下一个大事件”，但它与琼斯注重面对面关系和长期投资的理念完全不一致。

During the boom years of the 1990s, there was intense industry and media pressure—and pressure from Jones’s own brokers—to add Internet trading. The firm was criticized for being behind the times. But the management team (Jones is one of the last remaining partnerships in the industry) held its ground, having learned from Porter to appreciate the power of trade-offs. Internet trading, despite its media coronation as “the next big thing,” was completely inconsistent with Jones’s focus on face-to-face relationships and long-term investing.

如今，您可以访问爱德华琼斯公司的网站，您会发现一个标题为“当我们说不”的标签。它列出了爱德华琼斯公司不做的事情：它不为豪赌客和日内交易者提供服务。它不出售衍生品、大宗商品或低价股。它不提供网上交易，因为那“会鼓励草率决策”。它告诉潜在客户，它需要投资者，而不是赌徒。 这样的权衡从来都不是件容易的事。毫无疑问，爱德华琼斯公司放弃了赚钱的机会。但与此同时，它掌握了波特所说的竞争权衡的最大悖论之一。高管们往往不愿做出权衡，因为他们担心会失去一些客户。讽刺的是，除非他们做出权衡，并故意选择不服务所有客户和满足所有需求，否则他们不太可能很好地服务好任何客户和满足任何需求。

Today, you can go to the Edward Jones Web site and you will find a tab with the title “When We Say No.” It lays out what Edward Jones does not do: It doesn’t serve high rollers and day traders. It doesn’t sell derivatives, commodities, or penny stocks. It doesn’t offer online trading because that “encourages rash decision making.” It tells prospective clients it wants investors, not gamblers. Trade-offs like these are never easy. Make no mistake, Edward Jones has left money on the table. But at the same time, it has mastered what Porter calls one of the great paradoxes about trade-offs in competition. Executives often resist making trade-offs for fear they will lose some customers. The irony is that unless they make trade-offs and deliberately choose not to serve all customers and needs, then they are unlikely to do a good job of serving any customers and needs.

那么，明确自己不会做什么，就是成功完成自己选择的事情的最好方法。只有通过故意对某些需求不做出回应，通过接受战略权衡，公司才能真正响应其他需求。换句话说，权衡在战略中的作用是故意让一些顾客不高兴。西南航空公司讲述了一个精彩的故事，讲述了其传奇首席执行官赫伯·凯莱赫如何处理一位常旅客，她写了太多投诉信，他们称她为“笔友”。首先，想想西南航空战略中必不可少的许多权衡。没有指定座位。没有头等舱。没有餐食。除了 737 之外没有其他飞机。没有行李转运。等等。这位笔友抱怨西南航空的几乎每一个选择。在对她的多封信发出无数次礼貌的回复后，客户关系人员已经想不出主意了。他们问赫伯是否愿意回复。他很快就写了以下内容：

Clarity about what you won’t do, then, is the best way to succeed at what you do choose to do. It is only by being deliberately unresponsive to some needs, by embracing strategic trade-offs, that companies can be genuinely responsive to other needs. Put another way, the role of trade-offs in strategy is deliberately to make some customers unhappy. Southwest Airlines tells a great story of how its legendary CEO, Herb Kelleher, dealt with a very frequent flyer they called the “Pen Pal” because she wrote so many complaint letters. First, think about the many trade-offs essential to Southwest’s strategy. No assigned seats. No first class. No meals. No planes other than 737s. No baggage transfer. And so on. The Pen Pal complained about almost every choice Southwest makes. After sending numerous polite responses to her many letters, the customer relations people had run out of ideas. They asked Herb if he would reply. It didn’t take him long to write the following:

“亲爱的克拉巴普尔夫人，我们会想念您的。爱你的，赫伯。”

“Dear Mrs. Crabapple, We will miss you. Love, Herb.”

赫伯·凯莱赫的故事往往很有趣，但通常也很有教育意义。建立和维持竞争优势意味着你必须有纪律地拒绝一系列会削弱你独特性的举措。顾客永远是对的观念是那些可能导致业绩平庸的半真半假观念之一。权衡利弊解释了为什么你不应该满足每个顾客的需求。有些顾客不是你的顾客，你应该打发他们走，最好是带着凯莱赫天生的才华和幽默感。

Herb Kelleher stories are often entertaining, but they are usually instructive as well. Building and sustaining competitive advantage means that you must be disciplined about saying no to a host of initiatives that would blur your uniqueness. The notion that the customer is always right is one of those half-truths that can lead to mediocre performance. Trade-offs explain why it is not true that you should give every customer what he or she wants. Some of those customers are not your customers, and you should send them packing, ideally with the same flair and humor that came naturally to Kelleher.

或者，正如波特所说：“战略就是在竞争中做出权衡。战略的本质是选择不做什么。”

Or, as Porter puts it, “Strategy is making trade-offs in competing. The essence of strategy is choosing what not to do.”

第六章

CHAPTER 6

 

合身：

Fit:

 

放大器

The Amplifier

 

本章讨论战略的第四个测试，即波特所说的“契合度”。契合度与价值链中各项活动的相互关系有关。它在战略中的作用凸显了另一个常见的误解，即竞争成功可以用一项核心竞争力来解释，即你做得非常好的一件事。这里的谬误是，好的战略并不依赖于一件事，也不依赖于做出一个选择。它们通常也不是一系列独立选择的结果。好的战略取决于许多事物之间的联系，取决于做出相互依赖的选择。

THIS CHAPTER ADDRESSES THE fourth test of strategy, something Porter calls “fit.” Fit has to do with how the activities in the value chain relate to one another. Its role in strategy highlights yet another popular misconception, that competitive success can be explained by one core competence, the one thing you do really well. The fallacy here is that good strategies don’t rely on just one thing, on making one choice. Nor do they typically result from even a series of independent choices. Good strategies depend on the connection among many things, on making interdependent choices.

 

好的策略取决于许多事物之间的联系以及相互依存的选择。

Good strategies depend on the connection among many things, on making interdependent choices.

 

在第 4 章中，我们了解到，一系列关于公司价值主张及其价值链的选择会产生竞争优势。如果这些选择涉及权衡，那么该战略就会变得更有价值，也更难模仿（第 5 章）。你可以将契合度视为放大器，它能提高这两种效应的强度。契合度通过降低成本或提高客户价值（和价格）来放大战略的竞争优势。契合度还通过提高模仿壁垒使战略更具可持续性。

We saw, in chapter 4, that a series of choices about a company’s value proposition and its value chain gives rise to competitive advantage. Where those choices involve trade-offs, the strategy becomes more valuable and more difficult to imitate (chapter 5). You can think of fit as an amplifier, raising the power of both of those effects. Fit amplifies the competitive advantage of a strategy by lowering costs or raising customer value (and price). Fit also makes a strategy more sustainable by raising barriers to imitation.

从某种程度上来说，契合度的概念完全是直觉的。每位总经理都知道协调企业竞争所需的各个职能领域的重要性和难度。让营销、生产、服务和信息技术 (IT) 等领域都朝着同一个方向发展通常说起来容易做起来难，尤其是在大型组织中。但波特发现了比协调更重要的东西。契合度在竞争中发挥的作用比大多数人意识到的更大、更复杂。

At one level, the idea of fit is completely intuitive. Every general manger knows the importance—and the difficulty—of aligning the various functional areas needed to compete in a business. Getting areas like marketing, production, service, and information technology (IT) all pulling in the same direction is usually easier said than done, especially in large organizations. But Porter has uncovered something even more substantial than alignment. Fit plays a larger and more complex role in competition than most realize.

什么是适合？

What Is Fit?

 

在第 4 章中，我们探讨了公司开展的活动与其价值主张之间的关系。在这里，我们的重点是这些活动之间的相互关系。让我们来看看宜家众多量身定制的活动中的一些：

In chapter 4 we explored how the activities a company performs relate to its value proposition. Here our focus is how those same activities relate to each other. Let’s look at just a dozen of IKEA’s many tailored activity choices:

 
  1. 产品设计师网络（控制产品开发）
  2. Network of product designers (controlled product development)
    3.  
  3. 集中管理的全球供应链（外包制造）
  4. Centrally managed global supply chain (outsourced manufacturing)
    5.  
  5. 大型商店
  6. Huge stores
    7.  
  7. 商店附属的仓库（商店布局中的最后一站）
  8. Warehouse attached to stores (the last stop in the store layout)
    9.  
  9. 靠近高速公路的郊区
  10. Suburban locations with easy highway access
    11.  
  11. 充足的免费停车位
  12. Ample free parking
    13.  
  13. 展厅内没有销售人员
  14. No sales associates on the showroom floor
    15.  
  15. 全室装修产品展示
  16. Fully decorated full-room product displays
    17.  
  17. 每件商品上都有大型信息吊牌（包括价格、尺寸、材料）
  18. Large informational hang-tags on every item (with price, dimensions, materials)
    19.  
  19. 扁平包装的物品（产品组装和交付“外包”给客户）
  20. Items in flat packs (product assembly and delivery “outsourced” to customers)
    21.  
  21. 店内餐厅
  22. In-store cafeterias
    23.  
  23. 店内儿童看护/游戏室
  24. In-store childcare/playroom
    25.  
 

正如我们在第 5 章中看到的，平板包装在宜家的竞争优势中发挥着重要作用，因为它们降低了运输和产品损坏的成本。因此，作为一种独立的选择，平板包装支持宜家的低价定位。郊区商店的位置降低了成本，因为城市范围以外的土地更便宜。但这两种选择当然是相互依存的。这些平板包装的价值因汽车友好型位置而放大，这些位置使客户更容易将购买的商品装入汽车。

Flat packs, as we saw in chapter 5, play a big role in IKEA’s competitive advantage because they lower the costs of shipping and product damage. So as an independent choice, flat packs support IKEA’s low-price positioning. Suburban store locations lower costs because land is cheaper outside the city limits. But these two choices are, of course, interdependent. The value of those flat packs is amplified by the car-friendly locations that make it easier for customers to load their purchases into their cars.

看看这些活动，你会看到许多此类契合示例。大型商店放大了全球规模产品采购的价值。如果顾客愿意每次光临花费更多时间，大型商店的价值就会更高。免费托儿服务和店内餐厅让顾客可以慢慢享用（如果你喜欢瑞典肉丸，甚至会感到愉快）。每种选择都会提升其他选择的价值。所有这些都有助于降低顾客价格。大型商店的形式为宜家提供了空间，可在装饰齐全的房间展示所有商品。这些，加上大型的产品信息吊牌，让宜家无需销售助理 — — 这是另一种成本节约，因为一项活动会影响另一项活动的价值。事实上，这是一个很好的工作定义：契合意味着一项活动的价值或成本受到其他活动开展方式的影响。

Go down the list of activities and you will see many such examples of fit. Huge stores amplify the value of global-scale product sourcing. Huge stores are more valuable if customers are willing to spend more time per visit. The free childcare and the in-house cafeteria make it possible (and even enjoyable, if you like Swedish meatballs) for customers to take their time. Each of these choices enhances the value of the others. All contribute to lower prices for customers. The huge store format gives IKEA space to showcase all its merchandise in fully decorated room displays. These, along with the large product information hang-tags, allow IKEA to do without sales associates—another cost saving that arises because one activity impacts the value of another. That, in fact, is a good working definition: fit means that the value or cost of one activity is affected by the way other activities are performed.

 

适合意味着一项活动的价值或成本受到其他活动执行方式的影响。

Fit means that the value or cost of one activity is affected by the way other activities are performed.

 

您需要有车才能享受宜家的价值体系。相比之下，如果您在时尚零售商 Zara 购物，您可能步行即可到达。Zara 是西班牙集团 Inditex（Industria de Diseño Textil，SA）的一部分，该集团是全球收入最高的服装零售商。Zara 的商店位于人流量很大的城市中心的显眼位置。它打造了一个如此热门的时尚品牌，以至于大多数法国女性都认为这家西班牙公司一定是法国公司。

You need a car to benefit from IKEA’s value system. In contrast, if you shop at the fashion retailer Zara, you probably arrive on foot. Zara is part of the Spanish group Inditex (Industria de Diseño Textil, S.A.), the world’s largest clothing retailer by revenue. Zara’s stores are prominently located in urban centers with heavy foot traffic. It has built such a hot fashion brand that most French women think this Spanish company must be French.

Zara 以适中的价格出售最新时尚的服装（不是绝对价格低，而是相对于时尚品牌而言价格低）。其如何实现这一特定价值主张的关键洞察力在于速度。Zara 所做的一切都是为了快速将最新款式送达其商店。大多数时尚零售商可以接受三个月的交货时间。Zara 的交货时间仅为两到四周，每年可以发布一百个系列。

Zara sells the latest-fashion clothes at moderate prices (not low in absolute terms, but low relative to fashion brands). Its key insight into how to deliver that particular value proposition is speed. Everything Zara does is tailored to getting the latest styles into its stores fast. Most fashion retailers can live with lead times of three months. Zara’s are just two to four weeks, allowing it to release one hundred collections per year.

这种快速发展的速度是可能的，因为 Zara 控制着整个价值链，并且其在整个价值链上的选择与竞争对手不同。Zara 做出了一些重大的权衡——在如何推广其品牌、如何设计其商品以及如何管理生产、物流和库存方面。Zara 的成功并非来自单一选择，而是来自这些选择如何相互配合、相互促进。

This blistering pace is possible because Zara controls its value chain from end to end, and its choices all along the value chain are different from its rivals. Zara makes some significant trade-offs—in how it promotes its brand, how it designs its merchandise, and how it manages production, logistics, and inventory. Zara’s success comes not from one choice, but from the way these many choices fit together to reinforce each other.

可以将 Zara 视为一个完美设计的系统，旨在优化其独特价值主张的传递。我说“优化”是因为如果你逐一看一下 Zara 所做的事情，你会发现它的某些选择会令你大吃一惊。例如，考虑到 Zara 的相对低价定位，它的某些选择可能看起来并不划算。其庞大的设计团队规模是另一家热门欧洲时装零售商 H&M 的两倍。与竞争对手不同，Zara 自己进行制造，而且大部分在欧洲而不是亚洲进行。它的商店位于城里租金最高的地区。这些选择本身都不是“低成本”解决方案。但当你退后一步，将整个系统视为一个系统时，你就会意识到，为了优化整体，Zara 愿意在某个方面做出次优选择。

Think of Zara as a system perfectly designed to optimize the delivery of its distinctive value proposition. I say “optimize” because if you look at what Zara does, piece by piece, some of the choices will surprise you. Some of its choices, for example, may not seem cost effective given Zara’s low relative price positioning. Its large design team is twice the size of H&M’s, another hot European fashion retailer. Unlike its rivals, Zara does its own manufacturing, and most of it is done in Europe, not Asia. Its stores are located in the highest-rent districts in town. None of these choices is, by itself, the “low cost” solution. But when you step back and look at the whole, as a system, you realize that Zara is willing to make a suboptimal choice in one area in order to optimize the whole.

那么 Zara 是如何做到的呢？让我们看看这个拼图的各个部分是如何组合在一起的。首先，设计师的作用是发现趋势并加以模仿。该公司不是花大价钱聘请大牌设计师来创造新的东西，而是在世界各地派出星探，在秀场和夜总会寻找最新的时尚潮流。其庞大的内部设计师团队可以在不到一个月的时间内创造出一个新系列，并可以在几周内修改现有的系列。团队规模使 Zara 能够快速复制，迅速将这些新设计投入生产。

So how does Zara do it? Let’s see how the pieces of this puzzle all fit together. First, the role of the designers is to spot trends and copy them. Rather than pay big-name designers big bucks to create something new, the company has scouts around the world looking for the latest fashion trends at shows and in nightclubs. Its large team of in-house designers can create a new collection in under a month and can modify existing collections in a couple of weeks. The size of the team allows Zara to be a fast copier, getting those new designs into production quickly.

Zara 最初并非零售商，而是制造商。它秉承自己的初衷，继续在内部、欧洲和为小批量生产而配置的工厂中完成大量生产。Zara 拥有一支卡车车队，可在 24 小时或更短的时间内将货物从其位于西班牙的集中物流中心快速运送到其遍布欧洲的门店。而且，与行业惯例相反，服装到达时会贴上标签并挂起来。这虽然增加了运输成本，但意味着商品到达时已准备好出售，无需在店内熨烫。速度才是主题。

Zara began not as a retailer but as a manufacturer, and true to its roots it continues to do a sizeable amount of production in-house, in Europe, and in plants configured for small-batch production. Zara owns a fleet of trucks to speed goods from its centralized logistics hubs in Spain to its stores throughout Europe in twenty-four hours or less. And, again counter to industry practice, garments arrive ticketed and hung. This raises shipping costs but means the merchandise arrives ready to sell, needing no in-store ironing. Speed is the theme.

商店本身位于人流量大的显眼位置，空间宽敞。但每周两次的新品供应有限，这传达了一个明确的信息：立即购买，否则将失去机会。店员不断反馈哪些商品畅销，哪些商品不畅销，这些信息有助于 Zara 就设计和生产量做出更好的实时决策。

The stores themselves—in prominent locations with high foot traffic—are spacious. But the new goods that come twice a week arrive in limited supply, sending a clear message: buy it now or lose the opportunity. Store personnel provide constant feedback about what’s selling and what isn’t, information that helps Zara make better real-time decisions about design and production volumes.

现在想想顾客体验：源源不断的新商品，加上作为商店广告牌的引人注目的商店，再加上商品稀缺。这引起了轰动。顾客和朋友谈论 Zara。他们不断回来，因为他们知道选择会有所不同，当他们走过商店时，他们可以看到不断变化的商品。

Now think about the customer experience: the steady flow of new merchandise combined with eye-catching stores that serve as billboards for the store combined with a scarcity of goods. This generates buzz. Customers talk about Zara with their friends. They keep coming back because they know the selection will be different, and they can see the changing merchandise as they walk past the stores.

所有这些因素加在一起，造就了 Zara 的卓越业绩和竞争优势。您从 Zara 的财务状况中看到了哪些优势？举个例子。Zara 的顾客比同类商店的顾客购物更频繁，而且他们以全价购买的商品更多。根据我几年前看到的数据，Zara 的商品降价幅度约为 10%，而行业平均降价幅度为 17% 至 20%。在零售业，这是一个巨大的优势。而且 Zara 的降价优势并非单一选择的结果。例如，这不仅仅是因为其销售人员做出了更明智的购买决策。这是构成 Zara“系统”的众多选择的结果。

All of this adds up to produce Zara’s superior results, its competitive advantage. Where in Zara’s financials do you see that advantage? Here’s one example. Zara’s customers shop more often than customers of comparable stores, and they buy more merchandise at full price. According to data I saw a few years ago, Zara was marking down about 10 percent of items versus the industry average of 17 to 20 percent. In retailing, that’s a huge advantage. And Zara’s markdown advantage is not the result of one choice. It is not simply that its merchandisers make smarter buying decisions, for example. It is the result of many choices that make up Zara’s “system.”

这是 Zara 的优势如何影响其损益表的另一个例子。大多数时尚品牌都是由大量广告预算建立和支持的（该类别的广告支出平均约占销售额的 3% 至 4%）。H&M 的广告支出约为 5%。相比之下，沃尔玛等百货零售商在广告上的支出不到其收入的三分之一。但一旦你考虑了 Zara 活动选择的契合度，你就不会惊讶地发现 Zara 的广告支出与沃尔玛的水平相当。Zara 在门店选址上花费更多，但在广告上几乎没有花费。它的众多选择结合起来激发了顾客的热情，而无需大量营销支出。

Here’s another example of how Zara’s advantage hits its P&L. Most fashion brands are built and supported by a substantial advertising budget (ad spending for the category averages about 3 to 4 percent of sales). Ad spending at H&M has been about 5 percent. In contrast, a general merchandise retailer such as Walmart spends less than one-third of one percent of its revenue on advertising. But once you think about the implications of the fit across Zara’s activity choices, you won’t be surprised to learn that Zara’s ad spending has been right down there at Walmart’s level. Zara spends more on store locations, but almost nothing on advertising. Its many choices combine to generate customer enthusiasm without the aid of heavy spending on marketing.

Fit 的工作原理

How Fit Works

 

契合度有多种表现形式，但在实际操作中，它们之间的区别往往很模糊。波特列出的三种契合度类型对竞争优势的影响方式略有不同。

Fit can take a number of forms, although the distinctions among them are often blurred in practice. Each of the three types Porter identifies works in a slightly different way to affect competitive advantage.

第一种契合是基本一致性，即每项活动都与公司的价值主张相一致，并且每项活动都对其主导主题做出增量贡献。想想对 Zara 的成功至关重要的速度。在价值链的每一步，Zara 都对其活动进行了配置，以确保每项活动都花费比它需要的时间更长的时间：其设计团队的配置可以快速响应；其工厂位于附近；其自己的卡车车队确保快速交货；其在 IT 方面的投资加快了设计和制造之间的沟通。每项活动都为 Zara 的速度做出了贡献。Zara 通过了基本一致性测试。

The first kind of fit is basic consistency, where each activity is aligned with the company’s value proposition and each contributes incrementally to its dominant themes. Think about the speed that is critical to Zara’s success. At every step in the value chain, Zara has configured its activities so that nothing takes longer than it needs to: its design teams are configured for rapid response; its plants are located nearby; its own fleet of trucks ensures rapid delivery; its investments in IT speed communications between design and manufacturing. Each activity contributes to Zara’s speed. Zara passes the basic consistency test.

当活动不一致时，它们会相互抵消。我的一个客户希望将自己定位为一家低成本的袜子供应商，为主要的折扣店提供服务。在其工厂经理试图削减成本的同时，销售部门允许甚至鼓励各种规模的零售客户订购需要定制生产的独一无二的颜色。这些“独一无二的颜色”并不是你想象的那样。例如，白色有数百种变化，每种都需要独特的染料配方。工厂必须按大于客户订单数量的批次生产。结果导致库存过剩，这些袜子首尾相连，可以绕地球一圈。（以下是“数字”促使公司采取行动的一个例子。）这不是第一家，也不会是最后一家在销售和制造之间挣扎的公司。用数学的方式表达，一致性意味着 1 + 1 + 1 = 3，而不是小于 3 的某个数字。不一致的活动会使整体小于部分之和。

When activities are inconsistent, they cancel each other out. A client of mine wanted to position itself to be a low-cost provider of socks to the leading discounters. At the same time that its plant managers were trying to cut costs, sales was allowing—even encouraging—its retail customers of all sizes to order one-of-a-kind colors that required customized production. These “one-of-a-kind colors” weren’t what you’d think. For example, there were literally hundreds of variations on the color white, each requiring a unique dye formula. The plant had to produce in batches larger than the customers’ order quantities. The result was so much excess inventory that, laid end to end, the socks would have circled the globe. (Here’s an example where “the numbers” jolted the company into action.) This wasn’t the first company, nor will it be the last, to struggle with the alignment between sales and manufacturing. Expressed mathematically, consistency means that 1 + 1 + 1 = 3, and not some number less than 3. Inconsistent activities make the whole less than the sum of the parts.

第二种契合发生在活动相互补充或强化时。这是真正的协同效应，每项活动的价值都会因另一项活动而提升。Zara 的店铺人流量大，产品系列数量众多，相互强化。高知名度的店铺有助于 Zara 实现每两周更新店铺所有商品的目标。大型展示窗就像灯塔一样吸引顾客。

A second type of fit occurs when activities complement or reinforce each other. This is real synergy, where the value of each activity is raised by the other. Zara’s high-traffic store locations and the large number of collections reinforce each other. The high-visibility locations help Zara with its goal of turning over all of a store’s merchandise every two weeks. Large display windows are like a beacon drawing customers in.

或者想想 Netflix 为其会员提供庞大的电影库（最初通过在地区仓库存放 DVD 库存；现在越来越多地通过数字发行）。它还维护着一个蓬勃发展的用户生成的电影评级系统，到 2010 年，该系统已产生超过 10 亿条评级。“我们试图解决的真正问题，”首席执行官里德·哈斯廷斯 (Reed Hastings) 解释说，“是如何改变电影选择，以便消费者能够找到他们喜欢的稳定电影流？这是一个巨大的匹配问题。我们这里有 55,000 个 DVD 标题。那里有 3 亿美国人。但大多数人无法告诉你他们渴望看的十部电影。”评级和庞大的电影库是互补的：评论帮助会员拓宽他们的观影品味，从而使大型电影库更有价值。

Or consider that Netflix offers its members access to an enormous library of films (initially by holding inventory of DVDs at regional warehouses; increasingly through digital distribution). It also maintains a thriving, user-generated movie-rating system that by 2010 had produced over a billion ratings. “The real problem we’re trying to solve,” explains CEO Reed Hastings, “is how do you transform movie selection so that consumers can find a steady stream of movies they love? It’s a huge matching problem. We’ve got 55,000 DVD titles over here. There are 300 million Americans over there. But most people can’t tell you ten movies they’re dying to see.” The ratings and the huge library are complementary: the reviews help members to broaden their movie-watching tastes, thereby making the large film library more valuable.

家得宝提供了另一个活动如何相互促进的例子。家得宝的基本价值主张有三个支柱：大量选择、每日低价和专业服务。以前没有人把这些都结合在一起。大型仓储店模式对于提供选择和低价至关重要。但如果没有优质的服务，顾客在仓储店会感到迷失。

Home Depot provides another example of how activities reinforce each other. The basic Home Depot value proposition has three legs: huge selection, everyday low prices, and knowledgeable service. Nobody before had put these all together. The large warehouse store format was essential to offering both selection and low prices. But without excellent service, customers would have felt lost in the warehouse stores.

20 世纪 70 年代末，创始人伯尼·马库斯 (Bernie Marcus) 和亚瑟·布兰克 (Arthur Blank) 聘请了知识渊博的员工（这在当时是一个激进的想法），并给他们丰厚的报酬，培养了客户服务的虔诚。例如，当顾客询问在哪里可以找到某件商品时，家得宝 (Home Depot) 的员工会接受培训，陪同顾客走到正确的过道。据说马库斯曾告诉他的员工，如果他发现他们指指点点而不是陪同顾客，他会“砍掉他们的手指”。家得宝的店铺规模和服务相辅相成。没有服务，规模就行不通。

In the late 1970s, founders Bernie Marcus and Arthur Blank hired knowledgeable employees—at the time a radical notion—paid them well, and cultivated a religion of customer service. When customers asked where they could find a given item, for example, Home Depot employees were trained to walk with the customer to the correct aisle. Marcus is reputed to have told his employees that if he caught them pointing instead of accompanying the customer, he would “rip their finger off.” Store size and service reinforced each other at Home Depot. Without the service, the size would not have worked.

将家得宝与宜家进行比较和对比是很有意思的。两家公司都使用大型商店来支持低价定位，但家得宝的定位和产品种类使个性化服务成为必需品，而宜家则使个性化服务变得无关紧要。在每种情况下，权衡和价值链的契合都是特定于战略的。

It’s interesting to compare and contrast Home Depot with IKEA. Both used large-format stores to support a low-price positioning, but while Home Depot’s positioning and product variety made personal service a necessity, IKEA’s made it irrelevant. In each case, the tradeoffs and the fit across the value chain are strategy specific.

波特的第三种匹配类型是替代。在这种匹配中，完成一项活动可以消除另一项活动。宜家的全屋展示和产品吊牌替代了销售人员。Zara 的显眼店址和其产品系列的快速更新使传统广告变得毫无必要。越来越多的公司学会了与供应商或客户合作，或两者兼而有之，以优化公司之间的工作。例如，对于大型企业客户，戴尔会将定制软件安装到新电脑上。戴尔可以在组装过程中比客户的 IT 部门更快、更便宜地完成这项工作，因为客户的 IT 部门必须在电脑交付后逐台安装软件。这种替代降低了总成本，使戴尔可以与客户分享部分节省的成本。因此，替代有助于优化公司的价值链。

Porter’s third type of fit is substitution. Here performing one activity makes it possible to eliminate another. IKEA’s full-room displays and product hang-tags substitute for sales associates. Zara’s prominent store locations and the rapid turnover of its collections make traditional advertising unnecessary. Increasingly, companies have learned to cooperate with suppliers or customers or both in order to optimize efforts across company boundaries. For its large business customers, for example, Dell will load customized software onto new PCs. Dell can do this faster and cheaper during the assembly process than a customer’s IT department, which would have to load the software machine by machine after the PCs have been delivered. This substitution lowers the total cost, allowing Dell to share some of the savings with its customers. Substitution, then, works to optimize a company’s value chain.

这三种类型的契合都很常见，而且它们经常重叠。在拥有良好战略的公司中，契合往往既普遍又复杂。

All three types of fit are common, and they often overlap. In companies with good strategies, fit tends to be both pervasive and complex.

映射你的活动系统

Mapping Your Activity System

 

波特创建了一种他称之为“活动系统图”的工具，用于绘制公司的重要活动及其与价值主张以及彼此之间的关系。

Porter has created a tool he calls an “activity system map” to chart a company’s significant activities, their relationship to the value proposition, and to each other.

你可以先确定价值主张的核心要素。对于宜家，我会强调三个：独特的设计、低廉的价格和即时使用。

You can start by identifying the core elements of the value proposition. For IKEA, I would highlight three: distinctive design, low prices, and immediate use.

然后，您可以确定企业中最突出的活动，即最有助于创造客户价值的活动或产生重大成本的活动。尝试列出每一步的独特活动选择。这使得公司与其竞争对手之间的对比更加明显。例如，即使粗略地看一下宜家的价值链与传统家具店的价值链，也会发现其独特的店内服务和配送配置。

You then identify the most salient activities performed in the business, those most responsible for creating customer value or those that generate significant cost. Try to list the unique activity choices at each step. This makes contrasts between the company and its competitors more obvious. For instance, even a cursory glance at IKEA’s value chain compared with that of a traditional furniture store would highlight its unique configuration of in-store service and delivery.

接下来，按照下图所示将活动放在地图上。在合适的地方画线——活动对价值主张的贡献以及两个活动相互影响的地方。在宜家地图上，平板包装有助于降低价格和立即使用。它们影响客户的自行交付。等等。如果你全面绘制宜家的活动，你最终会得到一个非常密集和纠结的网络。对于战略来说，这是一件好事。相反，连接稀疏的地图可能表明该战略很弱。

Next, place activities on the map as shown in the following figure. Draw lines wherever there is fit—where an activity contributes to the value proposition and where two activities affect each other. On the IKEA map, flat packs contribute to low prices and immediate use. They affect self-delivery by customers. And so on. Were you to fully map IKEA’s activities, you’d end up with an extremely dense and tangled web. For strategy, this is a good thing. Conversely, a map with sparse connections likely signals that the strategy is weak.

 

 

宜家的活动地图

IKEA’s activity map

 

 

 

活动图可以帮助你了解每项活动对整体定位的支持程度——服务的客户、满足的需求、相对价格。对于每项活动，都要思考如何才能更好地与整体战略联系起来，即使是订单处理或物流等活动，这些活动可能看起来基本上是通用的。波特观察到，在大多数组织中，有些活动的协调性被忽视了，因为它们不被视为战略的一部分。

An activity map can help you see how well each activity supports the overall positioning—the customers served, the needs met, the relative price. For each activity, ask how it could be better linked to the overall strategy, even activities such as order processing or logistics that might seem to be largely generic in character. In most organizations, Porter observes, there are activities whose alignment has been ignored because they were not seen as part of strategy.

活动图可以帮助您确定增强契合度的方法。负责每项活动的经理通常可以告诉您他们的绩效是否受到其他活动的影响。他们可能还对如何改善活动之间的契合度有自己的想法。超越基本的一致性。您能否找到新的方式，让活动相互加强或一项活动可以替代其他活动？

An activity map can help you identify ways to strengthen fit. Managers responsible for each activity can usually tell you whether their performance is impaired by other activities. They may also have ideas about how to improve the fit across activities. Look beyond basic consistency. Can you find new ways in which activities can reinforce each other or where one activity can substitute for others?

活动图还可能激发创造力，使战略更具可持续性。您能否找到新的活动或对现有活动的改进，这些活动或改进的成本或效率是否可以通过现有活动系统得到改善？您是否可以提供（而竞争对手无法提供的）服务、功能或产品种类，这是由于您已经开展了其他活动？竞争对手最难模仿的就是这些扩展。

An activity map might also spur creativity about how to make a strategy more sustainable. Can you find new activities, or enhancements to what you already do, whose cost or effectiveness is improved by your existing activity system? Are there services, features, or product varieties that you can offer (and rivals cannot) because of the other things that you already do? Extensions like these will be the hardest for rivals to imitate.

 

契合度和核心竞争力

Fit and Core Competence

 

波特认为，适配性为战略的一个基本问题提供了新的见解：竞争优势从何而来？许多公司在寻找竞争优势时，重点关注的是所谓的关键资源、核心能力或关键成功因素。尽管这些术语之间存在技术差异，但管理者通常将它们混用，并将它们统称为核心竞争力。所有这些术语都反映了一个相似的观点：竞争优势来自少数因素，无论是无形技能还是硬资产。因此，竞争之道就是获取和发展这些核心竞争力。

Fit, as Porter conceives of it, sheds new light on a fundamental question of strategy: Where does competitive advantage come from? In many companies, the search for competitive advantage focuses on what are variously called critical resources, core capabilities, or key success factors. Although there are technical differences among these terms, managers generally use them interchangeably and lump them together under the umbrella term core competence. All reflect a similar point of view: that competitive advantage comes from a small number of factors, be they intangible skills or hard assets. The way to compete, then, is to acquire and develop those core competences.

制定战略时，一个常见的错误就是选择与行业内其他人相同的核心竞争力。例如，如果你认为只有少数几样东西对竞争至关重要，那么你就会争先恐后地抢占这些宝贵资源。整个行业都一窝蜂地想要控制一项“战略”资源 — — 例如，现有客户群（例如，手机用户）、分销渠道（例如，电视台或有线电视系统、股票经纪人）或产品组合（例如，电影库） — — 从而抬高了这些资源的成本。在 1999-2000 年间，AT&T 以 1,300 亿美元收购了有线电视公司 TCI、MediaOne 和 Cablevision 的部分业务。仅仅两年后，这些资产就以 440 亿美元的价格卖给了康卡斯特。糟糕。不难看出这种竞争方式会导致什么结果：模仿、竞争趋同、零和竞争，只为争第一。

A common mistake in strategy is to choose the same core competences as everyone else in your industry. If, for example, you believe that only a few things matter to competition, then you will race to acquire those valuable things before your rivals do. Entire industries have rushed headlong to control a “strategic” resource—for example, an installed base of customers (e.g., cellular subscribers), distribution channels (e.g., television stations or cable systems, stock brokers), or product portfolios (e.g., film libraries)—driving up the costs of those resources. In this vein, AT&T acquired the cable companies TCI, MediaOne, and part of Cablevision for $130 billion in 1999–2000. Just two years later, these assets were sold to Comcast for $44 billion. Oops. It is not hard to see where this approach to competition leads: imitation, competitive convergence, zero-sum competition to be the best.

 

战略中的一个常见错误是选择与行业中其他人相同的核心竞争力。

A common mistake in strategy is to choose the same core competences as everyone else in your industry.

 

契合意味着整体比单个部分更重要，许多因素共同创造价值，而不仅仅是几个独立的因素。例如，是什么导致了Zara的成功？是Zara的时尚天赋？是其灵活的欧洲制造？是其门店位置？还是其物流方式？答案并不在于一两项核心竞争力。答案在于Zara所有价值创造活动之间的契合。Zara的战略涉及一系列同时做出的选择。Zara的成功取决于整个相互依存的活动系统，而不仅仅是一两个强大的部分。它不仅来自于Zara在配置其活动时所做的权衡，也来自于这些活动之间的相互影响。

Fit means that the whole matters more than any individual part, that many things together create value, not just a few things in isolation. What, for example, accounts for Zara’s success? Is it Zara’s flair for fashion? Its flexible European manufacturing? Its store locations? Its approach to logistics? The answer isn’t to be found in one or two core competences. The answer lies in the fit among all of Zara’s value-creating activities. Zara’s strategy involves a series of choices made simultaneously. Zara’s success depends on a whole system of interdependent activities, not just one or two powerful parts. It comes not only from the trade-offs Zara has made in configuring its activities but also from the way those activities impact each other.

契合意味着，单个活动的竞争价值（以及相关技能、能力或资源）不能脱离系统或战略。无论是西南航空还是 Zara、家得宝还是 Lowe's、Enterprise 还是 Zipcar、In-N-Out Burger 还是麦当劳、爱德华·琼斯还是 Netflix，价值不仅仅来自“核心竞争力”，还来自它们在公司定位中的部署方式。

Fit means that the competitive value of individual activities—and the associated skills, competences, or resources—cannot be decoupled from the system or the strategy. Whether it is Southwest or Zara, Home Depot or Lowe’s, Enterprise or Zipcar, In-N-Out Burger or McDonald’s, Edward Jones or Netflix, value comes not from “core competences” alone, but from how they are deployed in the company’s positioning.

保留核心业务，外包其余业务？不要着急

Keep the Core, Outsource the Rest? Not So Fast

 

你的核心竞争力是什么？如果你问的是这个问题，那么你是不是不太可能关注定制、权衡和契合？如果竞争中只有少数几件事很重要，那么很多事情就根本不重要了。核心竞争力的逻辑导致许多公司在没有考虑战略后果的情况下追求外包。标准论点是公司应该专注于核心活动。那些不是“核心”的业务可以外包给更高效的供应商。

What is your core competence? And if that’s the question you are asking about your own organization, aren’t you less likely to be paying attention to tailoring, trade-offs, and fit? If just a few things matter in competition, then many things don’t matter at all. The logic of core competences has led many companies to pursue outsourcing without thinking through the strategic consequences. The standard argument has been that companies should focus on their core activities. Those that aren’t “core” can be outsourced to more efficient providers.

但一旦你认识到了契合度的作用，你就会停下来，更认真地思考外包问题。波特不再试图确定哪些活动是核心活动，而是提出了一个不同的问题：哪些活动是通用的，哪些活动是定制的？通用活动（即那些无法根据公司定位进行有意义的定制的活动）可以安全地外包给更高效的外部供应商。然而，波特认为，对于那些已经或可以根据战略进行定制的活动，尤其是那些与其他活动具有很强互补性的活动，外包是有风险的。公司价值链中剩余的要素越少，扩展定制、权衡和契合的机会就越少。

But once you appreciate the role of fit, you will stop and think much harder about outsourcing. Instead of trying to determine which activities are core, Porter asks a different question: Which activities are generic and which are tailored? Generic activities—those that cannot be meaningfully tailored to a company’s position—can be safely outsourced to more efficient external suppliers. However, Porter argues that outsourcing is risky for activities that are or could be tailored to strategy, and especially for those activities that are strongly complementary with others. The fewer elements that remain in the company’s value chain, the fewer the opportunities to extend tailoring, trade-offs, and fit.

最初的外包决策几乎总能带来短期成本节约，但其对成本和竞争融合的长期影响却令人担忧。外包不仅会限制公司实现独特性和适应公司战略的机会，还会使整个行业变得更加同质化。

The initial outsourcing decision almost always results in short-term cost savings, but the longer-term implications for both cost and competitive convergence are troubling. Outsourcing can not only limit the opportunities for uniqueness and fit in the company’s strategy but also push an entire industry into greater homogenization.

 

契合使战略更具可持续性

Fit Makes Strategy More Sustainable

 

契合不仅能通过提高价值或降低成本来扩大竞争优势，还能使这种优势更具可持续性。我们在第 5 章中看到，权衡利弊使竞争对手很难复制成功的战略。契合则更难。为了获得模仿的好处，你现在必须复制一整套相互依赖的活动。

Fit not only amplifies competitive advantage by enhancing value or lowering costs, but also makes that advantage more sustainable. We saw in chapter 5 that trade-offs make it hard for rivals to copy a successful strategy. Fit makes it even harder. To get the benefit of imitation, you now have to copy a whole nest of interdependent activities.

波特认为，契合可以从多方面阻止模仿。首先，竞争对手很难搞清楚他们要模仿什么。如果你想复制 Zara，你到底要复制什么？它的产品设计方法？商店配置？它的制造业务？它的卡车车队？竞争对手可能很容易辨别基本的一致性，但一家公司的定位越依赖于复杂的契合，竞争对手就越难知道他们到底想复制什么。除非你是内部人士，否则很难弄清楚到底发生了什么。

Porter argues that fit deters imitation in a number of ways. First, rivals will have a hard time figuring out what they have to match. If you wanted to copy Zara, what exactly would you copy? Its approach to product design? The store configurations? Its manufacturing operations? Its fleet of trucks? Basic consistency may be readily discerned by rivals, but the more a company’s positioning rests on complex fit, the harder it is for rivals to know exactly what it is they are trying to copy. Unless you’re an insider, it’s very difficult to untangle what’s going on.

其次，即使竞争对手能够找到相关的关联，他们也很难复制所有这些关联，因为匹配对组织而言是一项挑战。复制产品功能或特定的销售团队方法是一回事。匹配整个活动系统则是另一回事，这通常需要跨工作组、部门和职能整合决策和行动。

Second, even if rivals can identify the relevant interconnections, they will have a hard time replicating all of them because fit is organizationally challenging. It’s one thing to copy product features or a particular sales-force approach. It’s another to match a whole system of activities, something that typically requires the integration of decisions and actions across work groups, departments, and functions.

通过在模仿者面前设置多重障碍，契合度降低了策略被复制的几率。为了具体说明这一点，波特使用了一个简单的数学论证。假设你匹配任何一项活动的概率为 90%。如果你必须匹配一个包含两项活动的系统，那么成功概率为 81%（0.9 × 0.9）。如果有四项活动，成功概率下降到 66%（0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9）。依此类推。

By throwing multiple obstacles in the path of would-be imitators, fit lowers the odds that a strategy can be copied. To make this concrete, Porter uses a simple mathematical argument. Let’s assume you have a 90 percent probability of matching any one activity. If you then have to match a system with two activities, your probability of success is 81 percent (0.9 × 0.9). If there are four activities, your probability of success drops to 66 percent (0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9). And so on.

 

通过在模仿者的道路上设置多重障碍，适配降低了策略被复制的可能性。

By throwing multiple obstacles in the path of would-be imitators, fit lowers the odds that a strategy can be copied.

 

现在想想，有人成功复制宜家或 Zara 的可能性有多大。一旦你将战略视为一个相互关联的选择系统（图 6-1），你就能理解概率如何迅速累积，从而使一个好的战略具有可持续性。此外，由于契合度降低了成功模仿的概率，因此它提高了失败的惩罚，因为这些活动是相互关联的。一个方面的小小不足可能会在其他地方产生连锁反应，正如我们在英国航空公司失败的低成本航空公司 Go 身上看到的那样。

Now think about how likely it is that someone can successfully copy IKEA or Zara. Once you see strategy as a system of interconnected choices (figure 6-1), you can grasp how quickly the probabilities compound to make a good strategy sustainable. Moreover, as fit lowers the probability of successful imitation, it raises the penalty for failure precisely because the activities are interconnected. A small shortfall in one can produce ripple effects elsewhere, as we saw with British Airway’s failed low-cost carrier, Go.

图 6-1

FIGURE 6-1

Zara 的相互关联选择

Zara’s interconnected choices

 

最后一点有一个微妙的推论。波特观察到，具有高度契合度的公司通常在战略和执行方面都更胜一筹，因此它们一开始就不太可能吸引模仿者。为什么？当活动相互影响时，其中一项的缺陷将损害整体绩效。这往往会凸显弱点，使它们更有可能得到解决。这也意味着解决运营不足有更大的好处，而且往往有更大的压力。这类公司由此产生的实力是阻止模仿的另一个因素。

There is a subtle corollary to this last point. Porter observes that companies with strong fit are typically superior in both strategy and execution, and thus they are less likely to attract imitators in the first place. Why? When activities affect each other, flaws in one will impair overall performance. This tends to shine a spotlight on weaknesses, making it more likely they will be addressed. It also means there is more upside in addressing operational shortfalls, and often more pressure to do so. The resulting strength of companies like these is another deterrent to imitation.
