在第 4 章中，我们看到量身定制的价值链（不同的活动）是抵御模仿的第一道防线。在第 5 章中，我们看到权衡构成了第二道防线。量身定制和权衡可防止现有竞争对手通过跨界或重新定位来复制良好的战略。竞争对手需要重新配置的活动越多，他们对当前地位造成的损害就越大。最后，契合度解释了如何保持竞争优势以对抗新进入者，即使是最坚定的新进入者。在争夺最佳地位的竞争中，模仿很容易，优势也是暂时的。一家公司在独特性方面的竞争越激烈，就越不容易受到模仿，优势可以长期保持。伟大的战略就像复杂的系统，其中所有部分都天衣无缝地结合在一起。你做的每一件事都会放大你做的其他事情的价值。这增强了竞争优势。它也增强了可持续性。“契合度”，波特说，“通过创建一个与最强环节一样强大的链条，将模仿者拒之门外。”

In chapter 4 we saw that a tailored value chain—different activities—was the first line of defense against imitation. In chapter 5, we saw that trade-offs constitute a second line of defense. Tailoring and trade-offs prevent existing rivals from copying a good strategy, either by straddling or repositioning. The more activities rivals have to reconfigure, the more damage they will do to their current positions. Finally, fit explains how competitive advantage can be sustained against new entrants, even the most determined of them. In competing to be the best, imitation is easy, and advantages are temporary. The more a company competes on uniqueness, the less susceptible it is to imitation, and advantages can be sustained over long periods of time. Great strategies are like complex systems in which all of the parts fit together seamlessly. Each thing you do amplifies the value of the other things you do. That enhances competitive advantage. And it enhances sustainability as well. “Fit,” Porter says, “locks out imitators by creating a chain that is as strong as its strongest link.”

第7章

CHAPTER 7

 

连续性：

Continuity:

 

推动者

The Enabler

 

现在我们来谈谈战略的第五个也是最后一个测试：持续的连续性。回顾一下：前两个测试——独特的价值主张和量身定制的价值链——是战略的核心。第三个测试“权衡”是经济关键。它们使价格和成本差异成为可能并可持续。第四个测试“契合度”是一个放大器，它增强了成本和价格差异，而这些差异是竞争优势的本质，使竞争对手更难复制该战略。连续性是推动因素。战略的所有其他要素——量身定制、权衡、契合度——都需要时间来发展。没有连续性，组织一开始就不可能发展竞争优势。

WE COME NOW TO the fifth and final test of strategy: continuity over time. To recap: the first two tests—a unique value proposition and a tailored value chain—are the core of a strategy. Trade-offs, the third test, are the economic linchpin. They make differences in price and cost possible and sustainable. Fit, the fourth test, is an amplifier, enhancing the cost and price differences that are the essence of competitive advantage, and making it even harder for rivals to copy the strategy. Continuity is the enabler. All the other elements of strategy—tailoring, trade-offs, fit—take time to develop. Without continuity, organizations are unlikely to develop competitive advantage in the first place.

图 7-1

FIGURE 7-1

良好战略的五项测试

The five tests of a good strategy

 

这一代商界领袖一直专注于变革。他们被灌输了关于如何应对不断加快的变革步伐、如何克服变革阻力、如何领导大规模变革工作等建议。许多针对管理者的变革文献都是激励性的。它们旨在激励组织。但它产生了一种过分夸张的言论，可能会破坏良好的战略。现在，每一项变革都被称为“颠覆性的”，无论其影响有多慢或多突然，多浅或多深。想想你听到“不断重塑”和“彻底变革”这些短语的频率。

This generation of business leaders has been preoccupied with change. It has been flooded with advice about how to deal with the accelerating pace of change, how to overcome resistance to change, how to lead large-scale change efforts, and so on. A lot of the change literature aimed at managers is motivational. It’s about firing up the organization. But it has produced an overheated rhetoric that can undermine good strategy. Now, every change is referred to as “disruptive,” no matter how slow or sudden, how shallow or deep its impact might be. Think about how often you hear the phrases “constant reinvention” and “radical transformation.”

是的，竞争是动态的，而不是静态的，公司经营的舞台也在不断变化。客户的需求在变化。新的竞争对手出现。旧技术不断发展，新技术不断涌现。应对变化是战略的重要组成部分。每个人都能举出曾经引以为豪的公司因未能看到变革的必要性或未能有效实施变革而陷入低谷的例子。

Yes, competition is dynamic, not static, and the arena in which companies operate is constantly changing. Customers’ needs shift. New competitors emerge. Old technologies evolve and new ones are created. Dealing with change is an essential part of strategy. Everyone can come up with examples of once-proud companies brought low either by their failure to see the need for change or to execute it effectively.

但连续性，尽管听起来平淡无奇，也是必不可少的。虽然人们更关注的是那些变化太少的公司，但波特却强调了一个同样甚至更大的错误：公司可能会改变太多，而且改变的方式不对。他认为，制定战略——做出选择、确定界限——并不会削弱你改变的能力。它实际上促进了正确的创新。

But continuity, as pedestrian as it sounds, is also essential. Whereas the spotlight is more often directed at companies that change too little, Porter highlights an equal, if not greater, mistake: companies can change too much, and in the wrong ways. And, he argues, having a strategy—making choices, defining limits—doesn’t impair your ability to change. It actually facilitates the right kind of innovation.

为何连续性至关重要？

Why Is Continuity Essential?

 

正如我们所见，战略涉及组织对市场的态度的各个方面。它本质上是复杂的。想想需要什么才能理解和服务你的客户，为他们创造真正的价值。想想你的组织与供应商和合作伙伴之间的联系。想想你执行的数百项活动，以及这些活动必须如何与你的价值主张和彼此保持一致。然后记住，所有这些都涉及到参与和协调数百甚至数十万从事这项工作的个人的行动。

As we’ve seen, strategy involves all aspects of an organization’s approach to the market. It is inherently complex. Think about what it takes to understand and serve your customers, to create real value for them. Think about the links between your organization and its suppliers and its partners. Think about the hundreds of activities you perform, and how these must be aligned with your value proposition and with each other. And then remember that all of this involves engaging and aligning the actions of hundreds or even hundreds of thousands of individuals who do the work.

请允许我打一个烹饪的比喻：战略不是炒菜，而是炖菜。需要时间来形成味道和口感。随着时间的推移，随着公司的所有成员（内部和外部）对公司能为他们提供什么或他们能为公司提供什么有了更深入的了解，一系列活动将变得更适合战略，并更好地相互协调。战略的这一方面从根本上讲与人及其吸收和处理变化的能力有关。考虑一下连续性如何实现竞争优势：

Allow me one cooking metaphor: strategy isn’t a stir fry; it’s a stew. It takes time for the flavors and textures to develop. Over time, as all of a company’s constituents—internal and external—come to a deeper understanding of what a company can offer them, or what they can offer to it, a whole raft of activities become better tailored to the strategy and better aligned with each other. This aspect of strategy is very fundamentally about people and their capacity to absorb and process change. Consider how continuity enables competitive advantage:

 
  • 连续性强化了公司的身份——它建立了公司的品牌、声誉和客户关系。这一原则在 In-N-Out Burger 得到了很好的体现，它是当今过度活跃、时髦的商业文化中的异类。该公司以其老式菜单（新鲜牛肉、真正的土豆、奶昔中的真正冰淇淋）和老式价值观（像家人一样对待员工）而自豪。它的狂热忠诚客户吹嘘他们愿意为 In-N-Out 解决多远的麻烦，或者当新店开业时他们愿意排队等待多长时间。该公司的网站恰到好处地表达了这一观点：“尽管时代变了，但 In-N-Out 几乎没有什么变化。”今天，你会发现“客户自 1948 年以来一直享受的东西。”

    宝马、宜家或迪士尼的变化要大得多，但客户永远不会误解这些公司的立场，他们能满足什么需求，不能满足什么需求。换句话说，他们了解核心价值主张和主要的权衡。一个好的战略，通过与客户的反复互动，长期保持一致，是品牌的力量所在。

  • Continuity reinforces a company’s identity—it builds a company’s brand, its reputation, and its customer relationships. This principle is well understood at In-N-Out Burger, an outlier in today’s hyperactive, hipper-than-thou business culture. The company is proud of its old-fashioned menu (fresh beef, real potatoes, real ice cream in the shakes) and its old-fashioned values (treat employees like family). Its fanatically loyal customers brag about how far they’re willing to drive for their In-N-Out fix, or how long they’ll wait in line when a new location opens. The company Web site strikes exactly the right note: “Though times have changed, little has changed at In-N-Out.” You’ll find today exactly what “customers have enjoyed since 1948.”

    There has been far more change at BMW or IKEA or Disney, but customers will never mistake what these companies stand for, what needs they can and cannot meet. In other words, they understand the core value proposition and the major trade-offs. A good strategy, consistently maintained over time through repeated interactions with customers, is what gives power to a brand.

    •  
  • 连续性有助于供应商、渠道和其他外部各方为公司的竞争优势做出贡献。这全都与协调和量身定制有关。例如，战略的连续性使戴尔在 20 世纪 90 年代和 21 世纪初能够与能够更好地适应其需求的关键供应商建立富有成效的关系。在戴尔的鼓励下，德克萨斯州奥斯汀成为数百家供应商的所在地，这些供应商在附近共同设立仓库和生产基地。由此形成的相关公司集群包括半导体和电子产品制造商、软件公司以及技术咨询和服务公司。（集群在竞争中发挥着特殊作用。有关这方面的更多信息，请参阅词汇表。）外部各方与公司合作的时间越长，他们就越能了解公司的目标和方法。

    互利互惠。持续经营使瑞士食品巨头雀巢公司得以在印度发展一个蓬勃发展的当地农民供应基地，为其牛奶业务提供保障。从 20 世纪 60 年代开始，雀巢公司只有 180 名农民，后来建造了冷藏牛奶场作为牛奶收集点。随着时间的推移，雀巢公司为农民提供技术援助、培训和供应，农民因此变得更加高效（和富裕）。与雀巢合作的农民数量已增长到 75,000 多人。

    战略的连续性在劳动力市场（另一个供应来源）中产生了类似的好处，使 Enterprise 和西南航空等公司能够吸引符合公司战略的员工。它还促进了与分销渠道的关系，而这需要时间来建立。当丰田推出其高端汽车雷克萨斯时，它投入巨资并历时多年来建立其经销商网络。如果丰田不长期致力于这一战略，那么这项投资就没有什么意义。

  • Continuity helps suppliers, channels, and other outside parties to contribute to a company’s competitive advantage. This is all about alignment and tailoring. Continuity of strategy, for example, allowed Dell in the 1990s and early 2000s to establish productive relationships with key suppliers that could better adapt to its needs. Austin, Texas, became home to hundreds of suppliers encouraged by Dell to co-locate warehouses and production nearby. The resulting cluster of related companies included manufacturers of semiconductors and electronics, software companies, and technology consulting and services firms. (Clusters play a special role in competition. See the glossary for more on this.) The longer outside parties work with a company, the better they understand its goals and methods.

    The benefits can flow both ways. Continuity has enabled the Swiss food giant Nestlé to develop a thriving supply base of local farmers for its milk business in India. Starting in the 1960s with just 180 farmers, Nestlé built refrigerated dairies as collection points for milk. Over time it provided technical assistance, training, and supplies to the farmers, who have become vastly more productive (and prosperous) as a result. The number of farmers working with Nestlé has grown to over 75,000.

    Continuity of strategy produces similar benefits in the labor market, another source of supply, allowing companies such as Enterprise and Southwest Airlines to attract employees who fit the company’s strategy. It also fosters relationships with distribution channels, which take time to develop. When Toyota launched its premium auto, the Lexus, it invested heavily, and over many years, to create its dealer network. If Toyota weren’t committed to this strategy for the long term, the investment would not have made much sense.

    •  
  • 连续性促进了个体活动的改进，并适应了各种活动；它使组织能够根据其战略建立独特的能力和技能。例如，阿拉文眼科医院的战略连续性使其能够为自己的员工制定定制的培训计划，以及为整个印度增加熟练眼科护理提供者的供应量。今天，阿拉文眼科医院的“课程”非常广泛，从眼科医生的住院医师计划到仪器维护技术人员的非临床课程。或者看看西南航空和四季酒店，这两家公司以其独特的服务风格而闻名。多年来，每家公司都磨练了自己的招聘实践。每家公司都能更有效地筛选出具有与公司战略相符的技能和态度的员工。正是通过这种方式，随着时间的推移，对战略的持续追求使公司能够开发出一系列难以匹敌的战略特定资产（包括其文化）。

    连续性增加了整个组织中人们理解公司战略以及他们如何为之做出贡献的可能性。他们“理解得越多”，就越有可能做出强化和延伸战略的决策。管理者将更有可能协调那些原本互不相容的活动。这里要强调的一点是，技能开发和协调很少能在一夜之间发生。

  • Continuity fosters improvements in individual activities and fit across activities; it allows an organization to build unique capabilities and skills tailored to its strategy. The continuity of strategy at Aravind Eye Hospital, for example, allowed it to develop customized training programs for its own staff, as well as courses to increase the supply of skilled eye care providers for India at large. Today Aravind’s “curriculum” is extensive, ranging from residency programs for ophthalmologists to nonclinical courses for technicians in instrument maintenance. Or consider Southwest Airlines and Four Seasons Hotels, two companies distinguished by their unique styles of service. Over many years, each has honed its hiring practices. Each can screen more effectively for employees with the skills and attitudes that fit the company’s strategy. It is in this way that consistent pursuit of a strategy over time allows a company to develop a whole raft of strategy-specific assets—including its culture—that become hard to match.

    Continuity increases the odds that people throughout the organization will understand the company’s strategy and how they can contribute to it. The more they “get it,” the more likely they are to make decisions that reinforce and extend the strategy. Managers will be more likely to align activities that had been working at cross-purposes. The point to underscore here is that skill development and alignment rarely happen overnight.

    •  
 

正是因为连续性的价值，公司为频繁的战略转变付出了高昂的代价。这需要重新配置活动并重新调整整个系统。必须让客户和价值链合作伙伴重新了解公司现在正在做的事情，这通常意味着对品牌和形象进行大量再投资。举个例子，西尔斯从 20 世纪 80 年代开始，从一个战略跳到另一个战略，让客户对公司的立场感到困惑。多年来，西尔斯一直以工具和电器销售商而闻名，它首先试图成为金融服务提供商，然后成为时装零售商，然后以“从股票到袜子”这个不切实际的口号成为一站式购物体验。西尔斯从一个计划跳到另一个计划，从“未来商店”到“每天低价”，再到“品牌中心”，再到“西尔斯的柔和一面”和“伟大的室内空间”。正如西尔斯的一位经理所说，“我们从公司那里得到了好主意…… “每个想法都会出现、动摇、消失，六个月后又会出现另一个想法。过了一段时间，我们就不再相信这些想法了。”

For the very same reasons that continuity is valuable, companies pay a high price for frequent shifts in strategy. These require reconfiguration of activities and realigning entire systems. Customers and value chain partners have to be reeducated about what the company is now trying to do, which typically means heavy reinvestments in brand and image. To cite one example, Sears, beginning in the 1980s, jumped from one strategy du jour to another, confusing its customers about what the company stood for. Known for many years as a seller of tools and appliances, it tried to become, first, a financial services provider, then a fashion retailer, and then a one-stop shopping experience under the implausible slogan “From Stocks to Socks.” Sears lurched from one initiative to another, from “The Store of the Future” to “Everyday Low Pricing” to “Brand Central” to “The Softer Side of Sears” and “The Great Indoors.” As one Sears manager put it, “We got good ideas from corporate . . . Each idea would come, falter, and go, and in six months there would be another idea. After a while we stopped believing in the ideas.”

成功实施一项新战略通常需要数年而不是数月的时间。想想“一个福特”，这是福特汽车公司在首席执行官艾伦·穆拉利领导下重新定位的代名词。2006 年，当福特从波音公司聘请穆拉利时，该公司已经苦苦挣扎了几十年。穆拉利放弃了前任们组建的“品牌家族”，出售了捷豹、路虎、阿斯顿马丁和沃尔沃。穆拉利专注于福特品牌，将重点从卡车和 SUV 转移到更小、更环保的乘用车。他还认为，全球客户的需求和品味正在趋同——为某个市场专门设计汽车将越来越不合理。2012 款福克斯是该公司第一款真正的全球性汽车。

It usually takes years, not months, to successfully implement a new strategy. Think about “One Ford,” the name given to Ford Motor Company’s repositioning under CEO Alan Mulally. Ford had been floundering for decades by the time it hired him from Boeing in 2006. Mulally dropped the “house of brands” assembled by his predecessors, selling off Jaguar, Land Rover, Aston Martin, and Volvo. Focusing on the Ford badge, Mulally is shifting the emphasis from trucks and SUVs to smaller, more environmentally friendly passenger cars. He is also betting that the needs and tastes of customers around the globe are converging—that it will make less and less sense to design cars specifically for one market or another. The 2012 Focus is the company’s first truly global car.

现在想想，对于一家拥有 20 万名员工的公司来说，这样的战略转变意味着什么。随着新结构、新系统和新流程的建立，旧的做事方式必须被废除和摒弃。产品开发必须彻底改革。生产能力必须降低。劳动协议必须重新谈判。营销需要改革。这个过程已经进行了四年，穆拉利估计，福特 80% 的产品将再花三年时间在全球平台上生产。

Now think about what a strategy shift like this involves for a company with 200,000 employees. Old ways of doing things had to be dismantled and unlearned as new structures, systems, and processes were put in place. Product development had to be overhauled. Production capacity had to be reduced. Labor agreements had to be renegotiated. Marketing needed to be revamped. Four years into the process, Mulally estimates it will take another three years for 80 percent of Ford’s products to be built on global platforms.

管理挑战是巨大的。回想一下波特对为什么复制战略可能产生不尽人意的结果所做的简单数学解释：当每项活动都正确的概率小于 1 时，四五项活动都正确的概率会迅速下降（0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 = 0.59）。同样的逻辑解释了为什么频繁改变战略可能会严重拖累业绩。有些活动、实践、技能或态度永远无法赶上新战略。

The managerial challenge is enormous. Recall Porter’s simple mathematical explanation of why copying a strategy is likely to produce less-than-stellar results: when the probabilities of getting each activity right are less than 1, the probability of getting four or five things right quickly deteriorates (0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9 = 0.59). The same logic explains why frequent shifts in strategy are likely to be a significant drag on performance. Some activities, practices, skills, or attitudes will never catch up with the new strategy.

连续性涉及什么？

What Does Continuity Involve?

 

战略的连续性并不意味着组织应该停滞不前。只要核心价值主张保持稳定，那么在实现核心价值主张的方式上就可以而且应该进行巨大的创新。事实上，成功的公司很少需要自我改造，因为他们会不断重塑自己的方法。他们不断改进自己的工作。他们不断寻找创造更多价值、扩大蛋糕的方法。

Continuity of strategy does not mean that an organization should stand still. As long as there is stability in the core value proposition, there can, and should, be enormous innovation in how it’s delivered. In fact, successful companies rarely have to reinvent themselves because they are constantly reinventing their methods. They keep getting better at what they do. They keep searching for ways to create more value, to make the pie bigger.

 

战略的连续性并不意味着组织应该停滞不前。只要核心价值主张保持稳定，那么在实现战略的方式上就可以（也应该）进行巨大的创新。

Continuity of strategy does not mean that an organization should stand still. As long as there is stability in the core value proposition, there can, and should, be enormous innovation in how it’s delivered.

 

1850 年，保罗·朱利叶斯·路透 (Paul Julius Reuter) 发现了一种巧妙的方法，可以快速向市场参与者传递全球金融信息。他的新技术就是信鸽。路透创立的公司至今仍然存在，尽管信鸽被一系列技术创新所取代，从电报开始，到互联网。路透社继续满足人们对快速获取金融市场信息的持久需求，尽管如今它所开展的业务与 150 多年前大不相同。

In 1850, Paul Julius Reuter found an ingenious way to speed the delivery of global financial information to market participants. His new technology was the carrier pigeon. The company Reuter founded survives to this day, although the pigeons gave way to a series of technological innovations, beginning with the telegraph and culminating in the Internet. Reuters continues to serve the enduring need for rapid information about financial markets, albeit with a very different set of activities today than it used more than 150 years ago.

看看今天的印度阿拉文眼科医院，你会看到一个提供全方位眼科护理服务的大型综合组织。它与当地社区领袖和服务团体合作，开办免费眼科筛查营，这是一种外展机制，每年为农村 230 多万患者提供护理和教育。1992 年，随着阿拉文眼科医院的手术量不断扩大，它开始向后整合生产镜片，这是其最昂贵的供应品之一。其制造部门 Aurolab 生产人工晶状体以及眼科手术中使用的其他消耗品。1976 年，阿拉文眼科医院成立之初非常简陋，只有 3 名医生和 11 张床位，此后，其规模和范围都发生了巨大变化，但它始终致力于满足人们对平价眼科护理的持久需求。

Look at India’s Aravind Eye Hospital today and you will see a large, complex organization that offers a full range of eye care services. It partners with local community leaders and service groups to run free screening eye camps, an outreach mechanism that brings care and education to over 2.3 million patients a year in rural villages. In 1992, as Aravind’s volume of surgeries had grown to scale, it backward integrated into the production of lenses, one of its most expensive supplies. Its manufacturing division, Aurolab, makes intraocular lenses, as well as other consumables used in eye surgery. From its very humble origins in 1976, starting with three doctors and eleven beds, there have been vast changes in both Aravind’s scale and scope, but it continues to serve the enduring need for affordable eye care.

今天的沃尔玛商店与 1962 年（这家折扣零售商成立的那一年）的商店相比已大不相同。沃尔玛的第一批商店服务于美国小镇和农村的客户，这些市场是其他折扣商店所不具备的。如今，沃尔玛在全球各种规模的市场开展业务。它在山姆·沃尔顿做梦也想不到的品类中处于领先地位。例如，今天沃尔玛是美国最大的食品杂货销售商，而沃尔玛只是在 20 世纪 80 年代末才进入这一行业。它的 DVD 销量超过其他任何零售商，而沃尔玛于 1999 年进入这一品类。尽管 50 年来沃尔玛销售的商品发生了巨大变化，门店形式和系统也不断改进，生产率也不断提高，但基本的价值主张始终未变：沃尔玛继续以每天低价向客户提供品牌商品。

A Walmart store today looks very different from its counterpart of 1962, the year the discount retailer was founded. Walmart’s first stores served customers in small-town, rural America, markets that were not served by other discounters. Walmart now operates in markets of all sizes, all around the globe. It is a leader in categories that Sam Walton never dreamed of selling. Today, for example, Walmart is the largest seller of groceries in the United States, a business that Walmart entered only in the late 1980s. It sells more DVDs than any other retailer, a category Walmart entered in 1999. Despite five decades of dramatic change in the merchandise it sells, modifications in its store formats and systems, and continuous improvements in productivity, the basic value proposition is unchanged: Walmart continues to offer its customers branded merchandise at everyday low prices.

在上述每个案例中，变革都是由方向的连续性促成的。这就是稳定性最为重要的地方——在基本价值主张、公司满足的核心需求及其相对价格方面。

In each of these cases, change has been enabled by continuity of direction. That’s where stability is most important—in the basic value proposition, the core of needs the company meets and its relative price.

不确定性下的连续性

Continuity Under Uncertainty

 

对于管理者来说，生活中最困难的事情之一就是必须在不确定的情况下做出决策。如果你在高度不确定的环境中运营，很容易陷入如下错误的三段论：

One of the most difficult facts of life for managers is having to make decisions under conditions of uncertainty. And if you operate in a highly uncertain environment, it’s easy to get caught in a false syllogism that goes something like this:

 
  • 我无法预测未来。
  • I can’t predict the future.
    •  
  • 战略需要对未来的预测。
  • Strategy requires a prediction of the future.
    •  
  • 因此，我无法坚持某种策略。
  • Therefore, I can’t commit to a strategy.
    •  
 

如果你无法预测下一季度会发生什么，更不用说三到五年后会发生什么，也许保持灵活性、跑得更快、睡得更快才是更安全的做法。这种逻辑至少在过去十年甚至更久的时间里一直贯穿着关于竞争的争论。

If you can’t predict what’s going to happen next quarter, let alone three to five years from now, maybe it’s safer to stay flexible, run harder, and sleep faster. This logic has pervaded the debate about competition for at least the past decade, if not longer.

但波特认为，第二个前提是有缺陷的。伟大的战略很少，如果有的话，是建立在对未来的特别详细或具体的预测之上的。例如，沃尔玛发现自己正处于零售业革命之中，但它的战略并不要求沃尔玛预测这场革命将走向何方。自 1948 年 In-N-Out 汉堡推出以来，食品的生产、制备和消费方式发生了革命性的变化，但它的战略并不依赖于它预测任何巨大变化的能力。宝马的战略不需要对震撼汽车业的事件有不同寻常的远见，从石油危机到中国崛起成为全球增长最快的汽车市场。

But the second premise, Porter argues, is flawed. Great strategies are rarely, if ever, built on a particularly detailed or concrete prediction of the future. Walmart, for example, found itself in the midst of a revolution in retailing, yet its strategy didn’t require Walmart to predict the direction that revolution would take. Since In-N-Out Burger’s launch in 1948, there has been nothing short of a revolution in the way food is produced, prepared, and consumed, yet its strategy didn’t depend on its ability to predict any of those massive changes. BMW’s strategy didn’t require unusual foresight about events that have shaken the auto industry, ranging from an oil shock to the emergence of China as the world’s fastest-growing car market.

 

伟大的战略很少，如果有的话，是建立在对未来特别详细或具体的预测之上的。

Great strategies are rarely, if ever, built on a particularly detailed or concrete prediction of the future.

 

你只需要对未来五年或十年内哪些客户和需求会相对强劲有一个非常广泛的认识。战略隐含地是一种赌注，即所选择的客户或需求——以及以合适的价格满足这些需求的基本权衡——将会持久。

You need only a very broad sense of which customers and needs are going to be relatively robust five or ten years from now. Strategy is implicitly a bet that the chosen customers or needs—and the essential trade-offs for meeting them at the right price—will be enduring.

从这个意义上讲，有些价值主张比其他价值主张更为有力。戴尔的直销业务模式基于这样一个事实：有些客户不想要或不需要零售商或中间商（如经销商）向他们提供建议和信息。在个人电脑发展的早期，这种定位选择的妙处在于，随着客户对电脑越来越熟悉，愿意放弃中间商的客户数量可能会增加，而不是减少。戴尔的定位策略可能比其他策略拥有更多的增长机会。从这个意义上讲，戴尔做出了一个隐含的预测，事实证明这一预测是正确的，至少在几年前是这样（参见“战略何时需要改变？”）。

In that sense, some value propositions turn out to be more robust than others. Dell’s direct business model was based on the fact that some customers didn’t want, or didn’t need, a retailer or an intermediary such as a reseller to give them advice and information. The brilliance of that positioning choice in the early years of personal computers was that, as customers became more comfortable with computers, the number of customers willing to forego an intermediary would probably grow, not shrink. Dell was positioned in a strategy that was likely to have more growth opportunity than other strategies. In that sense, Dell made an implicit forecast that proved to be correct, at least up until a few years ago (see “When Does Strategy Need to Change?”).

何时需要改变策略？

When Does Strategy Need to Change?

 

战略成功的时间越长，就越难发现可能使其失效的真正威胁。连续性并不意味着自满，但是，人是人，如果管理者不警惕，自满就会出现。好的战略具有持久力，但显然有时必须改变战略。在波特看来，这些所谓的拐点相对罕见，公司更有可能过早放弃其战略。因此，了解绝对需要新战略的条件非常重要。

The longer a strategy has been successful, the more difficult it may be to see genuine threats that might invalidate it. Continuity does not mean complacency, but, people being human, complacency can set in if managers aren’t vigilant. Good strategies have staying power, but there are clearly times when a strategy must be changed. In Porter’s view, these so-called inflection points are relatively rare, and companies are more likely to pull away from their strategies prematurely. It is therefore important to understand the conditions that absolutely require new strategies.

首先，随着客户需求的变化，公司的核心价值主张可能会变得过时。通常，随着需求的变化，公司能够发展以服务于需求，但并非总是如此。真正的问题发生在需求消失时。

First, as customer needs change, a company’s core value proposition may simply become obsolete. Often, as needs shift, companies are able to evolve to serve them, but not always. The real problem occurs when the needs disappear.

丽诗加邦 (Liz Claiborne) 成立于 1976 年，满足了初入职场的新一代女性的新兴需求。丽诗加邦让顾客有安全感，确保她们能够穿着得体，获得成功。利用这一新需求，丽诗加邦迅速发展，盈利颇丰。整个 20 世纪 80 年代，该公司表现优异。然而，到 20 世纪 90 年代初，女性在职场对时尚的不安全感有所减轻。在依靠丽诗加邦提供时尚指导十年后，女性对自己的选择更加自信，也更注重多样性。与此同时，办公室着装规范也放松了。丽诗加邦所满足的需求迅速减少。收益从 1991 年的 2.23 亿美元下降到 1994 年的 8,300 万美元。

Founded in 1976, Liz Claiborne met an emerging need for a generation of women entering the professional workforce for the first time. Liz Claiborne gave its customers the security that they would be dressed appropriately for success. Tapping into this new need, Liz Claiborne grew rapidly and profitably. Throughout the 1980s, the company was a stellar performer. By the early 1990s, however, women’s fashion insecurity in the workplace had diminished. After a decade of relying on Liz Claiborne for fashion guidance, women became more confident about their own choices and more interested in variety. At the same time, office dress codes loosened up. The need Liz Claiborne served so well shrank rapidly. Earnings dropped from $223 million in 1991 to $83 million in 1994.

除了人口结构和社会变化之外，还有许多因素会导致客户需求发生变化。例如，监管方面的重大变化通常会改变公司可以提供的买方价值和成本的组合。监管可以通过任意定义客户需求来使行业处于人为的平衡状态。放松管制可以释放被压抑的经济力量，从而产生新的需求。行业发生重大结构变化通常需要新的战略定位。

Many factors beyond demographics and social change can cause customer needs to shift. Significant changes in regulation, for example, typically alter the mix of buyer value and cost that companies can offer. Regulation can hold an industry in an artificial equilibrium by defining customer needs in an arbitrary way. Deregulation can unleash pent-up economic forces, allowing new needs to emerge. Major structural changes in an industry often require new strategic positions.

其次，各种创新都可能使战略所依赖的基本权衡失效。戴尔的战略是以相对较低的价格满足基本的 PC 需求，这种战略基于其直销模式的成本优势。这种战略在近二十年中一直行之有效。但台湾 ODM（原始设计制造商）的崛起使得惠普等竞争对手能够将设计和组装外包，这基本上抹杀了戴尔的成本优势。戴尔还面临着 PC 销售从大型企业客户转向消费者的转变，以及通过零售渠道销售的行业销售额比例急剧上升的问题。这些变化抵消了戴尔最重要的权衡。当我在 20 世纪 90 年代末采访迈克尔·戴尔时，他说他担心戴尔的员工“谈论‘模式’时，好像它是一个无所不能的存在，可以照顾好一切。这很可怕，因为我知道没有什么是 100% 不变的。”他的担心后来被证明是有预见性的。如果一家公司的价值链无法让其在提供其独特的价值主张方面胜过竞争对手，那么它就需要制定新的战略。

Second, innovation of all sorts can serve to invalidate the essential trade-offs on which a strategy relies. Dell’s strategy, meeting basic PC needs at low relative prices, was based on the cost advantages of its direct model. That strategy worked for the better part of two decades. But the rise of Taiwanese ODMs (original design manufacturers) has enabled rivals like Hewlett-Packard to outsource design and assembly, basically wiping out Dell’s cost advantage. Dell has also struggled with the shift in PC sales from large business customers to consumers and with the sharp rise in the percentage of industry sales sold through the retail channel. These changes neutralized Dell’s most important trade-offs. When I interviewed Michael Dell in the late 1990s, he said he worried about people at Dell “who talk about ‘the model’ as if it were an all-powerful being that will take care of everything. It’s scary because I know that nothing is ever 100 percent constant.” His concern turned out to be prophetic. A company needs a new strategy if its value chain does not allow it to outperform its competitors in delivering its unique value proposition.

第三，技术或管理上的突破可以完全超越公司现有的价值主张。在所有威胁战略的力量中，没有什么比技术更受关注。有时新技术会改变游戏规则，但通常不会。一项真正具有颠覆性的技术将使当前一代行业领袖的资产失效。数码摄影对胶卷的主要生产商柯达来说是一项颠覆性技术。对于大多数用途而言，数码摄影优于胶卷。结果，柯达在 100 多年历史中积累的现有化学资产价值已大幅缩水。但即使在这种极端情况下，柯达将不得不投资数十亿美元来积累新的电子专业技术，该公司仍然拥有其宝贵的品牌和其他资产，可以在此基础上打造新的未来。

Third, a technological or managerial breakthrough can completely trump a company’s existing value proposition. Of all the forces that threaten strategies, none gets more attention than technology. Sometimes new technology changes the rules of the game; often it does not. A truly disruptive technology will invalidate the assets of the current generation of industry leaders. Digital photography was a disruptive technology for Kodak, the dominant producer of photographic film. For most uses, digital photography is superior to film. As a result, the value of Kodak’s existing chemistry-based assets, assembled over a 100-year history, has been decimated. But even in this extreme case, in which Kodak will have to invest billions to assemble new expertise in electronics, the company still has its valuable brand and other assets on which to build a new future.

要判断一项技术是否真正具有颠覆性，就要问它是否可以融入公司现有的价值链，或以增强公司现有活动的方式进行定制。波特认为，实际上，真正具有颠覆性的技术非常罕见。

To determine whether a technology is truly disruptive, ask whether it can be integrated into the company’s existing value chain or customized in a way that enhances the company’s existing activities. In practice, Porter argues, truly disruptive technologies are quite rare.

 

美国在线 (AOL) 的战略与戴尔如出一辙。AOL 帮助数百万人接触互联网，让用户体验更加友好，并为此收取高昂的费用。这种定位选择具有内在的弱点。随着客户越来越习惯上网，他们不太可能需要 AOL 提供的功能。他们必然会从简单的网页和手把手服务升级到功能更强大或速度更快的服务。或者，他们会选择价格更低、服务更精简的互联网服务提供商。

The strategy of America Online (AOL) was the mirror image of Dell’s. AOL helped to introduce millions of people to the Internet, making the experience user friendly and charging a premium price for doing so. This positioning choice had an inherent vulnerability. As customers grew more comfortable going online, they would be less likely to need what AOL was configured to deliver. They would inevitably trade up from simple Web pages and hand-holding to deeper functionality or faster speed. Or they would trade down to a more stripped-down Internet service provider at a lower price.

除了这个基本赌注——即所选需求将持久存在之外，战略并不需要波特所说的对未来的“英雄预测”。西南航空只需预测人们将继续需要低成本、便捷的交通。他们不必预测人们对恐怖主义日益增长的担忧，或航空燃油价格，或任何影响航空业的变量。In-N-Out Burger 只需预测有些人将继续需要简单新鲜的汉堡和炸薯条，新鲜烹制。同样，宝马只需预测对设计、驾驶性能和声望的需求将持久存在。

Beyond this fundamental bet that the chosen needs will be enduring, strategy does not require what Porter calls “heroic predictions” about the future. Southwest Airlines had only to predict that people would continue to want low-cost, convenient transportation. They did not have to predict the rising concern over terrorism, or the price of jet fuel, or any of a host of variables that have had an impact on the airline industry. In-N-Out Burger had only to predict that some people would continue to want simple fresh burgers and fries, freshly prepared. Similarly, BMW had only to predict that the need for design, driving performance, and prestige would be enduring.

艾伦·穆拉利 (Alan Mulally) 围绕一个简单的预测来构建福特的未来：全球消费者对汽车的需求将越来越相似。福特的战略并不取决于电动汽车的渗透曲线有多陡峭，尽管如果真的发生，电动汽车可能会成为一场轰动性的技术变革。穆拉利说：“‘这就是战略的意义所在。战略是关于未来的观点，然后根据这种观点做出决策。最糟糕的事情就是没有观点，不做决策。’”波特自己也说得再好不过了。

Alan Mulally is building Ford’s future around a simple prediction that consumers across the globe are becoming more similar in what they want from a car. The strategy doesn’t depend on how steep the penetration curve will be for electric vehicles, although that could potentially be a blockbuster technological disruption—if it happens at all. Says Mulally, “‘That is what strategy is all about. It’s about a point of view about the future and then making decisions based on that. The worst thing you can do is not have a point of view, and not make decisions.’” Porter couldn’t have said it better himself.

回到我们开始提到的错误三段论。许多管理者在管理大师的鼓励下，将灵活性作为战略的替代品。但是，如果你运用竞争优势的经济基本原理，你就会很快发现这种方法的缺陷。问问自己，灵活性和卓越绩效之间的联系在哪里？灵活性是否可能比专注于客户需求的战略更好地满足任何客户的需求？对冲你的活动（半途而废，只做一部分，不做全部）是否可能导致价格上涨和成本降低？波特认为，问题在于，当你用灵活性取代战略时，你的组织将不会代表任何东西或变得擅长任何事情。灵活性在理论上听起来不错，但追溯到你执行的活动的具体层面，你就会明白为什么没有战略的灵活性将注定平庸——定制将很差，不存在权衡，不可能适应。所有这些都要求公司保持方向。

Go back to the false syllogism we started with. Many executives, cheered on by management gurus, have embraced flexibility as an alternative to strategy. But if you apply the economic fundamentals of competitive advantage, you’ll be quick to spot the flaw in this approach. Ask yourself, Where’s the link between flexibility and superior performance? Is it likely that flexibility will meet any customer’s needs better than a strategy sharply focused on those needs? Will hedging your activities—going halfway, doing some, not all—likely result in higher prices and lower costs? The problem, Porter argues, is that when you substitute flexibility for strategy, your organization never stands for anything or becomes good at anything. Flexibility sounds good in theory, but trace it down to the concrete level of the activities you perform and you’ll see why flexibility without strategy will guarantee mediocrity—tailoring will be poor, trade-offs nonexistent, fit impossible. All of these require a company to maintain a direction.

 

当你用灵活性取代战略时，你的组织将不会代表任何东西，也不会擅长任何事情。

When you substitute flexibility for strategy, your organization never stands for anything or becomes good at anything.

 

哪些事情必须改变？

What Must Change?

 

战略是一条路径，而不是一个固定点。有效的战略是动态的。它定义了期望的市场结果，而不是实现该结果的所有手段。虽然方向的连续性对于战略至关重要，但某些类型的变化对于保持竞争优势绝对至关重要。

Strategy is a path, not a fixed point. An effective strategy is dynamic. It defines a desired market outcome, not all the means of achieving it. Although continuity of direction is essential to strategy, some kinds of change are absolutely critical to maintaining competitive advantage.

首先，你必须始终站在运营效率的前沿。如果你不这样做，战略就毫无意义。你必须不断吸收与你的战略或其必要权衡不冲突的最佳实践。如果不能保持这一水平，将导致成本损失，从而抵消你的其他优势。

First, you must stay on the frontier of operational effectiveness. If you don’t, strategy won’t matter. You must continuously assimilate best practices that do not conflict with your strategy or the trade-offs essential to it. Failure to keep up on this dimension will result in cost penalties that can swamp your other advantages.

20 世纪 90 年代中期，宝马就面临这样的挑战。其他汽车制造商在最佳实践方面投入了大量资金。宝马却落后了。例如，在产品开发方面，宝马发现每辆车 60 个月的开发时间是无法维持的。它着手将开发时间缩短一半。在此过程中，宝马实施了一系列重要的 OE 改进，这些改进无论采用何种战略，都能提高汽车制造商的生产力。例如，通过并行运行一些活动，缩短了旧有的线性设计任务序列。碰撞模拟可以在计算机上进行，而不必使用原型。这些显然是最佳实践，无论您生产的是豪华轿车还是入门级家用厢式货车。

BMW faced such a challenge in the mid-1990s. Other automakers had invested heavily in best practices. BMW had fallen behind. For example, in product development, BMW could see that its development time of sixty months per vehicle was untenable. It set out to cut the time in half. In the process, BMW embraced a host of important OE improvements, practices that would make any automaker more productive regardless of its strategy. For example, the old linear sequence of design tasks was shortened by running some activities in parallel. Crash simulations could be performed on computers instead of with prototypes. These were clear best practices, whether you were producing a luxury sedan or an entry-level family van.

但宝马划定了界限，变化可能会影响其独特之处。例如，它实施了计算机辅助造型 (CAS) 系统，设计师只需完成约 80% 即可完成，但要达到宝马所需的造型水平，其余部分需要使用实体模型完成。修改后的设计流程是一种混合流程，结合了 CAS 的时间优势以及粘土和手工造型的质量优势。

But BMW drew the line where changes might affect the very qualities that make it unique. For example, it implemented a computer-aided styling (CAS) system that took designers about 80 percent to completion, but to achieve BMW’s requisite level of styling, the rest needed to be done with physical models. The revised design process was a hybrid that combined the time advantages of CAS with the quality advantages of clay and hand-styling.

对于任何新技术或管理创新，有些用途将是每个人都必须采用的最佳实践。其他用途则具有战略意义，你必须仔细评估这些。关于任何创新，要问的问题都很简单：它会强化你的战略还是会损害其独特性？

With any new technology or management innovation, some uses are going to be best practices that everyone will have to adopt. Other uses will have strategic significance, and you must assess these carefully. The question to ask about any innovation is a simple one: will it reinforce your strategy or will it compromise its uniqueness?

其次，只要有办法扩展你的价值主张或有更好的方法来实现它，你就必须做出改变。这些改变是针对具体战略的，并不是所有公司都能从中获益。在某种程度上，这些创新机会的出现正是因为你从一开始就有一个战略。几乎从首席执行官里德·哈斯廷斯创办 Netflix 邮寄 DVD 的那一天起，他就开始寻找基于互联网的解决方案。当将视频直接流式传输到客户电脑上成为可能时，Netflix 立即意识到这样做更能满足其最初制定战略时所围绕的需求。邮购是执行其“直接”模式的一种方式。流媒体将进一步缩短将 DVD 来回运送到客户家中所需的时间和相关的物流成本。（2010 年，邮寄 DVD 的往返成本约为 1 美元，而流媒体仅需 5 美分。）对于 Coinstar 的 Redbox 等竞争对手而言，这种变化并不那么直接相关，因为 Redbox 的战略是围绕位置便利的售货亭建立的。

Second, you must change whenever there are ways to extend your value proposition or better ways to deliver it. These changes are strategy specific, and would not benefit all companies equally. To some extent, these opportunities to innovate arise precisely because you have a strategy to begin with. Almost from the day CEO Reed Hastings started Netflix to distribute DVDs by mail, he began searching for an Internet-based solution. When it became feasible to stream videos direct to a customer’s PC, Netflix saw immediately that doing so would better serve the needs around which its strategy was built in the first place. Mail order was one way of executing its “direct” model. Streaming would further cut the time and the associated logistics costs of shipping DVDs back and forth to a customer’s home. (In 2010, the cost, round-trip, for a mailed DVD was about a dollar versus just five cents to stream.) For rivals such as Coinstar’s Redbox—whose strategy is built around conveniently located kiosks—the change was less immediately relevant.

与大多数其他汽车制造商不同，宝马似乎将电动汽车的到来视为扩展其价值主张的一种方式。当其他所有人都在利用现有的传统汽车平台争相进入市场时，宝马工程师却选择独自竞争。他们认为，要实现宝马所著称的性能和造型，唯一的办法就是从头开始设计一款全新的汽车。乘客舱和其他部件的碳纤维结构将抵消汽车电池增加的重量。宝马设计总监阿德里安·范·霍伊东克 (Adrian van Hooydonk) 表示，这款汽车的定位将是“高端可持续性”，旨在满足“城市富裕司机想要表现出环保意识”而不必“宣誓贫穷”的需求。

Unlike most other automakers, BMW appears to see the coming of electric cars as a way to extend its value proposition. While everyone else is rushing to market using their existing conventional car platforms, BMW engineers are choosing to run their own race. They believe that the only way to achieve the kind of performance and styling for which BMW is known is to design a completely new vehicle from the bottom up. Carbon fiber construction of the passenger compartment and other components will offset the added weight of the car’s batteries. According to BMW’s design chief, Adrian van Hooydonk, the positioning will be “premium sustainability,” aimed at “affluent drivers in urban areas who want to appear environmentally conscious” without having to take a “ ‘rolling vow of poverty.’ ”

策略的出现和演变

Strategies Emerge and Strategies Evolve

 

波特在论述战略时，选择的是那些战略完善、内容丰富的公司，比如西南航空和宜家。如果有诺贝尔商业战略奖，这些公司将会获奖。这些伟大的典范以优异的成绩通过了所有的战略测试。他们取得了大多数管理者梦寐以求的成就：几十年来业绩辉煌（图 7-2 ）。波特事后研究了这些公司，并问道：是什么导致了他们的成功？答案总是一样的：每家公司都能够创建一个复杂的商业系统，并且经过精心配置，可以在特定的行业环境中创造某种价值。我要强调的是，这些组织花了几十年的时间来磨练这些系统，这些错综复杂的整体。这就是为什么长期的连续性是波特五项测试之一，也是我称之为推动因素的原因。

When Porter writes about strategy, he chooses companies with fully developed, rich strategies, companies like Southwest or IKEA. If there were a Nobel Prize for business strategy, these companies would win it. These great exemplars pass all the tests of strategy with flying colors. They have achieved what most managers can only dream of: stellar performance over several decades (figure 7-2). Porter examines those companies, after the fact, and asks, What explains their success? The answer is always the same: each was able to create a complex business system elegantly configured to produce a certain kind of value in a specific industry context. Let me underscore that these organizations have spent decades honing these systems, these intricate complex wholes. This is why continuity over time is one of Porter’s five tests, and why I call it the enabler.

图 7-2

FIGURE 7-2

西南航空的连续性

Continuity at Southwest Airlines

 

西南航空战略的连续性体现在其持续的竞争优势上。从 1980 年到 2010 年的 30 年间，西南航空的平均投资回报率为 11.4%，而行业平均投资回报率为 3.1%。西南航空的优势在 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代最为显著。过去十年，面对劳动力成本更低的模仿者的竞争，西南航空的优势逐渐减弱。与此同时，增长压力迫使西南航空放松一些核心权衡。例如，它曾经只飞短途航线，现在情况已不再如此。放松权衡会带来经济后果。

Continuity of strategy at Southwest Airlines is reflected in its sustained competitive advantage. Over the 30-year period from 1980 to 2010, Southwest’s average ROIC was 11.4 percent versus the industry’s 3.1 percent. Southwest’s advantage was strongest in the 1980s and 1990s. It has been eroding over the past decade in the face of competition from imitators with lower labor costs. At the same time, growth pressures have led Southwest to relax some of its core trade-offs. For example, once it flew only short-haul routes; that’s no longer the case. Relaxing trade-offs has economic consequences.

现在，我想没有人会天真地相信波特所说的任何人都可以只用三个简单的步骤在一夜之间创造出西南航空或宜家：

Now, I assume no one is so naive as to believe that Porter is suggesting that anyone can come along and create a Southwest or an IKEA overnight in three easy steps:

 
  1. 做一些分析（五种力量、价值链、相对成本和价值）。
  2. Do some analysis (five forces, value chain, relative cost and value).
    3.  
  3. 绘制行业地图，显示当前参与者的定位。
  4. Draw an industry map, showing how current players are positioned.
    5.  
  5. 选择一個未占用的位置。
  6. Choose an unoccupied position.
    7.  
 

一些管理者质疑，包括波特本人在内，是否有人能够提前设计出如此复杂的系统。所以，也许做战略分析是浪费时间。也许你最好与内心的企业家精神取得联系，或者进行大量实验，看看结果如何。

Some managers question whether anyone, including Porter himself, could possibly design, in advance, such a complex system. So maybe doing strategic analysis is a waste of time. Maybe you are better off getting in touch with your inner entrepreneur or unleashing lots of experiments and seeing what emerges.

那么，对于如何在分析性地设计战略和不断试验直至成功之间取得平衡，波特是怎么说的呢？你可能认为，波特会百分之百地支持“设计”这一论点。事实并非如此。良好的分析必不可少，但他认为，认为在事实发生之前就应该完全确定战略是错误的。有太多的变量和不确定性，无法预测一切。随着时间的推移，在服务客户和与竞争对手竞争的过程中，一个组织会对其战略形成重要的见解，而这些见解在开始时可能并不具备。随着时间的推移，新的机会就会出现。

So what does Porter say about how to strike the right balance between designing a strategy analytically and experimenting until one emerges? You might assume that Porter would come down 100 percent on the “design” side of the argument. Not so. Good analysis is essential, but it’s a mistake, he argues, to think that a strategy should be fully defined in its entirety before the fact. There are simply too many variables and too much uncertainty to anticipate everything. Over time, in the course of serving its customers and vying with its rivals, an organization develops important insights about its strategy that it might not have had at the start. Over time, new opportunities emerge.

连续性使组织有足够的时间来深化对战略的理解。换句话说，坚持一项战略可使公司更充分地了解其所创造的价值并真正擅长实施该战略。战略从来不会在第一天就成熟和定型。西南航空在创立四年后才开始飞行。宜家创始人英格瓦·坎普拉德于 1943 年创办公司，但直到 1958 年才真正开设了一家商店，而直到 20 世纪 60 年代中期，宜家才测试其标志性的自助式商店设计。战略往往通过一个发现过程诞生，这个过程可能需要数年反复试验，公司需要测试其定位并学习如何最好地实现它。

Continuity gives an organization the time it needs to deepen its understanding of the strategy. Sticking with a strategy, in other words, allows a company to more fully understand the value it creates and to become really good at it. Strategies never arrive full-blown and fully formed on Day One. It took Southwest a full four years after it was created even to begin flying. IKEA’s founder, Ingvar Kamprad, started his company in 1943, but he didn’t actually open a store until 1958, and it wasn’t until the mid-1960s that IKEA tested its signature self-service store design. Strategies often emerge through a process of discovery that can take years of trial and error as the company tests its positioning and learns how best to deliver it.

在另一个极端，波特警告不要认为一个组织可以通过鼓励所有部门进行不相关的实验而轻松地制定战略。战略关乎整体，而不是部分。首先必须有一个稳定的核心，或者至少有一个关于公司如何创造和获取价值的合理假设。

At the opposite extreme, Porter warns against thinking that an organization can simply stumble its way into a strategy by encouraging unconnected experimentation in all of its units. Strategy is about the whole, not the parts. There must be a stable core to begin with, or at least a grounded hypothesis about how the company is going to create and capture value.

通常，战略始于两三个基本选择。随着时间的推移，随着战略变得更加清晰，额外的选择将补充和扩展原有的选择。正如我们之前所看到的，西南航空一开始只有三架飞机，并以低价提供便捷服务为简单的价值主张。我们还看到了快速登机口周转对西南航空的竞争优势有多么重要。但西南航空的创始人事先并没有想出这个至关重要的因素。

Often, strategies begin with two or three essential choices. Over time, as the strategy becomes clearer, additional choices complement and extend the original ones. Southwest began, as we saw earlier, with three airplanes and the simple value proposition of convenient service at low price. We also saw how important fast gate turnarounds have been to Southwest’s competitive advantage. But that crucially important element was not something Southwest’s founders figured out in advance.

早些时候，首席执行官拉马尔·缪斯 (Lamar Muse) 看到了提供州外包机服务的机会，因此他购买了第四架飞机。这架额外的飞机还让西南航空在其常规航线上增加了更多航班，从而提高了便利性。但巧合的是，联邦地区法院随后裁定西南航空不能在德克萨斯州以外飞行。第四架飞机突然成了财务负担。缪斯卖掉了它，但他真的想保持增强的航班时刻表。这是可能的，但前提是他们将登机口的周转时间保持在 10 分钟内。需要成为发明之母。正如当时西南航空的一位站长回忆道：“‘我们大多数人没有航空公司背景，不知道我们不能这样做，所以我们就这么做了。’”

Early on, CEO Lamar Muse saw an opportunity to provide out-of-state charter service, so he bought a fourth plane. This extra plane also let Southwest add more flights to its regular routes, thus boosting its convenience. As luck would have it, a federal district court then ruled that Southwest could not fly outside the state of Texas. Suddenly the fourth plane was a financial burden. Muse sold it, but he really wanted to maintain the enhanced schedule. It would be possible, but only if they kept gate turnarounds to ten minutes. Necessity became the mother of invention. As one Southwest station manager at the time recalls, “ ‘Most of us, not having an airline background, had no idea that we couldn’t do this, so we just did it.’ ”

当你看到一个真正好的战略，比如西南航空或宜家的战略时，你会发现整个战略是如此复杂和连贯，经济逻辑是如此清晰和令人信服，以至于你会认为这一切都是事先计划好的。但事实并非如此。以戴尔为例。其战略的核心早期就围绕着直接销售（避免经销商的利润）和使用购买的零部件按订单生产（避免内部技术开发和零部件制造的成本）而形成。随着公司了解到战略中存在的可能性，而这些可能性是迈克尔·戴尔一开始没有预见到的，因此从这个核心开始，很多事情随着时间的推移得到了发展和改变。

When you look at a really good strategy, like Southwest’s or IKEA’s, the whole is so intricate and consistent, the economic logic so clear and compelling, that you think it must have all been planned out in advance. Not so. Consider Dell. The core of its strategy crystallized early around selling direct (avoiding the reseller’s margin) and building to order using purchased components (avoiding the cost of internal technology development and component manufacturing). From that core, much developed and changed over time, as the company learned about possibilities inherent in the strategy that Michael Dell didn’t envision at the start.

例如，戴尔公司早期发现，与规模较小的客户相比，拥有内部 IT 部门的大型企业客户更能接受戴尔的价值主张。此外，大型客户订购的数量足以让戴尔公司高效地为他们提供服务。因此，戴尔公司将早期的努力重点放在大型企业客户身上，而将当时无利可图的消费市场留给了其他电脑制造商。

Early on, for example, Dell found that the value proposition was more compelling with larger corporate customers with in-house IT departments than with smaller purchasers. It also turned out that large customers ordered in quantities large enough for Dell to achieve efficiencies in serving them. Thus Dell focused its early efforts on larger corporate customers, leaving what was at the time an unprofitable consumer market for other computer makers.

实施该战略多年后，戴尔意识到直接销售和按客户订单生产为公司带来了其他重要的竞争优势。这缩短了周期时间并降低了库存水平，使戴尔在零部件价格迅速下跌时获得了相对成本优势。也就是说，戴尔的竞争对手必须通过库存渠道来销售电脑，而这些电脑的零部件更旧、更昂贵。戴尔还了解到，与客户直接建立关系使其比竞争对手更好地了解未来需求，这反过来又改善了其供应链管理。直到 21 世纪初，这一直是戴尔成本优势的核心，也是它能够以更低的价格为客户提供标准 Windows-Intel 技术的能力。

Years into the strategy, Dell realized that selling direct—and building to customers’ orders—gave the company other significant sources of competitive advantage. It resulted in faster cycle times and lower inventory levels, which gave Dell a relative cost advantage at a time when the price of components was falling rapidly. That is, Dell’s rivals, having to stock channels, had computers with older, more expensive components. Dell also learned that its direct relationships with its customers gave it better information than its rivals about future demand, and this, in turn, improved its supply chain management. This, up through the early 2000s, was the heart of Dell’s cost advantage and its ability to offer its customers standard Windows–Intel technology at lower prices.

戴尔花了数年时间才充分认识到其战略的经济力量。戴尔越了解库存对其价值主张的重要性，就越能集中组织中的每个人精力，想出新的方法来减少库存。当其他 PC 制造商跟踪毛利率时，戴尔却关注着 ROIC，这是一项强调库存管理的指标。戴尔也从自己的错误中吸取了教训。面对 20 世纪 80 年代增长放缓，戴尔曾尝试通过经销商进行销售。当它意识到试图同时兼顾两种立场弊大于利时，它很快就改变了策略。

It took years for Dell to appreciate fully the economic power of its strategy. The more Dell learned about the importance of inventory to its value proposition, the better it was able to focus everyone in the organization on coming up with new ways to reduce it. While other PC makers tracked their gross margins, Dell kept its eye on ROIC, a measure that highlighted inventory management. And Dell learned from its mistakes as well. Faced with slowing growth in the 1980s, Dell tried to sell through resellers. It quickly did an about-face when it realized that trying to straddle two positions did much more harm than good.

波特的关键观点是：一开始就搞清楚最终会造成影响的一切几乎是不可能的。因此，改变是不可避免的，而改变的能力至关重要。但方向的连续性使得有效改变更有可能发生。不可否认，运气在一些非凡的商业成功中发挥了作用。但正如波特喜欢问的那样，你会愿意投资那些“策略”依赖运气的人吗？你可能无法分析自己取得巨大成功的方法——创造力和机缘巧合会发挥一定作用。但只要理解了策略的要点，你就更有可能——更有可能——在过程中做出更好的决策。

Porter’s key point is this: rarely, if ever, is it possible to figure out everything that will eventually matter at the very start. Change, then, is inevitable, and the capacity to change is critically important. But continuity of direction makes effective change more likely. There is no denying that dumb luck has played a role in some extraordinary business successes. But, as Porter likes to ask, would you be eager to invest in someone whose “strategy” is to rely on dumb luck? You may not be able to analyze your way to spectacular success—creativity and serendipity play a role. But armed with an understanding of strategy essentials, you are more likely—far more likely—to make better decisions along the way.

连续性悖论

The Continuity Paradox

 

自 20 世纪 90 年代以来，引领变革已成为优秀 CEO 的标志。然而，连续性原则提醒我们，并非所有变革都是好的，过多的变革可能是坏的，并非所有变革都需要改变战略。如果你能掌握连续性在战略中的作用，它将改变你对变革本身的看法。矛盾的是，战略的连续性实际上提高了组织适应环境变化和创新的能力。

Since the 1990s, leading change has become the hallmark of a great CEO. The principle of continuity reminds us, however, that not all change is good, that too much change can be bad, and that not all change requires a change in strategy. If you can grasp the role continuity plays in strategy, it will change your thinking about change itself. Paradoxically, continuity of strategy actually improves an organization’s ability to adapt to changes in the environment and to innovate.

 

矛盾的是，战略的连续性实际上提高了组织适应变化和创新的能力。

Paradoxically, continuity of strategy actually improves an organization’s ability to adapt to changes and to innovate.

 

为什么？变革的过程就是筛选和整理大量信息，然后确定公司需要采取的行动。利率和汇率波动。社交媒体呈指数级增长。一些新的零售模式出现。中国做X，印度做Y。新一代人表现出与父母不同的价值观和工作习惯。硅片实现了令人难以置信的电路密度。但显然，波特指出，这些事件以及其他数百个事件并非对每家公司都很重要。如果你没有战略，那么任何事情都可能很重要。战略可以帮助你决定什么是重要的，因为你知道你要服务的对象、你要满足的需求，以及你的价值链是如何以合适的价格独特地配置的。这些要素为公司奠定了基础，使其能够分辨出什么是重要的，什么是不重要的。战略使优先事项更加明确。此外，如果组织有一个人们理解的目标，他们改变的意愿和紧迫感就会更高。

Why? The process of change is about sifting and sorting through massive amounts of information and zeroing in on the actions a company needs to take. Interest and exchange rates fluctuate. Social media grow exponentially. Some new retail format emerges. China does X, India Y. The rising generation exhibits values and work habits different from their parents. Silicon chips achieve incredible circuit density. But clearly, Porter notes, these events, and hundreds of others, are not significant for every company. If you don’t have a strategy, then anything and everything could be important. A strategy helps you to decide what’s important because you know who you’re trying to serve, what needs you’re trying to meet, and how your value chain is distinctively configured to do so at the right price. These elements ground a company, enabling it to sort out what matters and what doesn’t. Strategy makes priorities clearer. Moreover, if the organization has a purpose that people understand, their willingness to change and their sense of urgency will be higher.

从人的角度来说，如果你知道自己是谁、自己代表什么，那么改变就会比较容易，而如果你不知道，那么改变就会非常困难。如果一个组织觉得它必须满足每一种新出现的需求，或者必须接受每一种新技术，那么它就会变得无能为力。但是，如果每个人都理解价值主张，那么组织就可以抓住新趋势，从而以更独特的方式满足客户的需求。它可以筛选周围的变化，并快速掌握哪些是相关的。宜家时尚而有教养的客户群关心环境。宜家 2010 年的目录重点介绍了平板包装的环保性。宜家可以通过营销一种 (a) 几十年来一直采用的方法，以及 (b) 与其低价策略一致的方法，来保持新鲜感和相关性。

Put in human terms, it is easier to change when you know who you are and what you stand for, and very difficult to change when you don’t. It is debilitating for an organization to feel it must serve every new need that emerges or embrace every new technology that comes its way. But when everyone understands the value proposition, an organization can jump at new trends that allow it to be more distinctive in meeting the needs of its customers. It can sift through the sea of changes around it and quickly grasp which ones are relevant. IKEA’s hip and educated customer base cares about the environment. IKEA’s 2010 catalogue highlights the eco-friendliness of flat packs. IKEA can stay fresh and relevant by marketing an approach that (a) it has been taking for many decades, and (b) is consistent with its low-price strategy.

 

在变化和不确定时期，制定深思熟虑和明确的战略比以往任何时候都更为重要。

The deliberate and explicit setting of strategy is more important than ever during periods of change and uncertainty.

 

组织是复杂的。它们需要时间才能真正熟练地提供它们所选择的价值。乍一听似乎有些自相矛盾，波特认为，在变革和不确定时期，深思熟虑、明确地制定战略比以往任何时候都更为重要。但如果你停下来想一想，这根本不是自相矛盾，战略提供了明确的方向，让管理者能够排除周围的许多干扰。战略专注于客户价值和成本之间的差距，可以防止盲目追随时尚的倾向。

Organizations are complex. They require time to become really proficient at delivering their chosen kind of value. In what at first sounds like a paradox, Porter argues that the deliberate and explicit setting of strategy is more important than ever during periods of change and uncertainty. But it’s no paradox at all when you stop to think that strategy offers a clear direction, allowing managers to tune out the many distractions around them. A strategy, with its focus on the spread between customer value and cost, guards against the tendency to follow fads blindly.

结语：

Epilogue:

 

一些影响

A Short List of Implications

 

我以马克·吐温的一句笑话 作为本书的开场白。他曾说过，经典是每个人都希望读过但却没人愿意读的作品。现在，读到最后，我终于明白了马克·吐温的笑话的真正含义。这并不是说经典太难了。而是我们太懒了，对自己要求太低了。

I INTRODUCED THIS BOOK WITH a joke attributed to Mark Twain. Classics, he quipped, are works that everybody wants to have read but nobody wants to read. Now, as I have come to the end, I finally get the point of Twain’s joke. It’s not that the classics are too hard. It’s that we are too lazy and demand too little of ourselves.

波特对管理者的要求非常简单，但也很严格。他要求管理者清楚地了解他们的决策和绩效。但他表示，不允许作弊——你必须做到精确和严谨。与大多数管理作家不同，波特拒绝告诉你该怎么做。他说，我会给你指导框架，一个适用于所有情况的一般理论，但你所做的工作是创造性的，你必须找到自己独特的答案。

What Porter asks of managers is both very simple and very hard. He asks, simply, that managers keep a clear line of sight between their decisions and their performance. But, he says, no cheating allowed—you must be precise and rigorous about it. And unlike most management writers, Porter refuses to tell you what to do. He says, I’ll give you guiding frameworks, a general theory that applies in all cases, but the work you do is creative and you have to find your own unique answers.

管理类书籍是出了名的时髦。今年的“开创性”思想在三年、五年或十年后将毫无用处。但真正的经典，借用作家伊塔洛·卡尔维诺的话来说，是一部“永不言弃”的作品。此外，“每次重读经典作品，都和第一次阅读一样，是一次发现之旅。”

Management books are notoriously faddish. This year’s “groundbreaking” ideas will be of little use three, five, or ten years down the road. But a true classic, to borrow a phrase from the writer Italo Calvino, is a work “that has never finished saying what it has to say.” Further, “Every rereading of a classic is as much a voyage of discovery as the first reading.”

对我来说确实如此。作为总结，我试图将重读波特所发现的实际意义提炼成一个简短的清单。这种清单很容易变得陈词滥调。但如果你掌握了波特的精髓，你就可以把每个意义追溯到波特建立的持久基础。

That has certainly been the case for me. By way of summary, I’ve tried to distill into a short list the practical implications of what I’ve discovered on rereading Porter. Lists of this sort can easily be trite. But if you have mastered the essential Porter, you can trace each implication to the enduring foundation that Porter has built.

十大实际意义

Ten Practical Implications

 
  1. 争当最好是一种直觉的但却是自我毁灭的竞争方式。
  2. Vying to be the best is an intuitive but self-destructive approach to competition.
    3.  
  3. 如果没有利润，规模或增长就毫无意义。竞争是为了利润，而不是市场份额。
  4. There is no honor in size or growth if those are profitless. Competition is about profits, not market share.
    5.  
  5. 竞争优势不是打败竞争对手，而是为客户创造独特价值。如果你有竞争优势，它就会体现在你的损益表上。
  6. Competitive advantage is not about beating rivals; it’s about creating unique value for customers. If you have a competitive advantage, it will show up on your P&L.
    7.  
  7. 独特的价值主张对于战略至关重要。但战略不仅仅是营销。如果你的价值主张不需要专门定制的价值链来实现，那么它就没有战略意义。
  8. A distinctive value proposition is essential for strategy. But strategy is more than marketing. If your value proposition doesn’t require a specifically tailored value chain to deliver it, it will have no strategic relevance.
    9.  
  9. 不要觉得你必须“取悦”每一个潜在客户。好的策略的标志是故意让一些客户不高兴。
  10. Don’t feel you have to “delight” every possible customer out there. The sign of a good strategy is that it deliberately makes some customers unhappy.
    11.  
  11. 任何战略，除非明确说明组织不会做什么，否则都是没有意义的。权衡利弊是确保竞争优势得以实现和持续的关键。
  12. No strategy is meaningful unless it makes clear what the organization will not do. Making trade-offs is the linchpin that makes competitive advantage possible and sustainable.
    13.  
  13. 不要高估或低估良好执行的重要性。它不太可能成为可持续优势的来源，但如果没有它，即使是最出色的战略也无法产生卓越的业绩。
  14. Don’t overestimate or underestimate the importance of good execution. It’s unlikely to be a source of a sustainable advantage, but without it even the most brilliant strategy will fail to produce superior performance.
    15.  
  15. 好的战略取决于多种选择，而不是单一选择，以及这些选择之间的联系。单凭核心竞争力很少能产生可持续的竞争优势。
  16. Good strategies depend on many choices, not one, and on the connections among them. A core competence alone will rarely produce a sustainable competitive advantage.
    17.  
  17. 面对不确定性时保持灵活性听起来是个好主意，但这意味着您的组织永远不会坚持任何东西或擅长任何事情。过多的改变对战略来说可能和过少的改变一样灾难性。
  18. Flexibility in the face of uncertainty may sound like a good idea, but it means that your organization will never stand for anything or become good at anything. Too much change can be just as disastrous for strategy as too little.
    19.  
  19. 坚持一项战略并不需要对未来做出大胆的预测。做出这样的承诺实际上会提高你的创新能力和适应动荡的能力。
  20. Committing to a strategy does not require heroic predictions about the future. Making that commitment actually improves your ability to innovate and to adapt to turbulence.
    21.  
 

常见问题解答：迈克尔·波特访谈

FAQs: An Interview with Michael Porter

 

此次采访于 2011 年第一季度在哈佛商学院分几场会议进行。为准备采访，我查阅了波特教授演讲活动的记录，特别关注了管理者在问答环节最常提出的问题。这些常见问题都反映在这里。

This interview was conducted at the Harvard Business School over the course of several sessions during the first quarter of 2011. To prepare, I reviewed transcripts of Professor Porter’s speaking events, paying special attention to the questions managers most often raise during the Q&A periods. Those frequently asked questions are reflected here.

一、常见的错误和障碍

I. Common Mistakes and Obstacles

 

马格雷塔：您认为最常见的战略错误是什么？

Magretta: What are the most common strategy mistakes you see?

波特：所有错误都是争先恐后，与其他人走同一条路，认为自己能取得更好的结果。这是一场很难取胜的比赛。许多管理者将运营效率与战略混为一谈。

Porter: The granddaddy of all mistakes is competing to be the best, going down the same path as everybody else and thinking that somehow you can achieve better results. This is a hard race to win. So many managers confuse operational effectiveness with strategy.

另一个常见的错误是将营销与战略混为一谈。战略自然而然地源于对客户及其需求的关注。因此，在许多公司中，战略是围绕价值主张而建立的，价值主张是等式的需求方。但强大的战略需要量身定制的价值链——它也与供应方有关，即提供价值的独特活动配置。战略将需求方的选择与价值链（供应方）的独特选择联系起来。没有两者，你就无法拥有竞争优势。

Another common mistake is confusing marketing with strategy. It’s natural for strategy to arise from a focus on customers and their needs. So in many companies, strategy is built around the value proposition, which is the demand side of the equation. But a robust strategy requires a tailored value chain—it’s about the supply side as well, the unique configuration of activities that delivers value. Strategy links choices on the demand side with the unique choices about the value chain (the supply side). You can’t have competitive advantage without both.

另一个错误是高估优势。许多组织都存在内向型偏见。你可能认为客户服务是一个强项。因此，这成为你试图制定战略的“优势”。但就战略而言，真正的优势必须是公司比任何竞争对手做得都好。而“更好”是因为你执行的活动与他们不同，因为你选择了与他们不同的配置。

Another mistake is to overestimate strengths. There’s an inward-looking bias in many organizations. You might perceive customer service as a strong area. So that becomes the “strength” on which you attempt to build a strategy. But a real strength for strategy purposes has to be something the company can do better than any of its rivals. And “better” because you are performing different activities than they perform, because you’ve chosen a different configuration than they have.

另一个常见错误是错误地定义业务或错误地定义地理范围。几十年前，西奥多·莱维特 (Theodore Levitt) 的著作影响深远，此后出现了一种对行业进行广泛定义的趋势。他最著名的例子是铁路公司未能意识到自己从事的是运输业务，因此他们忽视了卡车和空运带来的威胁。然而，将业务定义为运输的问题在于，铁路显然是一个独特的行业，具有独特的经济性和独立的价值链。铁路的任何合理战略都必须考虑到这些差异。将行业定义为运输可能会很危险，因为这会导致管理人员得出结论，他们需要收购一家空运公司，以便在多种运输形式中竞争。

Another common mistake is getting the definition of the business wrong, or getting the geographic scope wrong. There has been a tendency to define industries broadly, following the influential work of Theodore Levitt some decades ago. His famous example was railroads that failed to see that they were in the transportation business, and so they missed the threat posed by trucks and airfreight. The problem with defining the business as transportation, however, is that railroads are clearly a distinct industry with distinct economics and a separate value chain. Any sound strategy in railroads must take these differences into account. Defining the industry as transportation can be dangerous if it leads managers to conclude that they need to acquire an airfreight company so they can compete in multiple forms of transportation.

同样，人们也倾向于将只涉及国家或仅涵盖邻国的行业定义为全球性行业。企业在全球化浪潮的推动下，在没有真正了解其业务的经济效益的情况下就走向了国际化。价值链是划定竞争地理边界的主要工具，可以确定该业务的本地化程度或全球化程度。在本地业务中，每个本地区域都需要一条完整且基本独立的价值链。另一个极端是全球性行业，其价值链中的重要活动可以在所有国家共享。

Similarly, there has been a tendency to define industries as global when they are national or encompass only groups of neighboring countries. Companies, mindful of the drumbeat about globalization, internationalize without understanding the true economics of their business. The value chain is the principal tool to delineate the geographic boundaries of competition, to determine how local or how global that business is. In a local business, every local area will require a complete and largely separate value chain. At the other extreme, a global industry is one where important activities in the value chain can be shared across all countries.

然而，回顾我的经验，我不得不说，最糟糕的错误——也是最常见的错误——就是根本没有战略。大多数高管都认为他们有战略，但实际上他们没有，至少没有符合任何严格、经济基础定义的战略。

Reflecting on my experience, however, I’d have to say that the worst mistake—and the most common one—is not having a strategy at all. Most executives think they have a strategy when they really don’t, at least not a strategy that meets any kind of rigorous, economically grounded definition.

 

最严重也是最常见的错误就是根本没有战略。大多数高管都认为自己有战略，但实际上并没有。

The worst mistake—and the most common one—is not having a strategy at all. Most executives think they have a strategy when they really don’t.

 

马格雷塔：为什么会这样？为什么很少有公司拥有真正出色的战略？制定良好战略的最大障碍是什么？

Magretta: Why is that? Why do so few companies have really great strategies? What are the biggest obstacles to good strategy?

波特：我过去认为，大多数战略问题都源于数据有限或有误，或者对行业和竞争对手的分析不够充分。换句话说，我认为问题在于未能理解竞争。这种情况确实存在。但我在这个领域工作的时间越长，我就越能意识到，清晰的战略思维所面临的障碍越微妙、越普遍，企业要想长期维持其战略是多么困难。

Porter: I used to think that most strategy problems arose from limited or faulty data, or poor analysis of the industry and competitors. To say it differently, I thought the problem was a failure to understand competition. This surely does happen. But the more I have worked in this field, the more I have come to appreciate the more subtle and more pervasive obstacles to clear strategic thinking and how challenging it is for companies to maintain their strategies over time.

有太多的障碍分散、阻碍和转移管理者做出明确的战略选择。一些最重要的障碍来自内部系统、组织结构和决策过程中隐藏的偏见。例如，通常很难获得进行战略思考所需的成本信息。或者公司的激励制度奖励错误的东西。或者人性使得做出权衡或坚持权衡变得非常困难。权衡的需要是一个巨大的障碍。大多数管理者讨厌做出权衡；他们讨厌接受限制。他们几乎总是宁愿尝试服务更多客户，提供更多功能。他们无法抗拒相信这将带来更多增长和更多利润。

There are so many barriers that distract, deter, and divert managers from making clear strategic choices. Some of the most significant barriers come from the many hidden biases embedded in internal systems, organizational structures, and decision-making processes. It’s often hard, for example, to get the kind of cost information you need to think strategically. Or the company’s incentive system rewards the wrong things. Or human nature makes it really hard to make trade-offs, or to stick with them. The need for trade-offs is a huge barrier. Most managers hate to make trade-offs; they hate to accept limits. They’d almost always rather try to serve more customers, offer more features. They can’t resist believing that this will lead to more growth and more profit.

我认为许多公司破坏了自己的战略。没有人这样做。这是他们自己造成的。他们的战略失败是内部原因。

I believe that many companies undermine their own strategies. Nobody does it to them. They do it themselves. Their strategies fail from within.

然后，外部环境中还有许多战略杀手。从所谓的行业专家到监管者和金融分析师，他们都倾向于将公司推向我所说的“争当最佳”——分析师希望每家公司都看起来像当前市场最受欢迎的公司，顾问帮助你将自己与行业中的其他人进行对比，或者推动下一个重大事件，例如你应该取悦并留住每一位客户的想法。

Then there is the host of strategy killers in the external environment. These range from so-called industry experts to regulators and financial analysts. These all tend to push companies toward what I call “competition to be the best”—the analyst who wants every company to look like the current market favorite, the consultant who helps you benchmark yourself against everyone else in the industry, or who pushes the next big thing, such as the notion that you’re supposed to delight and retain every single customer.

让我们以最后这个观点为例。如果你听取每个顾客的意见并按照他们的要求去做，你就不可能制定战略。就像很多向经理们推销的想法一样，它有一定道理，但细微差别却被忽略了。战略并不是让每个顾客都满意。当你戴上战略家的帽子时，你要决定要满足哪些顾客和哪些需求。至于其他顾客和其他需求，好吧，你只需要克服你会让他们失望的事实，因为这实际上是一件好事。

Let’s take this last idea as an example. If you listen to every customer and do what they ask you to do, you can’t have a strategy. Like so many ideas that get sold to managers, there is some truth to it, but the nuances get lost. Strategy is not about making every customer happy. When you’ve got your strategist’s hat on, you want to decide which customers and which needs you want to meet. As to the other customers and the other needs, well, you just have to get over the fact that you will disappoint them, because that’s actually a good thing.

我还认为，随着资本市场的发展，它们对战略的破坏性越来越强。一心一意追求股东价值（以短期衡量）对战略和价值创造具有极大的破坏性。管理者正在追求错误的目标。

I also believe that as capital markets have evolved they have become more and more toxic for strategy. The single-minded pursuit of shareholder value, measured over the short term, has been enormously destructive for strategy and value creation. Managers are chasing the wrong goal.

 

资本市场对战略产生了毒害。一味追求股东价值……对战略和价值创造具有极大的破坏性。

Capital markets have become toxic for strategy. The single-minded pursuit of shareholder value . . . has been enormously destructive for strategy and value creation.

 

这些只是一些障碍。累积起来，它们就成了障碍。制定战略本身就很难。维持战略就更难了。

These are just some of the obstacles. Cumulatively, they add up. Having a strategy in the first place is hard. Maintaining a strategy is even harder.

马格雷塔：您能详细阐述一下资本市场如何影响战略吗？

Magretta: Would you elaborate on how the capital markets impact strategy?

波特：这是一个多方面的问题。我们先从金融分析师和投资者群体评估公司的方式开始。对于任何行业，分析师都倾向于确定一套相关指标。例如，如果是零售业，则是同店销售额。在另一个行业，可能是每位员工的收入。当然，尝试找到能够告诉你公司情况的指标是件好事。但战略的问题在于，相同的指标适用于行业中的所有公司。战略的一个重要教训是，如果你追求不同的定位，那么不同的指标将是相关的。如果你强迫每个人都在相同的指标上取得进步，那么你就会鼓励趋同并破坏战略独特性。

Porter: This is a multifaceted problem. Let’s start with the way financial analysts and the investor community evaluate companies. For any industry, analysts tend to settle on a set of relevant metrics. If it’s retailing, for example, it’s same-store sales. In another industry, it might be revenue per employee. Of course, it’s good to try to find measures that tell you what’s going on in a company. But the problem for strategy is that the same metrics are applied to all companies in the industry. One of the important lessons about strategy is that if you’re pursuing a different positioning, then different metrics will be relevant. And if you force everybody to show progress on the same metrics, you encourage convergence and undermine strategic uniqueness.

在另一个层面上，资本市场的参与者在任何时候都倾向于找出“赢家”。通常是那些看起来表现良好的公司，可能是因为增长速度更快，或者最近几个季度的盈利能力更好。对于分析师来说，这成为了黄金标准，然后业内所有公司都面临着复制当前行业宠儿所做的事情的压力。如果宠儿是辉瑞，而辉瑞一直在进行收购，那么业内其他所有人都面临着进行收购的压力。关注辉瑞。做一些交易。

At another level, at any moment in time there’s a tendency for the players in the capital markets to identify a “winner.” Typically it’s the company that seems to be doing well, maybe because it’s growing a bit faster, or its profitability the last few quarters has been better. For the analysts, this becomes the gold standard, and then all the companies in the industry are pressured to replicate what the current industry favorite is doing. If the favorite is Pfizer, and Pfizer has been making acquisitions, then everyone else in the industry is pressured to make acquisitions. Follow Pfizer. Do some deals.

现在经常发生的情况是，当前最受欢迎的公司最终会失宠，但通常不会在分析师将所有人都引向同一条道路之前发生。当然，在战略中没有一条最佳道路。战略的本质是开辟自己的道路。你想跑自己的比赛以达到一个独特的终点，这就是你选择创造价值的方式。因此，资本市场以这种方式强化了竞争以求最好的心态。他们把自己设定为“最佳”的仲裁者。

Now it often happens that the current favorite eventually falls out of favor, but usually not before the analysts have herded everyone down the same path. And, of course, in strategy there is no one best path. The essence of strategy is to create your own path. You want to run your own race to reach a distinctive endpoint, which is the way you choose to create value. So in this way the capital markets reinforce the mind-set of competition to be the best. And they set themselves up as the arbiter of what “the best” is.

在第三个层面，市场活动的重心已向短期交易而非长期投资倾斜。人们快速进出股票市场，试图从微小的差距和不连续性中获利。但战略需要更长的时间范围。在市场上建立独特的地位需要一系列长期投资。那么这种不匹配的后果是什么？如果需要几年时间才能建立收益，但只需几个月就可以买到收益，那么为什么不选择更快的路径，特别是如果你可以在交易结束后方便地忘记你注销的无形资产。交易存在强烈的偏见。那么，从最广泛的层面来看，市场对短期表现的关注与支持投资建立战略地位的长期范围之间存在不匹配。

At a third level, the weight of activity in the markets has gravitated toward short-term trading versus long-term investing. People move in and out of stocks quickly, trying to profit from small gaps and discontinuities. But strategy needs a longer time horizon. Building out a unique position in the market takes a series of investments over time. So what are the consequences of this mismatch? If it’s going to take a few years to build earnings, but only a few months to buy them, then why not take the quicker path, especially if you can conveniently forget about the intangibles you’re writing off after the deal closes. There’s a strong bias for doing deals. At the broadest level, then, there’s a mismatch between the market’s focus on near-term performance and the longer time horizon that would support investment in building a strategic position.

过去几十年来，管理层一直强调股东价值，但他们的关注点却错了，他们真正应该关注的是长期可持续地创造经济价值。资本市场更善于推动 OE，更善于向公司施压，使其提高效率和盈利能力，更好地利用资本——这些都是积极的影响。但我毫不怀疑，市场会损害战略，即使这种影响是微妙的，而且大多未被意识到。

The whole emphasis on shareholder value over the past couple of decades has focused managers on the wrong thing when they should really be focusing on creating economic value sustainably over the long term. The capital markets are better at driving OE, better at keeping pressure on companies to improve efficiency and profitability and to use capital better—these are positive influences. But I have no doubt that the markets damage strategy, even if the impact is subtle and mostly unrecognized.

二、增长：机遇与陷阱

II. Growth: Opportunities and Pitfalls

 

马格雷塔：资本市场给管理者施加压力，要求他们发展。但您发现，这种压力可能会对战略产生不利影响。如何在不损害战略的情况下发展业务？

Magretta: The capital markets pressure managers to grow. But you’ve observed that this pressure can have a perverse effect on strategy. How do you grow a business without undermining your strategy?

波特：这是一个大问题。增长压力是战略面临的最大威胁之一。我指的是企业内部的增长，而不是多元化，多元化同样具有挑战性。很多公司都认为，任何增长都是好的增长。他们往往会过度增长，增加产品线、细分市场或地域，从而模糊独特性、制造妥协、降低契合度，最终削弱竞争优势。

Porter: This is a huge problem. The pressure to grow is among the greatest threats to strategy. And I’m referring here to growth within a business, not diversification, which is equally challenging. Too often, companies believe that any growth is good growth. They have a tendency to overshoot, by adding product lines, market segments, or geographies that blur uniqueness, create compromises, reduce fit, and ultimately undermine competitive advantage.

 

增长压力是战略面临的最大威胁之一。

The pressure to grow is among the greatest threats to strategy.

 

我的建议是集中精力深化和扩展战略地位，而不是扩大并最终损害它。以下是关于如何在不破坏战略的情况下实现盈利增长的一些想法。

My advice is to concentrate on deepening and extending a strategic position rather than broadening and ultimately compromising it. Here are some thoughts about how to grow profitably without destroying your strategy.

首先，不要抄袭。公司总是面临着推出新产品、新服务或进入相邻客户群的机会。你应该如何看待这一点？如果你的竞争对手有一个好主意，那就从中学习，想想这种创新能带来什么，但不要只是抄袭它。弄清楚如何调整和修改这个想法以强化你的战略。它与你想要满足的需求相关吗？它能用来强化你的独特之处吗？你不必紧跟每一个趋势。但如果趋势是相关的，那就根据你的战略来调整它。

First, never copy. Companies always are confronted with opportunities for new products, new services, or moving into adjacent customer groups. How should you think about that? If your competitor has a good idea, learn from it, think about what that innovation accomplishes, but don’t just copy it. Figure out how the idea could be adapted and modified in order to reinforce your strategy. Is it relevant to the needs you’re trying to serve? Could it be used to reinforce what makes you unique? You don’t have to jump on every trend. But if the trend is relevant, tailor it to your strategy.

第二，要深化战略地位，而不是扩大它。一家公司通常可以通过更好地渗透其独特之处的需求和客户来增长更快，而且利润更高，而不是在公司缺乏独特性的潜在高增长领域中苦苦挣扎。因此，寻求增长的第一步是深化对核心目标客户的渗透。常见的错误是满足于目标细分市场的 50%，而 80% 是可以实现的。当客户目标被正确定义为您的战略最能满足的客户和需求的集合而不是整个行业时，您就可以争取真正的领导地位。

Second, deepen your strategic position, don’t broaden it. A company can usually grow faster—and far more profitably—by better penetrating needs and customers where it is distinctive than by slugging it out in potentially higher growth arenas in which the company lacks uniqueness. So the first place to look for growth is to deepen your penetration of your core target of customers. The common mistake is to settle for 50 percent of your target segment when 80 percent is achievable. You can shoot for true leadership when the customer target is properly defined not as the whole industry, but as the set of customers and needs that your strategy serves best.

深入发展可以让你充分利用所有优势并提高盈利能力。以这种方式深化战略地位包括使公司的活动更加独特、增强契合度，以及更好地向那些明显受益于你独特业务的客户传达战略。在你没有优势的另一个细分市场中获得 10% 的份额通常会损害你的盈利能力。

Going deeper allows you to leverage all your advantages and improve profitability. Deepening a strategic position in this way involves making the company’s activities more distinctive, strengthening fit, and communicating the strategy better to those customers who clearly benefit from what you uniquely do. Gaining 10 percent share in another segment where you have no advantage will often damage your profitability.

第三，有针对性地进行地域扩张。如果你已经抓住了国内的战略机遇，那么世界其他地方也同样有你的选择。

Third, expand geographically in a focused way. If you’ve penetrated your strategic opportunity at home, there’s always the rest of the world.

马格雷塔：关于开拓国外市场您还有什么建议吗？

Magretta: Any further advice about tackling foreign markets?

波特：当你进入国外市场时，请记住你并不是要服务整个市场。你要寻找的是重视你所做之事的细分市场。因此，当你进入西班牙时，不要试图像现有的西班牙公司那样竞争。去寻找那些与你最相配的客户。他们最初可能不是市场的主要组成部分，但可以随着时间的推移逐渐壮大。地域扩张的妙处在于，你可以用同样的策略实现增长。你不必为国内客户提供你无法很好满足其需求的客户。

Porter: When you go to a foreign market, remember that you’re not trying to serve the whole market. You’re looking for the segment that values what you do. So when you go to Spain, don’t try to compete like existing Spanish companies. Go find those customers who are in your sweet spot. They might not be a big part of the market initially, but can be built up over time. The wonderful thing about geographic expansion is that you can grow with the same strategy. You don’t have to serve customers at home whose needs you don’t meet very well.

但你必须真正集中精力，因为地域扩张的趋势是过于关注新市场中存在的差异。找到新市场中对你所做的反应的部分，而不是试图适应所有的差异。

But you have to be really focused, because the tendency in geographic expansion is to get too caught up in the differences present in the new market. Find the part of the new market that responds to what you do rather than try to adapt to all the differences.

成功国际化的另一个关键特征是你必须直接与客户联系。通过别人的分销渠道很难开展业务。你永远无法了解客户的需求，你永远无法让自己与众不同。如果别人代表你的产品并倾听客户的意见，你怎么能制定战略呢？

Another key characteristic of successful internationalization is that you’ve got to get direct contact with the customer. It’s hard to work through somebody else’s distribution channels. You’ll never understand the customer needs, you’ll never be able to differentiate and distinguish yourself. If somebody else is representing your product and listening to customers, how can you have a strategy?

在进行收购和整合时要特别小心。你买下一家西班牙公司，他们告诉你的都是西班牙的运作方式。经济学家研究兼并已有二十年，他们发现卖方获得大部分价值，而不是买方。外国收购必须围绕你的战略进行强制重新定位，而不能继续他们的战略（当然，除非他们的战略更好！）。

And be especially careful when making and integrating acquisitions. You buy a Spanish company and all you’re going to hear from them is how things are done in Spain. Economists have been studying mergers for twenty years and they find that the seller gets most of the value, not the buyer. Foreign acquisitions must be forcefully repositioned around your strategy, not allowed to continue theirs (unless, of course, theirs is better!).

但如果您以正确的方式进行，地理扩张实际上可以成为利用和发展您的战略的一种非常强大的方式。

But geographic expansion can actually be a very powerful way of leveraging and growing your strategy if you do it the right way.

马格雷塔：如果这些增长方法都不可行，那么您会怎么做？

Magretta: And what do you do if none of those approaches to growth are feasible?

波特：这是一个重要的问题，但很少有管理者愿意面对。有时，到最后，答案是，几乎没有机会通过你的战略快速发展并实现盈利。你在自己的领域占据了强势地位，但没有很好的办法来大幅扩张。在这里，最大的错误就是否认这一现实，试图把铅变成金。相反，你应该简单地实现良好的投资回报率，支付良好的股息或以其他方式回报资本，并享受创造价值和财富的乐趣。

Porter: That’s an important question that too few managers are willing to face. Sometimes, at the end of the day, the answer is that there are few opportunities to grow rapidly with your strategy and do it profitably. You’ve got a strong position in your space, and no good way to expand it significantly. Here, the huge mistake is to deny that reality and to try to turn lead into gold. Instead, you should simply make a good ROIC, pay good dividends or otherwise return capital, and enjoy creating value and wealth.

我认为，更多的公司应该支付更高的股息，而不是冒着巨大的风险，试图超越其战略和行业结构的能力。不要让自己陷入失败。支付股息多年前就不再受欢迎了。它成为管理团队缺乏想象力的信号。这就是美国在线时代华纳和其他许多破坏价值的增长计划和交易的兴起的原因。股息的好处在于它与经济价值相一致。除非你创造了经济价值，否则你不能支付股息，这表明你在如何竞争方面做出了正确的选择。

I think many more companies should pay higher dividends rather than take enormous risks trying to grow beyond the capacity of their strategy and their industry structure. Don’t set yourself up for failure. Paying dividends fell out of favor years ago. It became a signal that the management team had no imagination. And that’s what gives rise to AOL Time Warner and so many other value-destroying growth plans and deals. The nice thing about dividends is that they’re aligned with economic value. You can’t pay a dividend unless you create economic value and that’s a sign you’re actually making good choices about how to compete.

三、战略与创新

III. Strategy and Innovation

 

马格雷塔：如今，行业界限似乎变化得如此之快。行业真的还重要吗？

Magretta: Industry boundaries seem to change so fast these days. Does industry really still matter?

波特：琼，你的问题有两个答案。一个是纯粹经验性的。当你查看行业盈利能力的数据时，它会告诉你，不同行业之间的相对盈利能力差异非常持久。你可以查看五年、十年甚至十五年的数据，你会发现，行业盈利能力的排名顺序几乎没有太大变化。几十年来，航空业一直处于榜单底部附近。IT 软件一直处于榜单顶部附近。这些关系相当稳定。因此，数据告诉我们，行业差异的变化相当缓慢。

Porter: There are two answers to your question, Joan. One is purely empirical. When you look at the data on industry profitability, it tells you that relative profitability differences across industries are remarkably durable. You can look at the data over five years, ten years, even fifteen years, and what you see is that the rank order of industries by their profitability simply doesn’t change very much. The airline industry has been down near the bottom of the list for decades. IT software has been up near the top. Those relationships are quite stable. So the data tells us that industry differences are pretty slow to change.
