但我们也知道，行业确实在经历结构性变化，有时不连续性会改变行业边界和结构，从而影响盈利能力。这些事情确实会发生。但它们是例外，而不是常态。即使发生了这样的转变，它们的进展也相对缓慢。互联网在改变少数行业的行业边界和结构方面具有变革性。但即使在互联网领域，绝大多数行业也能够拥抱互联网并继续前进。即使在信息密集型行业（如维护、维修和运营分销），互联网影响深远，竞争对手也没有改变，基本结构也没有改变。

But we also know that industries do undergo structural change and there are discontinuities that sometimes shift industry boundaries and structure in ways that impact profitability. Those things happen. But they are the exception and not the rule. And even when shifts like that do happen, they unfold relatively slowly. The Internet was transformational in changing industry boundaries and structure in a few industries. But even in the Internet space, the great majority of industries were able to embrace the Internet and move on. Even in information-intensive industries like maintenance, repair, and operations distribution, where the Internet was profound, the competitors didn’t change, the fundamental structure didn’t change.

关于行业是否仍然重要这一问题的第二个答案是：即使行业界限发生变化，分析变化意义的工具也是相同的。因此，五种力量仍然重要。我们经历了一个历史性的放松管制、全球化和技术进步的时期。一些行业界限已经模糊或发生了变化。但这并不能改变每个行业都有其独特结构的事实，而五种力量的独特配置决定了该行业竞争的性质。

The second answer to your question about whether industry still matters is this: Even where industry boundaries are changing, the same tools are used to analyze the significance of the change. So the five forces still matter. We have been through a historic period of deregulation, globalization, and technology advances. Some industry boundaries have blurred or shifted. But that doesn’t change the fact that every industry has its distinct structure, and its peculiar configuration of the five forces drives the nature of competition in that industry.

您会发现，一个或多个力量受到某些因素的显著影响——例如买方、供应商的变化、进入壁垒的中断等。因此，同样的工具适用于任何时刻。如果您想了解哪些趋势对您的行业很重要，请看看这些趋势可能会如何改变结构的某些基本方面。

You see that one or more of the forces have been significantly affected by some factor—a change on the buyer side, on the supplier side, some discontinuity in the entry barriers, for example. So the same tools apply at any moment in time. If you’re trying to understand which trends are going to be important in your industry, look to see how those trends might change some fundamental aspect of structure.

那些认为行业结构不再重要的人很可能就是那些认为每一项新技术或管理创新都是“颠覆性”的人。但你必须小心，因为数据根本不支持这种观点。

People who believe that industry structure no longer matters are likely to be the same people who see every new technology or management innovation as “disruptive.” But you’ve got to be careful because the data simply doesn’t support that view.

马格雷塔：什么是颠覆性技术？它与你的战略思想有何交集？

Magretta: What is a disruptive technology? Where does it intersect with your thinking about strategy?

波特：这个观点确实有用，也非常引人注目，但人们却严重误用和误解了它，认为它适用于所有竞争威胁。管理者最好只用这个术语来描述真正改变游戏规则的、不太常见的情况。

Porter: This is a really useful and compelling idea, but it is badly misused and misunderstood to refer to any and every competitive threat. It would be more helpful for managers to use the term only for the far less common situation of real game changers.

颠覆性技术并非任何新技术。许多新技术并不具有颠覆性。它也不是什么重大的技术飞跃，因为许多重大飞跃并不具有颠覆性。颠覆性技术是一种使价值链配置和产品配置失效的技术，它允许一家公司超越另一家公司，或使现有企业难以匹敌或做出回应，因为它们拥有现有资产。因此，颠覆性技术是一种会使重要竞争优势失效的技术。

A disruptive technology is not any new technology. Many new technologies are not disruptive. Nor is it any big technological leap, because many big leaps are not disruptive. A disruptive technology is one that invalidates value chain configurations and product configurations in ways that allow one company to leap ahead of another and/or make it hard for incumbents to match or respond because of the existing assets they have. So a disruptive technology is one that would invalidate important competitive advantages.

互联网就是一个典型的例子。当信息传递机制是产品或服务的基础，而业务本质上是传递机制时，互联网就具有颠覆性。例如旅行社或唱片业。但在其他情况下，互联网并不具有颠覆性，因为它只是与客户或供应商沟通的又一个渠道。在这些情况下，拥有最佳产品系列和品牌的知名公司能够轻松采用新技术。它与他们所做的任何事情都不矛盾或不一致。

The Internet offers a classic case. It was disruptive where the mechanism for delivering information was fundamental to the product or service, where the business, in essence, was the delivery mechanism. Travel agents, for example, or the recorded music business. But in other cases, the Internet wasn’t disruptive because it was simply one more channel for communicating with customers or suppliers. In those cases, established companies with the best product sets and brands were simply able to incorporate the new technology. It wasn’t incompatible or inconsistent with anything they were doing.

两个问题可以告诉你，你面对的是否是颠覆性技术。首先，它在多大程度上使重要的传统优势失效？其次，在位者在多大程度上可以接受这项技术而不会对其业务产生重大负面影响？如果你停下来问这些问题，你会发现真正的颠覆并不常见。例如，如果你回顾过去十年构成经济的数百个行业，我猜只有不到 5% 到 10% 的行业会受到颠覆性技术的影响。

Two questions will tell you whether you’re dealing with a disruptive technology or not. First, to what extent does it invalidate important traditional advantages? Second, to what extent can incumbents embrace the technology without major negative consequences for their business? If you stop and ask those questions, you’ll see that true disruptions are not so common. If you look over a decade, for example, at the hundreds of industries that make up the economy, I would guess that less than 5 to 10 percent would be affected by a disruptive technology.

话虽如此，管理者当然应该警惕潜在的颠覆性变化。他们得到的建议往往只关注一种形式的颠覆：一种更简单、成本更低的技术得到改进，并变得足够好，可以满足目前由更复杂、成本更高的技术满足的需求。因此，大多数管理者寻找来自下层的威胁，来自一些你一直认为与你的业务无关的新兴企业。然后你惊恐地发现，对于很多客户来说，新兴企业已经足够好了。用我的价值主张术语来说，客户的需求被“旧”技术过度满足了。新技术以合适的价格满足了他们足够的需求。来自下层的颠覆是焦点战略的一个例子。如果你专注于那些不需要所有特殊花哨功能的客户，你就可以建立一个滩头阵地。拥有颠覆性技术的聚焦者可以进入你的行业，并最终成长为一个主要地位。这就是西南航空的故事。

Having said that, managers should of course be on the lookout for potentially disruptive changes. The advice they get tends to focus on just one form of disruption: a simpler and less costly technology is improved and gets good enough to serve a need that’s currently met by a more complex and more costly technology. So most managers look for the threat to come from below, from some upstart you’ve been dismissing as being irrelevant to your business. And then you learn to your horror that for a lot of customers, the upstart is good enough. To use my value proposition terms, the customers’ needs were being overserved by the “old” technology. The new one meets just enough of their needs at the right price. Disruption from below is an example of a focus strategy. If you focus on the customers who don’t need all the special bells and whistles, you can establish a beachhead. A focuser with a disruptive technology can enter your industry and ultimately grow to occupy a major position. This is the Southwest Airlines story.

但其他形式的颠覆在战略中也发挥着作用。威胁可能来自上层。你可以拥有先进的技术或更丰富的方法，它们可以发挥高水平的性能，但可以简化或精简以满足不太复杂的需求，而且成本要低得多。我们没有充分的证据表明哪种形式最为普遍，但两种形式都存在。颠覆性技术作为一个比喻很有说服力，但管理者需要严格了解造成颠覆的原因。它如何影响价值链？相对价格？相对成本？战略基本原理在这里绝对适用。

But other forms of disruption play a role in strategy. The threat can come from above. You can have an advanced technology or a richer approach that performs at a high level but that can be simplified or streamlined to meet less sophisticated needs at much lower cost. We don’t have good evidence on which form is most prevalent, but both exist. Disruptive technology is compelling as a metaphor, but managers need to be rigorous about what’s creating the disruption. How does it impact the value chain? Relative price? Relative cost? The strategy fundamentals definitely apply here.

 

颠覆性技术作为一个比喻很引人注目，但管理者需要严谨地了解造成颠覆的因素。

Disruptive technology is compelling as a metaphor, but managers need to be rigorous about what’s creating the disruption.

 

Magretta：商业媒体对“商业模式”一词给予了高度关注，尤其是在创新型新企业的背景下。商业模式和战略是一回事吗？

Magretta: The term “business model” gets a lot of attention in the business press, especially in the context of innovative new businesses. Is a business model the same thing as a strategy?

波特： “商业模式”一词被广泛使用，但并没有精确的定义。因此，与“战略”一词一样，不幸的是，它对不同的人可能意味着很多不同的东西。但我认为，这个概念在这里很有用。如果你正在创办一家新企业，但还不确定它是否或如何运作，商业模式概念可以帮助你专注于最基本的问题：我们如何赚钱？我们的成本是多少？我们的收入从何而来？这项业务如何盈利？有多种不同的收入获取方式和管理成本的方式，而商业模式视角可以帮助你探索这些方式。

Porter: The term “business model” is widely used, but it’s not precisely defined. So as with the word “strategy,” it unfortunately can mean a lot of different things to different people. But here’s where I think the concept can be useful. If you’re starting a new business and you’re not yet sure whether or how it’s going to work, the business model concept helps you to focus in on the most basic question of all: How are we going to make money? What will our costs look like? Where will our revenue come from? How can this business be profitable? There are different ways of getting revenue and different ways of managing costs, and the business model lens can help you to explore those.

但是商业模式并不能帮助你开发或评估竞争优势，而这正是战略的目的所在。战略超越了基本的生存能力问题：我们能赚钱吗？战略提出了一个更复杂的问题：我们如何才能比竞争对手赚更多的钱，如何才能获得更高的回报，然后，我们如何才能长期保持这种优势？商业模式强调了你的收入和成本之间的关系。战略更进了一步。它考察相对价格和相对成本，以及它们的可持续性。也就是说，你的收入和成本与竞争对手相比如何。然后，它将这些与你的价值链中的活动联系起来，并最终与你的损益表和资产负债表联系起来。

But the business model doesn’t help you to develop or to assess competitive advantage, which is what strategy aims to do. Strategy goes beyond the basic viability question, Can we make money? Strategy asks a more complicated question, How can we make more money than our rivals, how can we generate superior returns, and then, How can we sustain that advantage over time? A business model highlights the relationship between your revenues and your costs. Strategy goes an important step further. It looks at relative prices and relative costs, and their sustainability. That is, how your revenues and costs stack up against your rivals’. And then it links those to the activities in your value chain, and ultimately to your income statement and your balance sheet.

因此，商业模式最好是作为思考公司可行性的最基本步骤。如果你满足于仅仅具有可行性，那就到此为止吧。如果你想实现卓越的盈利能力（或避免低劣的盈利能力）并保持可行性，那么战略（我定义它）将带你进入下一个层次。

So the business model is best used as the most basic step in thinking about the viability of a company. If you’re satisfied with just being viable, stop there. If you want to achieve superior profitability (or avoid inferior profitability) and stay viable, then strategy—as I define it—will take you to the next level.

 

商业模式是思考公司可行性的最基本步骤。如果你满足于仅仅具有可行性，那就到此为止吧。如果你想实现卓越的盈利能力，那么战略——正如我所定义的——将带你进入下一个阶段。

The business model is the most basic step in thinking about the viability of a company. If you’re satisfied with just being viable, stop there. If you want to achieve superior profitability then strategy—as I define it—will take you to the next level.

 

马格雷塔：如果你是一名企业家，在一个全新的市场领域开创新业务，你该如何进行五力分析？当没有现成的行业，或者当条件仍然如此不稳定，没有明显的行业结构和直接竞争对手时，战略是否重要？

Magretta: How do you do a five forces analysis if you’re an entrepreneur starting a new business in a completely new market space? Is strategy even relevant when there’s no existing industry or when conditions are still so fluid that there is no discernible industry structure and no direct competitors?

波特：战略对于任何组织而言都至关重要，无论处于发展轨迹的哪个阶段。如何发展和维持竞争优势是每个组织要想成功和繁荣就必须回答的核心问题。在新兴行业中，有很多实验。最终的产品会是什么样子？分销系统会是什么样子？产品或服务范围会产生一个独立的行业吗？还是这个新想法会成为更大或现有行业的一部分？

Porter: Strategy is relevant for any organization at any point in its trajectory. How to develop and sustain a competitive advantage is the core question that every organization has to answer if it’s to be successful and to prosper. In emerging industries there’s a lot of experimentation. What will the product ultimately look like? What will the distribution system look like? Will the product or service scope produce a stand-alone industry, or will this new idea become part of a larger or existing industry?

事物形态的不确定性更多，但五力分析法基本相同，只有一点不同：你不是分析已经存在的事物，而是进行预测。你可能对五力分析法了解很多，但只有一种除外。你知道你的目标客户是谁。他们可能对价格敏感吗？你知道你的供应商是谁，或者他们可能是谁。他们会变得多强大？你知道替代品，并能确定可能的进入壁垒。你还没有真正的竞争对手。这就是你需要思考他们可能是谁的地方。竞争对手最有可能来自相邻行业吗？还是来自其他国家已经存在的公司？或者可能的竞争对手是新成立的公司？这些竞争对手可能如何竞争？因此，即使你正在开拓新的市场空间，你可能已经对五力分析法有了比你意识到的更多的了解。

There’s more uncertainty about the shape of things, but the five forces exercise is fundamentally the same with one big exception: instead of analyzing what already exists, you’re forecasting. And you probably know quite a lot about all of the five forces but one. You know the customers you’re targeting. Are they likely to be price sensitive? You know who your suppliers are or who they are likely to be. How powerful will they become? You know the substitutes and can identify the likely entry barriers. What you don’t have yet are actual rivals. That’s where you need to think through who those might be. Will the rivals most likely come from adjacent industries? Or from companies that already exist in other countries? Or will the likely rivals be new start-ups? How would each of these rivals be likely to compete? So even when you’re inventing new market space, you probably already know more about the five forces than you realize.

进行这样的分析很重要，因为如果你正在创造真正有价值的东西，就不要自欺欺人地认为没有人会跟随你。没有一个市场是没有竞争的，尽管这听起来不错。创新可以让你忽视竞争的想法是一个童话。所以你必须假设一旦有了行业，这个行业可能会如何形成。

Doing such analysis is important because if you’re creating something that’s truly valuable, don’t kid yourself that no one will follow you. There is no such thing as a market where competition is irrelevant, as nice as that might sound. The idea that innovation allows you to ignore competition is a fairy tale. So you have to have a hypothesis for how the industry might take shape once there is an industry.

早期，演进可以采取多种路径，你可以做出许多选择，这些选择将对行业的吸引力产生重要影响。随着时间的推移，你和其他人做出的决定将开始锁定基本的经济因素，使行业结构变得不那么灵活。因此，了解行业可能如何发展的不同路径，并提出有关五种力量的基本问题至关重要，这样你就可以做出选择，让行业走上最佳道路。

Early on, there are many paths the evolution can take, many choices you can make that will have an important impact on how attractive the industry will become. Decisions you and others make over time will begin to lock in the basic economics, making industry structure less fluid. So it’s crucial to see different paths for how the industry might evolve, and to ask the basic questions about the five forces, so that you can make choices that will put the industry on the best possible path.

四、特殊情况：缺乏吸引力的行业、发展中国家、非营利组织

IV. Special Cases: Unattractive Industries, Developing Countries, Nonprofits

 

马格雷塔：如果你的行业缺乏吸引力怎么办？你是否只能依靠这五种力量，或者你可以重塑它们，让它们对你有利？

Magretta: What if your industry is unattractive? Are you stuck with the five forces, or can you reshape them in your favor?

波特：任何行业的结构都受到一些基本经济因素的严重影响。航空业真正的利润杀手是低进入门槛和高退出门槛的极不寻常组合。这是一种非常罕见的力量组合。因此，创办一家新航空公司并不难，但如果公司倒闭了，飞机也不会消失。飞机是我们所说的可替代资产，也就是说，任何航空公司都可以在任何时候在任何航线上使用它们。因此，飞机可以更换所有权，但运力永远不会离开市场，除非飞机真的解体。如果你经营一家航空公司，一旦你获得了飞机、雇佣了员工并制定了时间表，那么固定成本就会非常高，而可变成本就会很低。因此，填满飞机的压力很大，而打折的压力也会很大。

Porter: The structure of any industry is heavily influenced by some underlying economics. The real profit killer for the airline industry has been the highly unusual combination of low entry barriers and high exit barriers. That’s a very rare configuration of forces. So it’s not all that hard to start a new airline, but if the company goes out of business, the airplanes don’t go away. Airplanes are what we call fungible assets, that is, they can be used by any carrier, on almost any route, at any time. So the plane can change ownership, but the capacity never leaves the market until the plane literally falls apart. If you’re running an airline, once you’ve acquired your planes, hired your staff, and set a schedule, then the fixed costs are enormous and the variable costs are low. Therefore there’s intense pressure to fill the plane, and pressure on discounting to do so.

这些因素决定了航空业的基本经济状况，并反映在行业结构中。如果大型飞机的每位乘客运营成本较低，那么就会推动航空业向大型飞机发展。这是基本经济因素。有时这些基本经济因素确实会发生变化。想象一下，如果有人发明了一种不同的飞机发动机，改变了经济状况，有人降低了小型飞机的驾驶惩罚。这将放宽经济限制。当你拥有一项颠覆经济的新技术时，就会发生这种情况。

These elements define the underlying economics of the industry and they are reflected in the industry structure. If larger planes have lower operating costs per passenger, that will push the industry toward larger aircraft. That’s fundamental economics. Sometimes these basic economics do change. Imagine if someone invented a different kind of airplane engine that changed the economics, that someone lowered the penalty for flying smaller planes. That would relax the economic constraints. That’s what happens when you have a new technology that upends the economics.

但行业结构的某些方面源自行业领导者的选择，这些选择会引导你走向一条或另一条道路。航空公司并没有预先设定任何因素要求行业采用收益管理，即根据你购买机票的具体时间对同一航班的同一座位设定不同的价格。这肯定看起来是一种聪明的填满座位的方法，但事实上，这对行业来说是一场灾难，它造成了永久的价格竞争，摧毁了行业的盈利能力。客户已经习惯了以最低价格购物。旅游网站的出现就是为了帮助他们做到这一点。这个行业创造了一个吞噬利润的怪物。收益管理是一种选择。它不是行业经济的必然结果。因此，你必须区分行业结构中真正固有的方面和由你的选择导致的方面，这些选择可能会被领导层修改。

But some aspects of industry structure result from choices that industry leaders make that lead you down one path or another. There was nothing foreordained in airlines that required the industry to embrace yield management, setting different prices for the identical seat on a flight because of the exact time you bought the ticket. It must have seemed like a smart way to fill seats, but it has, in fact, been a disaster for the industry, creating permanent price competition that has devastated industry profitability. The customer has been trained to shop for the lowest price. Travel sites have emerged to help them do just that. The industry created a profit-devouring monster. Yield management was a choice. It wasn’t an inevitable outcome of the industry’s economics. So you’ve got to separate the aspects of industry structure that are truly inherent from those that result from choices you make, choices that could be modified by leadership.

请继续听我说，因为这是一个微妙的观点，如果你想改变行业结构，你就希望引领整个行业朝着既定的方向发展。当你追求竞争优势时，你就希望独树一帜。当你试图改变行业结构时，你希望其他人都跟随你。

And, stay with me because this is a subtle point, if you are trying to change industry structure, you want to lead the whole industry in a given direction. When you’re going for competitive advantage, you’re trying to be unique. When you’re trying to change the industry structure, you want everyone else to follow you.

看看 Sysco 如何改变食品分销行业。这个行业客户分散，供应商强大，通常是大型品牌食品公司。进入门槛很低。竞争历来都是价格战，因为分销商基本上都在分销相同的产品。这是一个糟糕的结构。但一些行业领导者（例如 Sysco）希望进行不同类型的竞争。他们开始推出自有品牌，以削弱供应商的权力。他们加大了 IT 投资，这为无力承担这些投资的小型分销商设置了进入门槛。他们开始为客户提供增值服务，例如菜单和营养计划、库存管理和库存融资。这将竞争转移到价格以外的其他方面。在这里，模仿是一件好事。随着其他人效仿 Sysco，这个行业变得更具吸引力。

Consider how Sysco transformed the food distribution industry. This was an industry with fragmented customers and powerful suppliers, often the big branded food companies. Barriers to entry were low. Rivalry historically had been on price because basically the distributors were all distributing the same products. That’s a bad structure. But some of the industry leaders—Sysco, for example—wanted a different kind of competition. They started doing private label to mitigate the power of the suppliers. They ramped up their IT investments, which served as an entry barrier to the small distributors who would be unable to afford those investments. They started to provide value-added services to their customers such as menu and nutrition planning, inventory management, and inventory financing. This shifted competition to dimensions other than price alone. And here, imitation was a good thing. As others followed Sysco’s lead, the industry became more attractive.

马格雷塔：战略对于在发展中经济体运营的公司来说重要吗？同样的战略基本原则是否也适用？

Magretta: Is strategy important for companies operating in a developing economy? Do the same strategy fundamentals apply?

波特：发展中国家的企业通常拥有较低的要素成本，例如劳动力，这可能使他们在一段时间内能够与国外竞争对手竞争，即使他们在 OE 方面落后并且他们的产品没有特色。但要素成本优势往往会随着时间的推移而减弱，最终发展中国家的企业将需要解决这两个问题。

Porter: Companies in developing economies typically have lower factor costs, such as labor, and this might let them compete for a time with rivals outside the country even if they are behind in OE and their products are not distinctive. But factor cost advantages tend to diminish over time, and eventually companies in developing countries will need to address both of those issues.

首先，他们必须缩小 OE 差距。他们必须克服劳动力技能水平、技术和管理能力方面的不足。当公司面临充满障碍的商业环境（例如糟糕的物理基础设施和复杂的法规）时，达到世界一流的 OE 标准并提高成本和质量绩效是一项挑战。

First, they have to close the OE gap. They have to overcome deficits in workforce skill levels, technology, and management capabilities. Where companies face a business environment full of obstacles such as poor physical infrastructure and complex regulations, it’s a challenge to reach world-class standards in OE and to improve performance in cost and quality.

其次，他们必须开始制定真正的战略。最终这些企业将不得不与跨国公司竞争——而当地公司仅凭运营效率是不太可能取胜的。这是危地马拉 Pollo Campero 牢记在心的教训。Pollo Campero 在中美洲快餐市场与麦当劳、汉堡王和必胜客等巨头成功竞争。它通过调整其价值主张和价值链来满足当地中美洲的需求。它还迈出了下一步，扩大业务范围，以满足美国日益增长的西班牙裔市场的相同需求。

Second, they have to begin to develop real strategies. Eventually these businesses will have to compete with the multinationals—and it is highly unlikely that a local company will win on operational effectiveness alone. That’s a lesson which Guatemala-based Pollo Campero has taken to heart. Pollo Campero competes successfully in the Central American fast food market against giants such as McDonald’s, Burger King, and Pizza Hut. It does so by adapting its value proposition and its value chain to meet local Central American needs. It has also taken the next step, expanding to serve those same needs for a growing Hispanic market in the United States.

发展中经济体的企业最终必须从被动和投机取巧转变为更具战略性，专注于建立独特的地位，开发市场上与众不同的产品。这意味着要转移焦点，这样你就不会只依赖成本优势，而是要从价值的角度来思考，最好是市场上独一无二的价值。

Companies in developing economies must eventually transition away from being very reactive and opportunistic to become more strategic, to focus on building a unique position, on developing something distinctive in the market. This means shifting the focus so you’re not just relying on a cost advantage, but you’re thinking in terms of value, ideally of unique value in the marketplace.

地理范围是一个真正的问题。举个例子，如果你看看土耳其的数据，你会发现公司仍然过于国内化，过于专注于自己的市场，尽管这个市场正在增长。未来是国际化的，而这通常始于关注该地区。这通常会带来巨大的机会，而本地公司可能具有独特的优势来服务于这些机会。

And geographic scope is a real issue. If you look at the data in Turkey, to cite just one example, companies are still much too domestic, much too focused on their own market, even though it is growing. The future is to be international, and that often starts by looking at the region. This often presents a tremendous opportunity, which local companies may be uniquely positioned to serve.

我发现发展中国家和新兴经济体的一个问题是，人们往往过于关注欧洲和美国，而看不到在该地区销售的机会，这通常是因为过去不可能实现。该地区是封闭的，每个国家都受到保护，因此出口的唯一途径就是出口到发达经济体。但这种情况正在改变。发展中国家和新兴中等收入经济体的公司今天确实有历史性的机会开始走向国际化。因为他们可以渗透到区域市场，所以他们不必只渗透到发达市场。

One of the problems I see in developing and emerging economies is that people tend to be too focused on Europe and the United States, and really don’t see the opportunity of selling within their region, often because that wasn’t possible in the past. The region was closed, and every country was protected, and so the only way you could export was to export out to the advanced economies. But that’s changing. There’s really a historic opportunity for companies in developing and emerging middle-income economies to start to be international today. Because they can penetrate regional markets, they don’t have to penetrate only the advanced markets.

我看到的另一个问题是，公司往往非常多元化。它们仍然在很多截然不同的业务领域竞争。重要的是要认识到，何时应该放弃这种模式，而将更多的精力集中在业务集团上，这样你就可以把能够相互利用的业务组合在一起，从而增强你的竞争优势，使你的定位更加独特。如果新兴经济体的公司希望最终充分发挥其潜力，那么这是一个重要的转变。需要改变的不是人员素质，而是思维方式，思考如何建立业务的方法，简而言之，就是战略。

Another problem I see is that companies tend to be very diversified. They still compete in lots of businesses that are very different. It’s important to recognize when the time comes to put that model aside, and to move to greater focus in your business groups, where you can put together businesses that can leverage each other, which can enhance your competitive advantage, which can make your position more unique. That’s an important transition for companies in emerging economies if they hope eventually to realize their full potential. What has to change is not the quality of the people, but the mind-set, the approach to thinking about how to build a business, in short, about strategy.

 

对于非营利组织的管理者来说，做出权衡往往更加困难。

Making trade-offs often turns out to be harder for managers in nonprofits.

 

马格雷塔：非营利组织需要战略吗？非营利组织非常注重筹集资金、使命和服务客户​​。但他们不会在战略上花太多时间。他们应该花吗？非营利组织的战略是什么？

Magretta: Do nonprofits need strategy? Nonprofits focus a lot on raising money, on their mission, on serving their clients. But they don’t spend much time on strategy. Should they? What is strategy for a nonprofit organization?

波特：战略对于任何服务客户或满足需求的组织来说都是必要的。任何组织的良好战略都始于确定适当的目标。企业的基本目标是长期获得卓越的投资回报。实现这一目标的业绩表明公司是否在创造价值。对于非营利组织来说，没有直接可比的指标，所以你必须创建一个。每个非营利组织面临的一个主要挑战是，根据其寻求创造的社会效益来定义其目标。然后，它必须制定一个价值指标，以衡量所取得的成果与实现这些成果所需的成本。

Porter: Strategy is necessary for any type of organization that serves customers or meets needs. Good strategy for any organization starts with defining appropriate goals. The fundamental goal for a business is superior long-term return on investment. Performance against that goal tells you whether or not the company is creating value. For a nonprofit, there is no directly comparable metric, so you’ve got to create one. A major challenge for every nonprofit is to define its goal or goals in terms of the social benefits it seeks to create. And then it must develop a value metric that looks at the results achieved versus the costs required to achieve them.

一旦非营利组织明确了自己要做的事情，那么其他所有战略原则都可以应用。你服务的对象是哪些“客户”？你提供的独特价值是什么？你会满足哪些需求？你的价值链如何量身定制才能最好地满足这些需求？你是否在权衡各种替代方法？你知道你的组织不会做什么吗？

Once the nonprofit has a clear handle on what it’s trying to do, then all of the other strategy principles apply. What “customer” are you serving? What’s the unique value you will deliver? What needs will you meet? How is your value chain tailored to best serve those needs? Are you making trade-offs with alternative approaches? Do you know what your organization will not do?

做出权衡往往对非营利组织的管理者来说更加困难。如果你没有明确的价值指标来指导你，那么你很容易将你所做的几乎每件事都视为对“好事”的贡献。由于资助者通常不是客户，这可能导致资金和价值之间的错位。通过提供产品获得客户报酬的企业具有强大的价值锚定力。非营利组织缺乏这种锚定力。事实上，资助者有时是分心的主要原因。当资助者更愿意支持新计划和新举措，而不是提供运营资金来帮助你扩大已有业务时，非营利组织很容易出现使命偏离。这是许多非营利组织面临的共同战略挑战。

Making trade-offs often turns out to be harder for managers in nonprofits. If you don’t have clear value metrics to guide you, then it is easy to see almost everything you do as contributing to “good.” Because the funder is often not the customer, this can lead to a misalignment between funding and value. Businesses that get paid by customers for what they deliver are powerfully anchored to value. Nonprofits lack that kind of an anchor. Funders, in fact, are sometimes a major source of the distraction. Nonprofits are prone to mission creep when their funders are more willing to support new programs and initiatives than they are to provide operating funding to help you scale what you already do. It’s a common strategic challenge facing many nonprofits.

五、领导组织

V. Leading the Organization

 

马格雷塔：您对战略规划流程有什么建议？

Magretta: What’s your advice on the strategic planning process?

波特：我经常被问到战略思维和战略规划之间是否有区别。我的回答是，战略规划应该是进行战略思维的过程，但它往往成为一种耗时的仪式，实际上根本不支持战略思维。

Porter: I am often asked about whether there’s a difference between strategic thinking and strategic planning. My answer is that strategic planning should be a process for doing strategic thinking, but it often becomes a time-consuming ritual that really doesn’t support strategic thinking at all.

 

战略规划通常会变成一种耗时的仪式，实际上根本不支持战略思维。

Strategic planning often becomes a time-consuming ritual that really doesn’t support strategic thinking at all.

 

我认为成功的战略规划有几个关键。其一是你需要召集负责特定业务的整个团队，他们需要一起制定计划。你不能把工作分开，然后在最后把它们拼凑在一起。战略关乎整个企业，而不是各个部分。这是好战略的基本原则。没有所谓的好营销战略。只有在整体战略的背景下，才有好的营销战略。派人去做他们自己的职能计划的危险在于，你最终会得到一系列毫无关联的“最佳实践”，而不是一个连贯的战略。这就是为什么战略计划需要整个管理团队共同思考行业、竞争对手、机会、价值链，然后最终做出一些关于定位和方向的选择。然后，团队需要制定行动的影响。

I think there are a couple of keys to successful strategic planning. One is that you need to bring together the whole team responsible for a particular business, and they need to do the plan together. You can’t divide up the work and then try to staple it together at the end. Strategy is about the whole enterprise, not the individual pieces. That’s a foundational principle of good strategy. There’s no such thing as a good marketing strategy. There’s only a good marketing strategy in the context of the overall strategy. The danger with sending people off to do their own functional plans is that you’ll end up with a series of unconnected “best practices,” not a coherent strategy. That’s why a strategic plan needs to involve the whole management team working together to think about the industry, the competitors, the opportunities, the value chain, and then ultimately make some choices about positioning and direction. Then, the team needs to develop the implications for action.

我认为制定正式的战略规划流程大有裨益，否则，日常业务压力会驱赶战略。需要每年或每两年进行一次流程，然后进行季度审核。但你不能让它仅仅成为预算和对明年增长率的猜测。规划需要支持思考，而不是驱赶思考。

I believe it’s beneficial to have a formal strategic planning process because otherwise the day-to-day pressures of the business drive out strategy. There needs to be a process once every year or two, and then quarterly reviews. But you can’t let it be simply about budgeting and making guesses about next year’s growth rate. Planning needs to support thinking rather than drive it out.

马格雷塔：你如何让组织中的每个人都达成共识？

Magretta: How do you get everybody in the organization on the same page?

波特：传达战略非常重要。如果战略是个秘密，如果组织中没有人知道战略是什么，那么战略就毫无用处。战略的目的是协调组织中每个人的行为，并帮助他们在独立时做出正确的选择。这些选择每天都在发生——当你的销售人员决定拜访谁、进行什么样的推销时，当产品开发人员考虑要考虑什么样的新想法时。人们每天都在做选择。你希望他们做出符合战略的选择。所以你必须传达它。

Porter: Communicating the strategy is really important. Strategy is useless if it’s a secret, if nobody else in the organization knows what the strategy is. The purpose of strategy is to align the behavior of everyone in the organization and to help them make good choices when they’re on their own. Those choices happen every day—when your salesman is deciding who to call on and what pitch to give, when the folks in product development are thinking about what sort of new ideas to look at. People are out there, every day, making choices. You want them to make the choice that fits the strategy. So you’ve got to communicate it.

如何传达？你必须找到一种简洁且令人难忘的方式来解释你的战略。真正优秀的领导者会将价值主张具体化为相对简单的东西。然后他们帮助组织中的各个部门将其含义转化为每项活动。优秀的领导者是战略教授，因为他们一直在教授战略。他们会就战略进行大量简短的演讲。每次会议开始时，他们都会重复价值主张的精髓二十五遍。然后继续讨论会议的主题。员工对话总是从“我们作为一家公司代表什么？是什么让我们与众不同？我们有何独特之处？”开始，然后继续讨论。你不断重复，并鼓励你的下属也向他们的组织发表同样的演讲。如果你是总经理，重要的是参加你的下属试图解释战略的一些会议，并听取他们的表现，以确保人们真正理解它。

How do you communicate it? Well, you’ve got to find a concise and memorable way to explain your strategy. Really good leaders crystallize the value proposition into something relatively simple. And then they help individual units in the organization translate what that means for every activity. Good leaders are strategy professors, in the sense that they’re teaching strategy all the time. They’re giving lots of little talks about strategy. They start every meeting with the twenty-fifth repetition of the essence of the value proposition. Then it goes on to whatever the meeting is about. The employee dialogues always start with, What do we stand for as a company? What makes us distinctive? How are we unique? And it goes on from there. You’re constantly repeating and you’re encouraging your direct reports to also give the same speech to their organizations. It’s important, if you’re the general manager, to sit in on some of those meetings where your direct reports are trying to explain the strategy, and listen to see how they do, just to make sure that people really understand it.

我见过太多组织对战略的理解和共识都是肤浅的。每个人都可以在某个非常高的层面上达成共识，但当你深入了解细节时，你会发现人们实际上并不理解，他们也不同意。他们彼此之间各行其是。所以你必须创造一个机会来真正了解人们的思维方式并面对问题。

I’ve seen too many organizations where the understanding of the strategy and the agreement about it are superficial. Everyone can agree at some very high level, but then when you get into the detail, you see that people actually don’t understand, and they don’t agree. They act at cross-purposes to each other. So you’ve got to create an opportunity to really understand the way people think and to confront the issues.

我还认为，你应该向你的客户、供应商、渠道和资本市场传达你的战略。你必须帮助资本市场了解你将如何脱颖而出，以及他们应该使用哪些指标来了解你首先的优势以及你的战略进展如何。不要以为股票分析师会弄清楚。你必须告诉他们。

I also believe that you should communicate your strategy to your customers, to your suppliers, to your channels, and to the capital markets. You’ve got to help the capital markets understand how you’re going to be superior and what metrics they ought to be using to see, first of all, how you’re superior and how you’re progressing in your strategy. Don’t assume that stock analysts will figure it out. You’ve got to tell them.

如果你的竞争对手听到你发表关于战略的演讲，那就更好了。因为如果你有一个明确的战略，有权衡和选择，竞争对手越了解你致力于此，他们就越有可能做其他事情，避免面对面的竞争，因为在这种竞争中他们无法取胜。归根结底，我认为广泛沟通是唯一的方法。现在你不一定想告诉你的竞争对手你要买哪台机器，你什么时候推出新产品，以及所有可能让他们有能力给你制造麻烦的细节。但你要走的基本方向是另一回事。他们无论如何都会发现的，所以你最好用自己的话清楚地表达出来。

If your competitor hears you give a speech about your strategy, so much the better. Because if you have a clear strategy with trade-offs and choices, the more the competitor knows you’re committed to it, the more likely they are to do something else, to avoid head-to-head competition where they’re not going to be able to win. Ultimately, I think communicating widely is the only way to do it. Now you don’t necessarily want to tell your competitor which machine you’re going to buy and when you’re going to introduce a new product and all the details that might give them some ability to make things difficult for you. But the basic direction you’re going is something else. They’re going to find out anyway, so you might as well communicate it clearly in your own words.

最后，如果有人不接受战略，就是拒绝加入，他们就不能继续留在公司。这是说他们必须离开的委婉说法。你们之间不能长时间辩论战略。不能。即使有一支愿意的管理团队，也很难很好地实施。我见过太多高管让持不同意见的人坚持下去的案例。由此产生的负面能量、混乱和时间浪费确实损害了战略。人们有分歧是有益的，管理者应该有机会陈述自己的观点并改变想法，但总有一天讨论必须结束。这与民主、共识或让每个人都满意无关。从根本上说，这是关于选择一个方向，然后让每个人都对它感到兴奋。

And finally, if there are individuals who don’t accept the strategy, who simply refuse to get on board, they cannot have an ongoing role in the company. That’s a polite way of saying they’ve got to go. You can’t debate strategy among yourselves for very long. You just can’t. It’s too hard to implement well even with a willing management team. I’ve seen too many cases where executives just let the dissenters hang on. The resulting negative energy and confusion and waste of time really damage the strategy. It’s healthy for people to disagree and managers should be given a chance to make their case and to change minds, but there comes a time when the discussion has to end. It’s not about democracy, or consensus, or about making everyone happy. Fundamentally, it’s about picking a direction and then getting everybody really excited about it.

波特词汇表：关键概念

A Porter Glossary: Key Concepts

 

活动： 离散的经济过程，例如运营销售队伍、开发产品或向客户进行实物交付。活动通常涉及人员、技术、固定资产、有时还包括营运资本和各种类型的信息。公司开展的活动是竞争优势的基本单位，因为它们是相对成本和公司可为客户提供的差异化水平的最终来源。

activities: Discrete economic processes, such as operating a sales force, developing products, or physical delivery to the customer. An activity usually involves people, technology, fixed assets, sometimes working capital, and various types of information. The activities companies perform are the basic units of competitive advantage because they are the ultimate source of both relative costs and the levels of differentiation a company can offer its customers.

进入壁垒： 新进入者进入某个行业必须克服的障碍。进入壁垒低（即容易进入的行业）会降低行业的平均盈利能力。新进入者的威胁是五种力量之一。

barriers to entry: The hurdles a new entrant would have to surmount in order to enter an industry. Low entry barriers (i.e., industries that are easy to enter) lower the industry’s average profitability. The threat of new entrants is one of the five forces.

模仿障碍： 行业内竞争对手为复制其他公司的战略而试图从一个定位转移到另一个定位时面临的障碍。模仿障碍会减缓竞争融合的进程。

barriers to imitation: The hurdles facing a rival within an industry who tries to move from one positioning to another in order to copy another company’s strategy. Barriers to imitation slow the process of competitive convergence.

集群： 公司、供应商、相关行业和专业机构（如学术项目）的地理集中，例如好莱坞（娱乐）、硅谷（技术）或印度修拉（钻石切割）。集群在竞争中发挥着重要作用，因为公司的生产力受到周围类似公司、机构和基础设施的影响。例如，如果当地供应商能够提供时效性强的服务，公司的效率就会更高。集群利用当地的资产和机构，例如公共教育、物质基础设施、清洁水、公平竞争法、质量标准和透明度。集群是所有成功和发展中经济体的显著特征，也是竞争力、创业精神和新业务增长的关键驱动力。有关此主题的更多信息，请参阅波特的《竞争论》（2008 年）中的“集群与竞争”。

clusters: Geographic concentrations of companies, suppliers, related industries, and specialized institutions such as academic programs—think Hollywood (entertainment), for example, Silicon Valley (technology), or Seurat, India (diamond cutting). Clusters play an important role in competition because a company’s productivity is influenced by the presence of like firms, institutions, and infrastructure around it. With effective local suppliers of time-sensitive services, for example, a company will be more efficient. Clusters draw on local assets and institutions, such as public education, physical infrastructure, clean water, fair competition laws, quality standards, and transparency. Clusters are prominent features of all successful and growing economies, and a crucial driver of competitiveness, entrepreneurship, and new business growth. For more on this topic, see “Clusters and Competition” in Porter’s On Competition (2008).

竞争： 该术语通常用于指竞争对手和对抗，但对于波特来说，这个定义太过狭隘。竞争是争夺利润的拉锯战，不仅发生在竞争对手之间，还发生在公司与其客户、供应商、替代品制造商和潜在的新进入者之间。

competition: The term is commonly used to refer to rivals and rivalry, but for Porter, this definition is too narrow. Competition is the tug-of-war over profits that occurs not just between rivals but also between a company and its customers, its suppliers, makers of substitutes, and potential new entrants.

竞争优势： 该术语通常用于表示“我们认为我们擅长的领域”，例如“我们的竞争优势是技术”。或者，它的用法更为宽泛，例如“我们的竞争优势在于我们的人才”。波特的定义与竞争经济学紧密相关：如果您的盈利能力持续高于竞争对手，那么您就拥有竞争优势。然后，您可以进一步挖掘以了解这种优势是来自更高的价格、更低的成本还是两者的结合。相对价格或相对成本的差异是由于所执行活动的差异而产生的。

competitive advantage: The term is commonly used to mean “Here’s what we think we’re good at,” as in “Our competitive advantage is technology.” Or, it is used even more loosely, as in “Our competitive advantage lies in our people.” Porter’s definition is tightly linked to the economics of competition: you have competitive advantage if your profitability is sustainably higher than that of your rivals. Then you can dig further to understand whether that advantage comes from higher prices, lower costs, or some combination of both. These differences in relative price or relative costs arise because of differences in the activities being performed.

竞争性融合： 当各公司互相模仿和效仿对方的举动，当它们竞相成为最佳时，就会发生这种情况。随着时间的推移，随着一个又一个的差异逐渐消失，所有公司开始变得相似。当竞争对手围绕标准产品进行融合时，客户必须仅根据价格进行选择。主流经济学一直强调这种“完美”竞争通过降低价格使客户受益。但波特对此有不同的看法。融合实际上会伤害客户，因为它限制了他们的选择。

competitive convergence: What happens when companies imitate and match each other’s moves, when they compete to be the best. Over time all companies begin to look alike as one difference after another erodes. When rivals converge around a standard offering, customers must choose on price alone. Mainstream economics has always highlighted the way in which this kind of “perfect” competition benefits customers by lowering prices. But Porter sees it differently. Convergence can actually hurt customers because it limits their choice.

竞争力（国家或地区）： 该术语通常用于描述具有低成本劳动力或其他传统比较优势（如可获得宝贵自然资源）的地区或国家。在波特看来，对低成本投入的关注，即“比较优势”，已经远不如以前那么重要了。波特根据一个地区的人力、自然资源和资本的利用效率来定义其竞争力。换句话说，竞争力来自于一个地区如何有效地利用投入来生产有价值的商品和服务，而不是来自于它所拥有的投入。它来自于选择，而不是禀赋。此外，波特认为，一个地区可能实现的生产力和繁荣，不是取决于其企业在哪些行业竞争，而是取决于它们如何竞争。政策制定者和高管通过他们的选择，创造了一种影响公司竞争方式的商业环境，从而影响了它们的竞争力。有关此主题的更多信息，请参阅《论竞争》 （2008 年）中的“国家竞争优势” 。

competitiveness (of a nation, a location): The term is commonly used to describe a region or country with low-cost labor or some other conventional comparative advantage such as access to a valuable natural resource. In Porter’s view, the focus on low-cost inputs, on “comparative advantage,” is far less relevant than it once was. Porter defines the competitiveness of a location in terms of how productively it uses its human and natural resources as well as its capital. Competitiveness arises, in other words, from how well a location uses inputs to produce valuable goods and services, not from the inputs it has. It arises from choices, not endowments. Moreover, Porter argues that the productivity and prosperity possible in a given location depend not on what industries its firms compete in, but on how they compete. Policy makers and executives, through their choices, create a business environment that affects how companies compete, and thus their competitiveness. For more on this topic, see “The Competitive Advantage of Nations” in On Competition (2008).

竞争对手分析： 通过评估竞争对手的意图和能力，收集和分析情报，帮助公司应对竞争动态。有关此主题的更多信息，请参阅波特在《竞争战略》（1980 年）第 3 章中的开创性著作。

competitor analysis: Intelligence gathering and analysis aimed at helping a company deal with competitive dynamics by assessing the intentions and capabilities of rivals. For more on this topic, see Porter’s seminal work in chapter 3 of Competitive Strategy (1980).

连续性： 波特用这个术语来指核心价值主张的稳定性。这是他对良好战略的第五项检验。战略是一条道路，而不是目的地。一家公司可以继续沿着这条道路前行，而不必停滞不前。有些人认为战略是“静态的”，或者不允许改变，但这种区别却被误解了。战略的所有其他要素——根据价值主张定制价值链、扩大权衡、实现跨活动的契合——都需要时间来发展。如果没有方向的连续性，一家公司就无法发展和深化其竞争优势。

continuity: Porter uses the term to refer to stability in the core value proposition. It is his fifth test of a good strategy. A strategy is a path, not a destination. A company can stay on the path without standing still, a distinction that is misunderstood by those who think that strategy is somehow “static,” or that it doesn’t allow for change. All of the other elements of strategy—tailoring a value chain to the value proposition, extending trade-offs, achieving fit across activities—take time to develop. Without continuity of direction, a company would be unable to develop and deepen its competitive advantage.

企业战略： 由多个行业的多元化业务组成的企业的整体战略；它与竞争战略不同。由于竞争优势的得失取决于单个业务的水平，因此企业战略的目标应该是增强其多个业务部门的竞争优势。但由于企业位于业务部门的“顶端”，是权力和控制的中心，这种区别在实践中常常被忽视。本末倒置，企业“协同效应”名声不佳。有关此主题的更多信息，请参阅《波特论竞争》（2008 年）中的“从竞争优势到企业战略”。

corporate strategy: The overall strategy for a corporation that consists of diversified businesses in multiple industries; it is not the same thing as a competitive strategy. Because competitive advantage is won or lost at the level of an individual business, the goal of corporate strategy should be to enhance the competitive advantage of its multiple business units. But because the corporation sits “on top” of the business units and is the seat of power and control, this distinction is often lost in practice. The cart often leads the horse, giving corporate “synergy” a bad name. For more on this topic, see “From Competitive Advantage to Corporate Strategy” in Porter’s On Competition (2008).

成本动因： 影响成本的因素。在分析公司的成本状况时，要查看每项不同的活动，看看哪些因素会影响该活动的成本。《竞争优势》（1985 年）有一章 50 页专门讨论这个重要主题。

cost driver: The factors that influence cost. In analyzing a company’s cost position, look at each distinct activity to see which factors influence the cost of that activity. Competitive Advantage (1985) has a fifty-page chapter on this important subject.

钻石理论： 波特的主要框架（本书未涉及）解释了为什么某些国家和地区在特定行业取得的经济成功大于其他国家和地区。比较优势将一个地区的成功归因于低成本劳动力或宝贵的自然资源。相比之下，波特强调竞争优势的作用，即通过更高的生产力和创新实现的优势。根据钻石理论，这些优势出现在当地环境最具前瞻性、最具活力和最具挑战性的地方。参见《国家竞争优势》（1990 年）。

diamond theory: A major Porter framework (not covered in this book) that explains why some nations and regions achieve greater economic success in a given industry than others. Comparative advantage attributes a region’s success to low-cost labor or access to a valuable natural resource. In contrast, Porter highlights the role of competitive advantage, achieved through higher productivity and innovation. These arise, according to diamond theory, where the local environment is the most forward-looking, dynamic, and challenging. See The Competitive Advantage of Nations (1990).

差异化： 该术语最常用的意思是“不同”。在营销中，它用于描述一种产品相对于其他产品的定位（即，它可能提供更好的质量或功能，或者可能以更低的价格出售）。波特更狭义地使用这个术语来指一家公司能够比竞争对手获得更高的相对价格，因为它的产品提高了客户的支付意愿。波特更喜欢这个更狭义和更精确的定义，因为他认为，重要的是不要混淆竞争优势的两个组成部分：价格和成本。

differentiation: The term is most commonly used simply to mean “different.” In marketing, it is used to describe how one offering is positioned in relation to others (i.e., it might offer more quality or features, or it might sell at a lower price). Porter uses this term more narrowly to refer to a company’s ability to command a higher relative price than rivals because its offering has increased customers’ willingness to pay. Porter prefers this narrower and more precise definition because he believes it is essential not to confuse the two components of competitive advantage: price and cost.

多元化： 公司向不同业务领域的扩张。波特对多元化的思考与价值链及其活动直接相关。波特观察到，定义模糊的核心竞争力往往为多元化提供了理由，而多元化最终却出现在实际上不相关的业务中。多元化的挑战在于确定可以与新业务共享的活动或活动系统，或者找到可以转移您在管理特定活动方面的专有技能的业务。这就是如何利用宝贵的资源或能力。有关此主题的更多信息，请参阅波特的《竞争论》（2008 年）中的“从竞争优势到企业战略”。

diversification: The expansion of a company into different businesses. Porter’s thinking about diversification is directly linked to the value chain and its activities. Too often, Porter observes, core competences that are vaguely defined provide a rationale for diversification that turns out to be in businesses that are actually unrelated. The challenge in diversification is to identify activities or activity systems that can be shared with new businesses, or to find businesses where your proprietary skills in managing specific activities can be transferred. This is how valuable resources or competences can be leveraged. For more on this topic, see “From Competitive Advantage to Corporate Strategy” in Porter’s On Competition (2008).

执行： 参见运营效率（OE）。

execution: See operational effectiveness (OE).

契合度： 一项活动的价值或成本受到其他活动执行方式的影响。契合度是衡量战略好坏的五项基本标准之一，它可以通过降低成本或创造独特价值来提高客户的支付意愿，从而扩大竞争优势的价值。它还可以增强战略的可持续性，使竞争对手更难理解和复制战略复杂的活动系统。

fit: When the value or cost of one activity is affected by the way other activities are performed. One of the five basic tests of a good strategy, fit can amplify the value of a competitive advantage by lowering costs or by producing unique value that raises a customer’s willingness to pay. It also amplifies the sustainability of a strategy, making it harder for rivals to understand and copy the strategy’s complex system of activities.

五力分析： 波特通过分析行业结构来评估任何行业竞争的开创性框架。该框架解释了不同行业之间盈利能力的巨大而持续的差异。五力分析是思考战略的第一步，思考如何将力量转向对你有利的方向，以及在何处可以建立独特的定位。有关该框架及其广泛应用，请参阅波特的《论竞争》（2008 年）中的“塑造战略的五种竞争力量”和“战略与互联网”。

five forces: Porter’s seminal framework for assessing competition in any industry by analyzing the industry’s structure. The framework explains the large and sustained differences in profitability from one industry to another. Five forces analysis is the first step in thinking about strategy, about how to shift the forces in your favor, and where you might be able to establish a unique positioning. For the framework and an extensive application of it, see “The Five Competitive Forces That Shape Strategy” and “Strategy and the Internet” in Porter’s On Competition (2008).

框架： 波特用这个术语来区分他的方法与正式的经济模型。正式的模型只能捕捉那些可以用数学表示和解决的竞争方面，而这需要严格限制可以考虑的变量数量。波特的框架承认竞争过于复杂，不适合正式建模；它们更像是专家系统，可帮助您考虑竞争的相关方面。

frameworks: The term Porter uses to distinguish his approach from formal economic models. Formal models can capture only those aspects of competition that can be represented and solved mathematically, and this requires sharply limiting the number of variables that can be considered. Porter’s frameworks accept that competition is too complex to lend itself to formal modeling; they are more like expert systems that help you to consider the relevant dimensions of competition.

通用战略： 战略定位关键主题的广泛特征。集中战略选择限制公司服务的客户和需求范围。差异化战略允许公司要求溢价，而成本领先战略则允许公司通过提供较低的相对价格来竞争。通用战略的概念是波特在《竞争战略》（1980 年）中首次提出的开创性概念，此后一直受到管理者的广泛欢迎。有效的战略通常以独特的方式整合多个主题。例如，您可以在某些方面实现差异化，同时保持低成本，只要特定类型的差异化价值与低成本不相矛盾。请参阅“进退维谷”。

generic strategies: Broad characterizations of the key themes of strategic positioning. A focused strategy chooses to limit the scope of customers and needs that a company serves. A differentiation strategy allows a company to command a premium price, while cost leadership allows it to compete by offering a low relative price. The idea of generic strategies was a seminal concept first described by Porter in Competitive Strategy (1980) and has been widely embraced by managers ever since. Effective strategies typically integrate multiple themes in a unique way. You can be differentiated in some ways and be low cost, for example, as long as the particular kind of differentiated value is not inconsistent with low costs. See stuck in the middle.

地理范围： 对于战略而言，正确划定行业地理边界至关重要。您的业务是全球性的、全国性的、地区的还是本地性的？五种力量的显著差异表明您可能正在处理不同的行业。波特指出，人们倾向于将企业定义为全球性的，但事实上，不同国家或地区的行业结构存在显著差异，需要不同的战略。请参阅《竞争论》（2008 年）中的“跨地区竞争：通过全球战略增强竞争优势”。

geographic scope: For strategy, it is critical to draw the geographic boundaries of your industry correctly. Is your business global, national, regional, or local? Significant differences in the five forces suggest that you may be dealing with separate industries. There has been a tendency, Porter notes, to define businesses as being global when in fact there are significant differences in industry structure from one country or region to the next that would demand different strategies. See “Competing Across Locations: Enhancing Competitive Advantage Through a Global Strategy” in On Competition (2008).

全球战略、全球化： 参见地理范围。

global strategy, globalization: See geographic scope.

行业结构： 行业的基本经济和技术特征，决定了制定战略的竞争环境。分析行业结构是了解竞争环境和行业利润潜力的起点。参见五力。

industry structure: The basic, underlying economic and technological characteristics of an industry that shape the competitive arena in which strategy must be set. Analyzing industry structure is the place to start in order to understand the competitive environment as well as the profit potential of the industry. See five forces.

运营效率 (OE)： 通常被管理者称为“最佳实践”或“执行”，OE 是波特对公司比竞争对手更好地执行相同或类似活动的能力的总称。OE 包括多种实践，可让公司从其使用的资源中获得更多收益。每个职能领域都有其当前的最佳实践：工厂装载的最佳方式、培训销售队伍的最佳方式等等。OE 的差异是普遍存在的，可以解释相对盈利能力的一些差异。OE 是关于实现卓越的执行。OE 对绩效很重要，但它与战略不同。有关 OE 的更多信息，请参阅波特的《竞争论》（2008 年）中的“什么是战略？”。

operational effectiveness (OE): Commonly called “best practice” or “execution” by managers, OE is Porter’s umbrella term for a company’s ability to perform the same or similar activities better than rivals. OE includes a multitude of practices that allow a company to get more out of the resources it uses. Every functional area has its current best practices: the best way to load a factory, the best way to train a sales force, and so on. Differences in OE are pervasive and can explain some differences in relative profitability. OE is about achieving excellence in execution. OE is important to performance, but it is different from strategy. For more on OE, see “What Is Strategy?” in Porter’s On Competition (2008).

外包： 决定从第三方购买贵组织曾经内部执行的活动。公认的观点是保留那些“核心”活动，并将其余活动外包。波特提供了一种不同的决策框架，将其与竞争优势经济学直接联系起来：保留那些可以或可以针对您的战略进行定制的功能，并将那些真正通用的功能外包，这些功能几乎不可能或与战略无关。

outsourcing: The decision to buy from a third party an activity that your organization once performed internally. The received wisdom has been to retain those activities that are “core” and to outsource the rest. Porter offers a different way to frame the decision, linking it directly to the economics of competitive advantage: retain those functions that are or could be tailored to your strategy, and outsource those that are truly generic, for which little tailoring is possible or relevant to the strategy.

波特假说： 环保界对波特的论点的称呼，即企业污染往往是经济浪费的标志：资源使用效率低下、能源浪费或宝贵原材料被丢弃。因此，改善环境绩效通常会提高生产力，在某些情况下甚至会抵消改进成本。因此，企业不应将环境改善视为监管麻烦，而应将其视为提高生产力和竞争力的重要组成部分。波特认为，明智的环境监管鼓励产品和流程创新。请参阅波特与 Claas van der Linde 合著的文章《绿色与竞争：结束僵局》，载于《论竞争》（2008 年）。

Porter hypothesis: The name given by the environmental community to Porter’s argument that corporate pollution is often a sign of economic waste: of resources used inefficiently, energy wasted, or valuable raw materials discarded. Improving environmental performance, then, will often increase productivity and, in some cases, even offset the cost of making improvements. Corporations therefore should see environmental improvement not as a regulatory nuisance but as an essential part of improving productivity and competitiveness. Smart environmental regulation, Porter argues, encourages product and process innovation. See Porter’s article (with Claas van der Linde) “Green and Competitive: Ending the Stalemate” in On Competition (2008).

定位： 针对特定相关行业竞争对手选择的价值主张。找到好的策略意味着找到独特的定位，即您希望在行业中占据的“位置”。

positioning: The choice of a value proposition made against a specific and relevant set of industry rivals. Discovering a good strategy means finding a unique positioning, the “place” you want to be in your industry.

相对购买者价值： 相对于其他产品，客户愿意为某种商品或服务支付多少钱。

relative buyer value: How much the customer is willing to pay for a good or service versus other offerings.

相对成本： 您的单位成本与竞争对手的单位成本之比。相对成本优势可能来自两个方面：更好地执行相同活动（竞争成为最佳，或 OE）或选择执行不同的活动（竞争成为独一无二的）。

relative cost: Your cost per unit relative to that of your rivals. A relative cost advantage can come from two possible sources: performing the same activities better (competing to be the best, or OE) or choosing to perform different activities (competing to be unique).

相对价格： 您的每单位价格与竞争对手的价格之比。相对价格优势来自于产生买方价值的差异化，或者用更通俗的话说，来自于生产出客户愿意支付更多钱的独特产品。

relative price: Your price per unit relative to that of your rivals. A relative price advantage comes from differentiation that produces buyer value, or in plainer English, from producing something distinctive for which customers are willing to pay more.

投资资本回报率 (ROIC)： 衡量企业产生的利润与投资资本的财务指标。对于波特来说，这是衡量成功的最佳财务指标，因为它可以反映出公司如何有效地利用资源创造经济价值。

return on invested capital (ROIC): A financial measure that weighs the profits a business generates versus the capital invested in it. For Porter, this is the best financial measure of success because it captures how effectively a company uses its resources to generate economic value.

战略竞争： 波特用这个术语来指正和竞争，即公司通过为客户创造独特价值来取胜（并获得卓越的盈利能力）。这是一种双赢的竞争形式，因为你的客户受益，你也受益。

strategic competition: Porter uses this term to refer to positive-sum competition, in which companies win (and achieve superior profitability) by creating unique value for their customers. This is a win–win form of competition because your customers benefit and so do you.

战略： 该词通常用于指任何重要的目标或计划，例如“我们的战略是成为行业第一”或“我们的战略是通过收购实现增长”。波特的定义：一套综合选择，决定了如何在竞争中取得卓越绩效。它不是目标（例如，成为第一），也不是具体的行动（例如，进行收购）。你选择的定位将导致实现目标；行动是你实现定位的途径。此外，当波特定义战略时，他实际上是在谈论什么是好的战略，即导致投资回报率高于行业平均水平的战略。

strategy: The word is commonly used to refer to any important goal or initiative, as in “Our strategy is to be number 1 in our industry,” or “Our strategy is to grow through acquisitions.” Porter’s definition: the set of integrated choices that define how you will achieve superior performance in the face of competition. It’s not the goal (e.g., be number 1), nor is it a specific action (e.g., make acquisitions). It’s the positioning you choose that will result in achieving the goal; the actions are the path you take to realize the positioning. Moreover, when Porter defines strategy, he is really talking about what constitutes a good strategy, one that will result in a higher ROIC than the industry average.

陷于中间： 波特的这句话很快成为战略词汇的一部分，用来描述公司在拒绝权衡利弊、试图满足所有客户需求时陷入的战略陷阱。问题是，当你试图提供不一致的价值类型时，你将不可避免地无法像更专注的竞争对手那样高效或有效，因为后者愿意调整其活动来提供独特的价值。

stuck in the middle: A Porter phrase that quickly became part of the strategy lexicon to describe a strategic trap companies fall into when they refuse to make trade-offs, when they try to be all things to all customers. The problem is that when you try to offer types of value that are inconsistent, you will inevitably fail to be as efficient or effective as a more focused competitor that has been willing to tailor its activities to deliver that unique value.

替代品： 客户可能会选择另一类别的产品来满足您的产品所满足的相同需求。令传统钟表制造商沮丧的是，手机正在成为手表的替代品，尤其是对年轻一代而言。替代品的威胁是五种力量之一。

substitute: A product from another category that a customer might choose to meet the same need your product serves. To the dismay of traditional watchmakers, cellphones are becoming a substitute for wristwatches, especially for the younger generation. The threat of substitutes is one of the five forces.

SWOT 分析： 一种简单且广泛使用的工具，于 20 世纪 60 年代开发，用于组织战略规划会议中的讨论。管理人员需要列出公司的优势、劣势、机会和威胁 (SWOT)。SWOT 试图将公司与其环境联系起来，但通常缺乏分析和客观性。SWOT 早于波特著作中的见解。

SWOT analysis: A simple and widely used tool developed in the 1960s to organize discussions in strategic planning meetings. Managers are asked to list the company’s strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats (SWOT). SWOT attempts to relate a company to its environment, but it is typically short on analysis and objectivity. SWOT predates the insights that derive from Porter’s work.

量身定制的价值链： 波特使用“量身定制”一词来指专门为实现特定价值主张而设计的活动。量身定制的活动与一般活动相反。拥有量身定制的价值链是波特对良好战略的第二个检验标准。

tailored value chain: Porter uses the word “tailored” to refer to activities that are designed specifically to deliver a certain value proposition. A tailored activity is the opposite of a generic one. Having a tailored value chain is Porter’s second test of a good strategy.

权衡： 当公司必须在不一致的战略定位之间做出选择时，就会发生权衡。这些选择会导致竞争对手在成本和价值方面产生差异，因此权衡是战略的经济关键。权衡是良好战略的五个测试之一，它有助于形成构成竞争优势的成本和价格差异。权衡还使做出不同选择的竞争对手难以在不损害自己战略的情况下复制您的做法。因此，权衡通过阻止现有竞争对手的模仿使竞争优势可持续。

trade-offs: Trade-offs occur when companies have to makes choices between strategic positionings that are inconsistent. Those kinds of choices give rise to differences among rivals in cost and value, and thus trade-offs are the economic linchpin of strategy. One of the five tests of good strategy, trade-offs contribute to the cost and price differences that constitute competitive advantage. Trade-offs also make it difficult for rivals that have made different choices to copy what you do without damaging their own strategies. Thus, trade-offs make competitive advantage sustainable by deterring imitation from existing rivals.

价值链： 企业在创造、生产、营销和交付其产品或服务时进行的所有独立活动的集合。这是理解竞争优势的基本工具，因为所有成本都来自价值链活动，所有差异化也由这些活动产生。

value chain: The set of all the discrete activities a firm performs in creating, producing, marketing, and delivering its good or service. This is the basic tool for understanding competitive advantage, since all costs arise from the value chain’s activities and all differentiation is created by them.

价值创造： 组织将投入转化为价值超过投入总和的商品和服务的过程。对于以创造经济价值为目的的企业和以最高效率实现特定社会目标为目的的非营利组织而言，这是卓越绩效的最终来源。战略是关于任何组织如何为其选定的客户创造独特价值。

value creation: The process by which organizations transform inputs into goods and services that are worth more than the sum of those inputs. This is the ultimate source of superior performance for businesses that exist to create economic value, and for nonprofits that exist to meet a specific social objective with the greatest efficiency. Strategy is about how any organization will create unique value for its chosen customers.

价值主张： 战略的核心要素，定义公司将为客户创造什么样的价值。价值主张回答三个问题：您要服务哪些客户？您要满足哪些需求？您将收取多少相对价格？独特的价值主张是良好战略的首要考验。

value proposition: The core element of strategy that defines the kind of value a company will create for its customers. A value proposition answers three questions: Which customers are you going to serve? Which needs are you going to meet? What relative price will you charge? A unique value proposition is the first test of a good strategy.

价值体系： 为最终用户创造价值的全套端到端活动。一家公司的价值链通常只是更大价值体系的一部分，该体系包括上游公司（供应商）或下游公司（分销渠道），或两者兼而有之。这种关于如何创造价值的观点迫使你考虑流程中的每一项活动，而不管是谁执行了这项活动。它还迫使你不仅将每一项活动视为成本，而且将其视为必须为成品或服务增加一定价值的步骤。因此，在思考你自己的价值链时，重要的是要看清你的活动如何与供应商、渠道和客户的活动建立联系。

value system: The full set of end-to-end activities involved in creating value for the end user. A company’s value chain is typically just a part of a larger value system that includes companies either upstream (suppliers) or downstream (distribution channels), or both. This perspective about how value is created forces you to consider every activity in the process, regardless of who performs that activity. It also forces you to see each activity not just as a cost, but as a step that has to add some increment of value to the finished product or service. In thinking about your own value chain, then, it’s important to see how your activities have points of connection with those of your suppliers, channels, and customers.

零和竞争： 一种竞争形式，只有当别人输了时你才能赢，即使“别人”是你的客户或供应商。例如，波特对美国医疗保健竞争的描述是：“通过将成本转嫁给他人，可以降低成本。医生被迫通过减少与患者相处的时间提高工作效率。医生通过与医院达成更好的协议而获胜……医院通过合并成集团以获得更多价格谈判权而获胜……健康计划通过限制服务并迫使医生接受较低的报酬而获胜。通过这样的方式，系统中的每个参与者不是通过增加患者的价值而获益，而是通过从其他人那里夺走价值。”参见波特和 E. Teisberg，“医生如何改变医疗保健的未来”，JAMA 297，第 10 期（2007 年）。

zero-sum competition: A form of rivalry in which you win only if someone else loses, even if the “someone else” is your customer or your supplier. For example, Porter’s description of U.S. health-care competition: “Costs are reduced by shifting them to others. Physicians are pressured to improve productivity by skimping on time spent with patients. Physicians win by cutting better deals with their hospitals . . . Hospitals win by merging into groups to gain more bargaining clout on rates . . . Health plans win by restricting services and muscling physicians to accept lower pay. In ways such as these, each player in the system gains not by increasing value for the patient but by taking value away from someone else.” See Porter and E. Teisberg, “How Physicians Can Change the Future of Health Care,” JAMA 297, no. 10 (2007).

章节注释和来源

Chapter Notes and Sources

 

有关波特著作的综合书目，包括演讲和访谈，请参阅战略与竞争力研究所的网站 http://isc.hbs.edu。为了帮助读者探究感兴趣的特定主题，我在词汇表中引用了波特的许多已出版著作。

For a comprehensive bibliography of Porter’s work, including presentations and interviews, see the Web site of the Institute for Strategy and Competitiveness, http://isc.hbs.edu. To help readers pursue particular topics of interest, I have referenced a number of Porter’s published works in the glossary.

介绍

Introduction

 

2010 年秋天，在与我的一次私人谈话中，波特描述了他在 20 世纪 70 年代面临的思想鸿沟。他对其框架起源的反思发表在 ME Porter、N. Argyres 和 AM McGahan 合著的《迈克尔·波特访谈录》中，《管理学院执行官》第 16 卷，第 2 期（2002 年）：第 43-52 页。

Porter described the intellectual divide he faced in the 1970s in a private conversation with me in the fall of 2010. His reflections on the origins of his frameworks appear in M. E. Porter, N. Argyres, and A. M. McGahan, “An Interview with Michael Porter,” Academy of Management Executive 16, no. 2 (2002): 43–52.

第 1 章 竞争：正确的心态

Chapter 1. Competition: The Right Mind-Set

 

机场座位的例子是丹尼尔迈克尔斯提出的，《热门座位：机场家具设计师为荣耀而战》，《华尔街日报》，2010 年 5 月 17 日。

The airport seating example was suggested by Daniel Michaels, “Hot Seat: Airport Furniture Designers Battle for Glory,” Wall Street Journal, May 17, 2010.

有关酒店床铺之争的引述见 Christopher Elliott 于 2006 年 1 月 31 日在《纽约时报》上发表的《酒店床铺之争的缓和》。另请参阅 Youngme Moon 撰写的《酒店床铺之争》，案例 9-509-059（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2009 年）。

The hotel bed wars quote was reported by Christopher Elliott, “Détente in the Hotel Bed Wars,” New York Times, January 31, 2006. See also Youngme Moon, “The Hotel Bed Wars,” Case 9-509-059 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2009).

第二章 五种力量：争夺利润

Chapter 2. The Five Forces: Competing for Profits

 

本章引用了迈克尔·波特的《塑造战略的五种竞争力量》，该文重印于《论竞争》更新扩充版（波士顿：哈佛商学院出版社，2008 年）。

This chapter draws from and quotes Michael E. Porter’s “The Five Competitive Forces That Shape Strategy,” reprinted in On Competition, Updated and Expanded Edition (Boston: Harvard Business School Publishing, 2008).

有关水泥行业市场力量的故事源自 Peter Fritsch 的《坚实的利润：墨西哥水泥巨头靠向穷人销售产品而蓬勃发展》一文，《华尔街日报》，2002 年 4 月 22 日。另请参阅 Pankaj Ghemawat 的《CEMEX 的全球化》一文，案例 9-701-017（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2004 年）。

The story of market power in the cement industry comes from Peter Fritsch, “Hard Profits: A Cement Titan in Mexico Thrives by Selling to Poor,” Wall Street Journal, April 22, 2002. See also Pankaj Ghemawat, “The Globalization of CEMEX,” Case 9-701-017 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2004).

“收发”工作规则在米歇林·梅纳德 (Micheline Maynard) 的《航空公司工会投票不仅仅关系到金钱》 (纽约时报，2003 年 4 月 29 日) 中有所描述。

The “receipt and dispatch” work rule is described by Micheline Maynard, “More Than Money Is at Stake in Votes by Airline Unions,” New York Times, April 29, 2003.

有关极其详尽和严格的五力分析的示例，请参阅 ISC 网站上有关航空业的帖子，网址为http://www.isc.hbs.edu/pdf/IATA_Vision_2050_Chapter_1.pdf。如需帮助您进行自己的行业分析，请参阅 Jan Rivkin 和 Ann Cullen 的《查找行业分析信息》，注 9-708-481（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2010 年）。

For an example of an extremely thorough and rigorous five forces analysis, see the posting on the ISC Web that covers the airline industry, at http:// www.isc.hbs.edu/pdf/IATA_Vision_2050_Chapter_1.pdf. For help with doing your own industry analysis, see Jan Rivkin and Ann Cullen, “Finding Information for Industry Analysis,” Note 9-708-481 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2010).

第 3 章竞争优势：价值链和您的损益表

Chapter 3. Competitive Advantage: The Value Chain and Your P&L

 

凯莱赫关于利润的名言来自凯文和杰基·弗赖伯格的《疯了！西南航空公司的商业和个人成功秘诀》（德克萨斯州奥斯汀：巴德出版社，1996 年），第 49 页。这是对西南航空公司早期历史的一次引人入胜、富有洞察力的描述，我将在后面的章节中再次引用。

The Kelleher quote about profits comes from Kevin and Jackie Freiberg, Nuts! Southwest Airlines’ Crazy Recipe for Business and Personal Success (Austin, TX: Bard Press, 1996), 49. This is an engaging, insightful account of the early history of Southwest that I draw upon again in later chapters.

我的价值链模板是波特经典图表的简化版本。原始版本请参阅《竞争优势：创造和维持卓越绩效》（纽约：自由出版社，1985 年）第 2 章以及《信息如何为您带来竞争优势》（《论竞争》（2008 年）重印版）。有关如何使用价值链分析的精彩课程，请参阅波特和罗伯特·S·卡普兰的《如何解决医疗保健成本危机》，《哈佛商业评论》，2011 年 9 月。

My value chain template is a simplified version of Porter’s classic graphic. For the original, see Chapter 2 of Competitive Advantage: Creating and Sustaining Superior Performance (New York: Free Press, 1985) and also “How Information Gives You Competitive Advantage,” reprinted in On Competition (2008). For a great lesson in how to use value chain analysis, see Porter and Robert S. Kaplan, “How to Solve the Cost Crisis in Health Care,” Harvard Business Review, September 2011.

我第一次听说 Whirlwind Wheelchair 是在 PBS Frontline/World 纪录片《Wheels of Change》中，该片由 Marjorie McAfee 和 Victoria Gamburg 制作，由 Marjorie McAfee 报道。Whirlwind 的执行董事 Marc Krizack 在 2011 年 4 月的一系列私人交流中向我提供了有关该组织的宝贵见解。

I first learned about Whirlwind Wheelchair from the PBS Frontline/World documentary Wheels of Change, produced by Marjorie McAfee and Victoria Gamburg, reported by Marjorie McAfee. Whirlwind’s Executive Director, Marc Krizack, provided me with valuable insights about his organization in a series of private exchanges in April 2011.

以下是有助于分析竞争优势（例如相对成本、成本驱动因素和支付意愿等主题）的三个极好的资源：

Three excellent sources for help with the analytics of competitive advantage (topics such as relative cost, cost drivers, and willingness to pay) are the following:

 
  • Pankaj Ghemawat 和 Jan W. Rivkin，“创造竞争优势”，注 9-798-062（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2006 年）。
  • Pankaj Ghemawat and Jan W. Rivkin, “Creating Competitive Advantage,” Note 9-798-062 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2006).
    •  
  • Hanna Halaburda 和 Jan W. Rivkin，《分析相对成本》，注 9-708-462（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2009 年）。
  • Hanna Halaburda and Jan W. Rivkin, “Analyzing Relative Costs,” Note 9-708-462 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2009).
    •  
  • Tarun Khanna 和 Jan Rivkin，《战略家的数学》，注 9-705-433（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2005 年）。
  • Tarun Khanna and Jan Rivkin, “Math for Strategists,” Note 9-705-433 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2005).
    •  
 

我曾在《管理是什么：它如何运作以及为什么它是每个人的事》（纽约：自由出版社，2002 年）一书中写过有关戴尔、本田和施瓦布的文章。

I have written about Dell, Honda, and Schwab in What Management Is: How It Works and Why It’s Everyone’s Business (New York: Free Press, 2002).

有关 Nomacorc 的例子，请参阅 Timothy Aeppel 的《Show Stopper：塑料如何打破软木塞垄断》，《华尔街日报》，2010 年 5 月 1 日。

For the Nomacorc example, see Timothy Aeppel, “Show Stopper: How Plastic Popped the Cork Monopoly,” Wall Street Journal, May 1, 2010.

波特在《论竞争》（2008 年）重印的“什么是战略？”中反对将 OE 与战略相混淆。

Porter argues against confusing OE with strategy in “What Is Strategy?” reprinted in On Competition (2008).

有关日本竞争力问题的分析，请参阅迈克尔·E·波特、竹内弘高和榊原麻里子合著的《日本能竞争吗？》（马萨诸塞州剑桥：Perseus Publishing，2000 年）。

For an analysis of Japan’s competitive problems, see Michael E. Porter, Hirotaka Takeuchi, and Mariko Sakakibara, Can Japan Compete? (Cambridge, MA: Perseus Publishing, 2000).

第四章 创造价值：核心

Chapter 4. Creating Value: The Core

 

本章中引用的波特引文和概念以及他对西南航空的分析均来自《什么是战略？》一书，该书重印于《论竞争》（2008 年）。描述价值主张的图表是波特的，取自未发表的演讲材料。

The Porter quotes and concepts in this chapter, as well as his analysis of Southwest Airlines, come from “What Is Strategy?” reprinted in On Competition (2008). The graphic depicting the value proposition is Porter’s, derived from unpublished presentation materials.

西南航空早期定价和扩张的详细信息来自前面引用的《Nuts!》 。

Details of Southwest’s early pricing and its expansion come from Nuts!, cited earlier.

我曾在《什么是管理》（2002 年）中撰写过有关沃尔玛、Enterprise、西南航空和阿拉文德航空的文章，还在 2002 年 5 月的《哈佛商业评论》中撰写过有关沃尔玛的文章“商业模式为何重要” 。

I have written about Walmart, Enterprise, Southwest, and Aravind in What Management Is (2002), and on Walmart in “Why Business Models Matter,” Harvard Business Review, May 2002.

有关 Aravind 的更多信息，请参阅 V. Kasturi Rangan 的《印度马杜赖阿拉文眼科医院：为视力服务》，案例 9-593-098（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2009 年）。

For more on Aravind, see V. Kasturi Rangan, “The Aravind Eye Hospital, Madurai, India: In Service for Sight,” Case 9-593-098 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2009).

我对《进步》的资料来源是 John Wells、Marina Lutova 和 Ilan Sender 所著的《进步公司》，案号 9-707-433（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2008 年）。

My source for Progressive is John Wells, Marina Lutova, and Ilan Sender, “The Progressive Corporation,” Case 9-707-433 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2008).

一篇关于 Enterprise 的好文章是 Carol Loomis 的《大惊喜是 Enterprise》，《财富》杂志2006 年 7 月 14 日刊。

A good article on Enterprise is Carol Loomis, “The Big Surprise Is Enterprise,” Fortune, July 14, 2006.

对于爱德华·琼斯，我引用了戴维·J·科利斯和迈克尔·G·鲁克斯塔德的《你能说出你的策略是什么吗？》《哈佛商业评论》，2008 年 4 月；以及戴维·J·科利斯和特洛伊·史密斯的《2006 年的爱德华·琼斯：直面成功》，案例 9-707-497（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2009 年）。

For Edward Jones, I have used David J. Collis and Michael G. Rukstad, “Can You Say What Your Strategy Is?” Harvard Business Review, April 2008; and David J. Collis and Troy Smith, “Edward Jones in 2006: Confronting Success,” Case 9-707-497 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2009).

我了解 Grace Manufacturing 的历史的资料来源是 John T. Edge 的《微型刨丝器如何走出车库》，《纽约时报》，2011 年 1 月 11 日。

My source for the history of Grace Manufacturing is John T. Edge, “How the Microplane Grater Escaped the Garage,” New York Times, January 11, 2011.

第 5 章 权衡：关键

Chapter 5. Trade-offs: The Linchpin

 

本章参考了波特战略与竞争力研究所校友 Andrew Funderburk 对麦当劳、英国航空公司 Go Fly、家得宝和劳氏公司尚未发表的研究。另请参阅 Stephanie Clifford 的《改造，家得宝吸引女性》，《纽约时报》，2011 年 1 月 28 日。

This chapter draws on unpublished research on McDonald’s, British Airways’ Go Fly, Home Depot, and Lowe’s done by Andrew Funderburk, an alumnus of Porter’s Institute for Strategy and Competitiveness. See also Stephanie Clifford, “Revamping, Home Depot Woos Women,” New York Times, January 28, 2011.

波特对宜家的分析来自《什么是战略？》一书，转载自《论竞争》（2008 年）。有关人们更看重自己建造的东西的研究，请参阅 Michael I. Norton、Daniel Mochon 和 Dan Ariely 的《‘宜家效应’：当劳动转化为爱时》，工作论文 11-091，哈佛商学院，波士顿，2011 年。

Porter’s analysis of IKEA comes from “What Is Strategy?” reprinted in On Competition (2008). For the research showing that people value more highly something they build themselves, see Michael I. Norton, Daniel Mochon, and Dan Ariely, “The ‘IKEA Effect’: When Labor Leads to Love,” working paper 11-091, Harvard Business School, Boston, 2011.

我第一次知道 In-N-Out Burger 是在 Youngme Moon 的《与众不同：逃离竞争群体》（纽约：Crown Business，2010 年）一书中。Stacy Perman 在《In-N-Out Burger：从柜台背后看打破所有规则的快餐连锁店》（纽约：Harper Collins，2009 年）一书中很好地讲述了该公司的历史。

I first learned about In-N-Out Burger from Youngme Moon’s Different: Escaping the Competitive Herd (New York: Crown Business, 2010). The company’s history is nicely told by Stacy Perman, In-N-Out Burger: A Behind-the-Counter Look at the Fast-Food Chain That Breaks All the Rules (New York: Harper Collins, 2009).

第 6 章 Fit：放大器

Chapter 6. Fit: The Amplifier

 

波特在《论竞争》（2008 年）重印的《什么是战略？》一书中讨论了适应的类型。

Porter writes about the types of fit in “What Is Strategy?” reprinted in On Competition (2008).

关于 Zara 的两个极好的资料来源是 Kasra Ferdows、Michael A. Lewis 和 Jose AD Machucam 的《快速履行》，《哈佛商业评论》，2004 年 11 月；以及 Pankaj Ghemawat 和 José Luis Nueno 的《Zara：快速时尚》，案例 9-703-497（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2003 年）。

Two excellent sources on Zara are Kasra Ferdows, Michael A. Lewis, and Jose A. D. Machucam, “Rapid-Fire Fulfillment,”Harvard Business Review, November, 2004; and Pankaj Ghemawat and José Luis Nueno, “Zara: Fast Fashion,” Case 9-703-497 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2003).

里德·哈斯廷斯 (Reed Hastings) 关于 Netflix 的匹配问题的引述来自威廉·C·泰勒 (William C. Taylor) 和波莉·拉巴尔 (Polly LaBarre) 的《工作中的特立独行者：为什么最具独创性的商界头脑会获胜》(纽约：HarperCollins，2006 年)。

The quotation from Reed Hastings about Netflix’s matching problem comes from William C. Taylor and Polly LaBarre, Mavericks at Work: Why the Most Original Minds in Business Win (New York: HarperCollins, 2006).

罗杰·马丁（Roger Martin）在 2010 年 11 月 24 日发表的博客“当战略未通过逻辑检验时”中谈到了 AT&T 的价值毁灭，http//blogs.hbr.org/martin/2010/11/i-pretty-much-knew-that.html。

Roger Martin blogged about AT&T’s value destruction in “When Strategy Fails the Logic Test,” November 24, 2010, http//blogs.hbr.org/martin/2010/11/ i-pretty-much-knew-that.html.

第 7 章 连续性：推动因素

Chapter 7. Continuity: The Enabler

 

波特在《战略与互联网》（重印于《论竞争》（2008 年）中）中运用五力思维来分析潜在的颠覆性技术。

Porter applies five forces thinking to the analysis of potentially disruptive technologies in “Strategy and the Internet,” reprinted in On Competition (2008).

有关雀巢牛奶业务，请参阅 Porter 和 Mark R. Kramer 的《战略与社会：竞争优势与企业社会责任之间的联系》，转载自《论竞争》（2008 年）。

For Nestlé’s milk business, see Porter and Mark R. Kramer, “Strategy and Society: The Link Between Competitive Advantage and Corporate Social Responsibility,” reprinted in On Competition (2008).

西尔斯的故事由罗杰·哈洛韦尔 (Roger Hallowell) 和詹姆斯·I·卡什 (James I. Cash Jr.) 讲述，《西尔斯、罗巴克公司 (A)：扭亏为盈》，案例 898-007（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2002 年）。

The Sears story is told by Roger Hallowell and James I. Cash Jr., “Sears, Roebuck and Company (A): Turnaround,” Case 898-007 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2002).

艾伦·穆拉利对福特转型的评论见比尔·弗拉西克在《纽约时报》2010 年 1 月 10 日发表的《福特的赌注：世界毕竟很小》一文中的报道。

Alan Mulally’s remarks about Ford’s transformation are reported by Bill Vlasic, “Ford’s Bet: It’s a Small World After All,” New York Times, January 10, 2010.

有关宝马设计过程的描述源自 S. Thomke 的《宝马的数字设计管理》，《设计管理期刊》第 12 卷，第 2 期（2001 年）。

This account of BMW’s design process is from S. Thomke, “Managing Digital Design at BMW,” Design Management Journal 12, no. 2 (2001).

有关 Netflix 的优质资料来源包括 Michael V. Copeland 的《Reed Hastings：领头羊》，《财富》 ，2010 年 11 月 18 日；以及 Willy Shih、Stephen Kaufmann 和 David Spinola 的《Netflix》，案例 9-607-138（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2009 年）。

Good sources for Netflix are Michael V. Copeland, “Reed Hastings: Leader of the Pack,” Fortune, November 18, 2010; and Willy Shih, Stephen Kaufmann, and David Spinola, “Netflix,” Case 9-607-138 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2009).

有关宝马对其电动汽车的想法，请参阅杰克·尤因 (Jack Ewing) 的《最新的电动汽车将是宝马，从电池开始》，纽约时报，2010 年 7 月 1 日。

For BMW’s thinking on its electric car, see Jack Ewing, “Latest Electric Car Will Be a BMW, From the Battery Up,” New York Times, July 1, 2010.

西南航空的第四架飞机如何导致登机口切换时间缩短十分钟的故事在《Nut s !》第 33–34 页中有讲述。

The story of how Southwest’s fourth plane led to ten-minute gate turns is told in Nuts!, 33–34.

我曾在《管理是什么》（2002 年）和《为什么商业模式很重要》（哈佛商业评论，2002 年 5 月）中写过关于戴尔的文章；我也曾在《虚拟整合的力量》（哈佛商业评论，1998 年 3 月）中采访过迈克尔·戴尔。有关戴尔的更多信息，请参阅 Jan W. Rivkin 和 Michael E. Porter 的《匹配戴尔》，案例 9-799-158（波士顿：哈佛商学院，1999 年）。

I have written about Dell in What Management Is (2002) and in “Why Business Models Matter,” Harvard Business Review, May 2002; and I interviewed Michael Dell in “The Power of Virtual Integration,” Harvard Business Review, March 1998. For more on Dell, see Jan W. Rivkin and Michael E. Porter, “Matching Dell,” Case 9-799-158 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 1999).

Nicolaj Siggelkow 在《管理学院期刊》第 44 期（2001 年）：838–857 页中撰写了有关 Liz Claiborne 的文章。

Nicolaj Siggelkow has written about Liz Claiborne in “Change in the Presence of Fit,” Academy of Management Journal 44 (2001): 838–857.

关于动荡时期战略的重要性的引述来自迈克尔·E·波特和简·W·里夫金的《行业转型》，注 701-008（波士顿：哈佛商学院，2000 年）。

The quote about the importance of strategy in turbulent times comes from Michael E. Porter and Jan W. Rivkin, “Industry Transformation,” Note 701-008 (Boston: Harvard Business School, 2000).

关于作者

About the Author

 

琼·玛格丽塔与迈克尔·波特的合作始于近二十年前，当时她是《哈佛商业评论》的战略编辑。她与波特在许多出版物上密切合作，包括他最具影响力的两篇文章：“什么是战略？”和“塑造战略的五种竞争力量”。她目前是哈佛商学院波特战略与竞争力研究所的高级研究员。

Joan Magretta’s collaboration with Michael Porter began almost two decades ago, when she was the strategy editor at Harvard Business Review. She has worked closely with Porter on many publications, including two of his most influential articles: “What Is Strategy?” and “The Five Competitive Forces That Shape Strategy.” She is currently a Senior Associate at Porter’s Institute for Strategy and Competitiveness at Harvard Business School.

玛格丽塔以撰写战略和综合管理方面的文章而闻名。1998 年，她获得了麦肯锡奖，该奖项每年颁发给《哈佛商业评论》上发表的最佳文章。她最近的一本书《管理是什么：它如何运作以及为什么它是每个人的事》 （2002 年）被翻译成 15 种语言。《金融时报》称赞这本书清晰明了，并把它评为《经济学人》年度最佳三本商业和经济学书籍之一，称它是“罕见的书籍——一本清晰、有趣且诚实的管理书籍”。它还被《商业周刊》选为十大最佳书籍之一，被誉为急需的“回归商业基础的路线图”。

Magretta is known for her writing about strategy and general management. In 1998 she won the McKinsey Award, given each year for the best article to appear in HBR. Her most recent book, What Management Is: How It Works and Why It’s Everyone’s Business (2002), appears in fifteen languages. It was praised by the Financial Times for its refreshing clarity and named one of the three best business and economics books of the year by The Economist, which described it as “A rare animal—a management book that is lucid, interesting, and honest.” It was also chosen for BusinessWeek’s top ten list, cited as a much needed “road map back to business basics.”

在加入 HBR 之前，玛格丽塔曾担任贝恩公司的合伙人。在她的职业生涯中，她为各个领域的高级管理人员提供咨询服务——从医疗保健到高级时尚，从重型制造业到高等教育。

Prior to joining HBR, Magretta was a partner at Bain & Co. Over the course of her career, she has advised senior management in a wide range of settings—from health care to high fashion, from heavy manufacturing to higher education.

在 1983 年获得哈佛商学院 MBA 学位之前，玛格丽塔曾担任人文学科教授，教授文学和电影。她是威斯康星大学优等生荣誉学会的毕业生，拥有哥伦比亚大学文学硕士学位和密歇根大学英语博士学位。

Before getting her MBA at Harvard Business School in 1983, Magretta was a professor in the humanities, teaching literature and film. She is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Wisconsin, with an MA from Columbia and a PhD in English from the University of Michigan.

*基于活动的成本核算已经存在了几十年，但不可否认的是，它很难做到。会计系统不以管理人员可以用来了解相对成本的形式提供成本数据。有关竞争优势分析的进一步指导，请参阅本章的注释。

* Activity-based costing has been around for decades, but it is admittedly hard to do. Accounting systems don’t provide cost data in a form that managers can use to understand relative costs. For further guidance on the analytics of competitive advantage, see the notes for this chapter.
